human: Naya Qeshta was born in Rafah on November 11.

human: A list of 10 “Working Rules” is taped to the concrete wall on the top floor of the Swiss architect Peter Zumthor’s studio, which overlooks a dramatic alpine landscape through floor-to-ceiling glass.

llm: A list of 120 names of artists, critics, curators and art historians was sent to the museum, with invitations extended to those who were available.

human: On Tuesday, I made the wrenching but necessary decision to resign as Harvard’s president.

human: Almost two years have passed since I began trying to draw people’s attention to the widening gap between economic perceptions and economic reality.
At the time the economic picture was mixed, with rapid job growth yet also rising inflation; even given that mixed picture, consumer sentiment seemed abnormally low.
llm: Almost two years after the start of the recession, economists and policymakers are struggling to understand its depth and breadth.
The economy has lost jobs every month since December 2007; the total is now approaching seven million.
Unemployment has reached double digits for the first time in more than a quarter century.

And while there have been glimmers of hope — a spate of recent positive economic indicators, an apparent bottoming out of home prices — it will likely be years before unemployment returns to pre-recession levels.

human: Every spring, trillions of flowers mate with the help of bees and other animals.
They lure the pollinators to their flowers with flashy colors and nectar.
As the animals travel from flower to flower, they take pollen with them, which can fertilize the seeds of other plants.
llm: Every spring, trillions of flowers burst into bloom across the world.
They come in all shapes and sizes, colors and scents — a veritable rainbow of reproductive organs that have evolved to attract specific pollinators and maximize their chances of fertilization.
But according to new research published Thursday in Science, this vibrant display is becoming less sexual over time as plants learn to make do without sex at all.

human: Instead of the usual “each week we choose a theme, and bring you three or four stories on that theme” business, this episode of “This American Life” throws all that away and brings you 20 stories — yes, 20 — in 60 minutes.

human: An inmate stabbed Derek Chauvin 22 times last week at a federal prison in Tucson, Ariz., the U.S. Attorney’s Office in Arizona said on Friday in announcing attempted murder charges.
llm: An inmate stabbed the correctional officer accused of murdering Jeffrey Epstein more than two dozen times, according to court papers filed by federal prosecutors on Monday.

Both officers have pleaded not guilty to those charges.
But the new filings give details about the attack on the third officer, who has been identified only as Officer John Doe.
They also said that the attack occurred after Mr. Epstein’s death and that it was unprovoked.
A spokesman for the Bureau of Prisons declined to comment on the allegations.

human: President Biden signed a short-term government funding bill on Thursday, narrowly averting a government shutdown but leaving a larger spending clash for Congress early next year.

The measure was approved by Congress last week after months of negotiations over border security and other policy provisions.
It provides a total of $738 billion for military programs, including money for nuclear weapons, missile defense and aircraft carriers.
It also includes funding for disaster relief, health care, education, law enforcement and infrastructure projects.

llm: WILMINGTON, Del. — A month after former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. announced that he would run for president, his campaign has yet to fully take shape.

human: “The Core of an Onion,” Mark Kurlansky’s latest single-subject food book, made me think of Thanksgiving.
He devotes an entire chapter to creamed onions, essential at Thanksgiving dinner when I was growing up.
His book has recipes for them dated to 1665 and a reference to the 1941 film “They Died With Their Boots On,” in which the onions play a role alongside Errol Flynn.

Other discussions of onion cookery — as in soup, stuffed, fried, breads, pickled, with eggs, in sandwiches (famously by James Beard) and more, with recipe histories — follow an unraveling of the onion botanically, historically, medicinally, literally, economically and gastronomically around the world.
Despite relevant but overlong digressions on the origins of the Gibson and of the bagel, it’s a lively read.
On the culinary side he might have touched on the Spanish tortilla when discussing eggs and onions; he makes an interesting point about swapping cream for milk when using older recipes.
llm: “The Core of an Onion”

human: Grief moves slowly, and war moves quickly.
After Hamas assailants killed at least 1,400 Israelis and took hundreds more hostage, Israel dropped more than 6,000 bombs on Gaza in the first week of a conflict that is ongoing.
So far, more than 5,000 Palestinians are reported dead and many more injured.
There’s no one way to cover this that reconciles all that is happening and all that needs to be felt.
llm: Grief moves slowly, in its own time.
It doesn't matter if you are grieving the loss of a loved one or the end of a marriage; we all have our way of dealing with it.
The Jewish left is now facing the unthinkable: the death of the two-state solution and their dreams of peace between Israelis and Palestinians.
They are trying to hold two thoughts in their minds at once: the two-state solution is dead but they must keep fighting for it.
That contradiction will not be resolved easily.

human: In New York, where roughly 7.7 million people flowed through the southern half of Manhattan every weekday before the pandemic — almost a quarter of them by motor vehicle — finding a place to park is not exactly easy.

human: There are two big questions right now about the U.S. economy.
One is why it’s doing so well.
The other is why so many Americans insist that it’s terrible.
llm: There are two ways of looking at Joe Biden’s economic plan, and which one you choose to adopt will likely determine your view of the man.
One is that it is a reasonable but uninspiring set of proposals—some good ideas, some bad ones, with nothing particularly exciting or new about any of them.

The other is that it is a reasonable and moderate set of proposals, but not particularly inspiring because what we need is a radical transformation of the American economy, not just a few tweaks here and there.

llm: This week, I'm thinking about what it takes to choose life over revenge.

On June 17, nine members were killed by Dylann Roof, a white supremacist.
At Roof's arraignment, several family members spoke directly to him.
They said they forgave him.
Many of us were amazed by their grace.
But this is not the first time we've seen victims of horrific crimes speak publicly about mercy, reconciliation, and

human: Nearly 50 years to the day after the Yom Kippur War in 1973, Israel was again taken by surprise by a sudden attack.
llm: Nearly 50 years ago, the Israeli military attacked a U.S. Navy ship in international waters and killed 34 Americans.
It was an act of war against America, but neither Congress nor any president since then has held Israel accountable.
If anything, they have rewarded Israel for its criminality.

llm: The Great Lawn, the grassy expanse in Central Park that has been the site of countless concerts and other events over the years, will be closed until next spring as a result of damage sustained during a series of free summer shows.

human: Why run?
I ask myself this question as I lace up my shoes, as I confront an approaching hill, as I coax one more lap out of my aching calves.
The obvious answer is that we run to be healthy, to improve our cardiovascular systems and our moods, to become fitter and stronger.
But sometimes it feels like the real reason that I run is to get better at running.
I run so that I can run more.
llm: Why run?
I don't know.
Why do people want to jump out of airplanes or go rock climbing?
It's a thrill, an adventure, a challenge and so much more.
For me, it is the way that I feel when I am running.
I love being outside in nature.
I enjoy feeling my body move as I push myself to see what I can achieve.
Running helps me clear my head and be present in the moment.
It's also about connecting with others who share the same passion.
The running community is amazing!
They are supportive, encouraging and non-judgmental.
I've met some really great people through running.
Most importantly, I have learned so much about myself and what I am capable of by pushing myself physically and mentally

human: Another year, another amazing album from Igor Levit.

Like all this pianist’s recording projects, “Fantasia” is daringly yet elegantly programmed: Eight works from across some 200 years, with four meaty masterpieces each set alongside a smaller companion.
llm: Another year, another Naxos anniversary: 30 years of the label.
It has been quite a journey so far with many highlights and even more challenges, but it’s one that we have enjoyed immensely.
We would like to take this opportunity to thank all our artists, composers, producers, engineers, and of course, listeners for making these past three decades such an incredible experience!

human: Apple resumed sales of its newest smartwatches on Thursday, a day after a federal appeals court temporarily reversed an earlier ban on their import and sale in the United States.

human: The Supreme Court is considering whether to take up the question of presidential immunity — that is, the idea that a president, by virtue of the unique nature of the office, is entitled to exceedingly broad protections from legal consequences for statements made and actions taken while in office.

What wasn’t widely known at the time was that the announcement had come after weeks of infighting within Open

human: After a long day at work, I absent-mindedly boarded an express train.
What should’ve been an 18-minute commute home turned into a 50-minute journey from Manhattan to Brooklyn and back.
Sitting on that last train to my apartment, I felt a digital dreariness overcome me.
I’d spent all day responding to emails, Slacks and DMs.
I just wanted to not look at a screen.
I didn’t have a book with me, so I took out my notebook and jotted down everything I saw, heard or smelled: A backpack occupying a seat for a human.
A woman wearing a spiky hat.
Shoelaces, untied.
Shoelaces, tied.
An aggressively yellow ad for something called Mullvad.
“Do Not Lean on Door.”
Snoring.
The person next to me typing out in a text, “Dinner next week?” before quickly deleting it and locking his phone.
llm: After a long week of work, it’s easy to feel like you haven’t accomplished much.
You might be thinking: “I didn’t change the world this week.”
But if you take a step back and think about all those little miracles that happened, you’ll realize just how much was accomplished.

human: Several months ago, as a federal judge worked through a docket of smuggling cases in the bustling border city of Laredo, Texas, three people were escorted into the courtroom.
llm: Several months ago, a group of NYU students began to question why the New York City Police Department (NYPD) had stopped and frisked them without any apparent justification.
The police officers who stopped these students were following a policy that instructs them to stop anyone in certain neighborhoods who they suspect might be involved in criminal activity.
These suspicions are often based on race and class, as well as gender and sexuality.
In fact, over 80% of those stopped are black or Latino, although only 52% of New Yorkers are black or Latino.
The stops have been especially common for young men of color, like the NYU students.

human: Inflation eased in October and price increases showed encouraging signs of slowing under the surface, according to fresh data released on Tuesday.

human: On Oct. 25, Professor Nurit Peled-Elhanan, a lecturer at a college in Jerusalem, participated in a discussion in a faculty WhatsApp group about the horrific events of Oct. 7.

We saw this gaze,” Ms. Peled-Elhanan wrote to her colleagues.
llm: On Oct. 25, 1940, the German government decreed that Jews were forbidden to change their address without official permission.
A week later, another decree ordered all Jewish businesses in Berlin closed.
And on Nov. 12, Jews were barred from using public transportation.
These measures are among many anti-Jewish laws passed by Nazi Germany in the years leading up to World War II.

human: Can magic illuminate a life that was far from magical?

human: Walking through New York City — America’s great harborer of people, culture and activity — can feel like strolling the world’s largest outdoor mall.

llm: Walking through New York's crowded streets, it's hard to imagine that the city is losing retail stores.

And it may be our fault.

human: Ivo Dimchev, a queer performance artist from Bulgaria whose brash charm has been known to compel people to take their clothes off and join him onstage — it happened at Joe’s Pub last month — has questions.

llm: Ivo Dimchev, a Bulgarian performance artist and musician, has been based in Berlin since 2009.

human: When Michael Stipe was little, his parents called him Mr. Mouse.
He was a scurrier.
As soon as he could stand, he ran, and when he ran, he ran until he face-planted.

His mother would deposit him in a baby walker, but if Stipe scrambled as fast as he could and hit the threshold of a doorway with a running start, he could topple the walker and eject himself onto the floor.
Then he’d spring to his feet and run away.
llm: When Michael Stipe, the lead singer of R.E.M., started thinking about retiring from music in 2011, he was not only contemplating leaving a band that had been together for three decades and sold tens of millions of albums, but also what he would do with his life afterward.
He was 51 at the time — an age when most people are still deep into their careers, not plotting out their next act.

The charges

human: In the 1970s and ’80s, when Rainer Judd was growing up at 101 Spring Street in New York’s SoHo with her father, the artist Donald Judd, she’d sit in the building’s open windows, “because no one told me not to,” she said, and because back then, SoHo was a “creaky, dirty, lovely place.”
In 1971, her father wrote that one day, the neighborhood might be invaded by “tourist shops and restaurants, bad art and high rents.”

And while this premonition has largely come to pass, his home, a cast-iron former textile factory where his family — which also included his wife, the dancer Julie Finch, and his son, Flavin — lived according to Judd’s influential ideas about art and architecture, is almost entirely unchanged.
llm: In the 1970s, a group of artists in New York City set out to challenge painting.
They wanted to rethink what an artwork could be, using new materials and methods to create objects that didn't hang on walls or sit on pedestals.

These founders didn’t have much experience running a business, so naturally there

human: One by one, the inmates filed into a chapel at Sing Sing Correctional Facility in Ossining, N.Y. — past a line of security officers, past a sign reading, “Open wide the door to Christ.”

llm: One by one, the men walked into the chapel and took their places in front of a standing-room crowd.

There was an electrician, two chefs, a truck driver, a barber, a janitor, a furniture maker, a former drug dealer and a former pimp who once beat up a woman with her own crutch for not earning enough money.

human: I first heard the band Sleater-Kinney when I was a teenager, and it’s not an exaggeration to say it changed my life.

The early 2000s were a particularly macho time in rock music — all wounded emo boys and nü-metal aggressors — and even in the late ’90s it was difficult to find female musicians lauded for how well they played their instruments rather than the way they looked.
Then I happened upon a live recording of Sleater-Kinney playing its 1997 song “Words and Guitar,” and it blew my hair back like I’d entered a wind tunnel.
llm: I first heard Sleater Kinney in 2003, when I was working at a record store in my hometown.
The album was One Beat and the song was “Step Aside,” which I remember playing over and over again on repeat.
That song made me realize that there are songs you can’t listen to just once.
You have to play them again and again because each time they reveal something new—another layer of meaning, another sound or texture, an emotion you didn’t hear before.
That’s why I love music: It never stops surprising you.

human: Buying things in bulk at wholesale retailers can be an all-day affair.

llm: Buying things in bulk is a great way to save money.
There are some items that you should not buy in bulk though.
It might seem like a good idea because it is cheaper but you could be wasting your money if you do not use all of what you bought before it goes bad.
Here are five food items you should never buy in bulk and why: 1. Meat Meat will spoil quickly so only buy enough for one week.
If you want to buy more than one package then put them into freezer bags and make sure they are frozen solid.

human: Despite the chockablock ballroom full of Hollywood’s best and brightest, a jovial emcee in the comedian John Mulaney and honorees the audience seemed thrilled to celebrate, a pall of sadness was cast over the Governors Awards — an event created 14 years ago by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences to shorten the Oscar telecast by relegating the honorary Oscars to its own untelevised confab.

human: There are many reasons to be horrified about recent events in the Middle East, and the prospect that attacks on shipping might undermine progress against inflation is way, way down the list.

llm: There are many stories, myths and legends about the parting of the Red Sea.
The Bible is the only document that makes a claim for such an event.
Is there any evidence in the Bible for the existence of the Red Sea?
In this talk I will show you why it should be called the Reed Sea.
I will also discuss whether the Biblical story can be considered historical or not.

human: Shining out from the Instagram slag heap, amid the endless A.I. selfies and reaction reels, is an account so quiet in presence and noble in intention that it is sometimes hard to believe it exists.

human: Across the U.S., roughly 6 million adults 65 and over have Alzheimer’s disease.

llm: Across the U.S., people are dying from a drug overdose every 19 minutes, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

In 2017 alone, more than 49,000 Americans died of opioid overdoses, and that number is likely to rise this year as well.1 This has become a national crisis, one that now claims more lives than car accidents or gun violence.

human: Sometimes in this job I have a kernel of a column idea that doesn’t pan out.

This latter experience happened as I looked into the growing bureaucratization of American life.
It’s not only that growing bureaucracies cost a lot of money; they also enervate American society.
They redistribute power from workers to rule makers, and in so doing sap initiative, discretion, creativity and drive.
llm: Sometimes in this world, you have to die a little bit before you can live again.

human: When Meg Bellamy got the call that would change her life — the one telling her that after months of auditions, it was she, among thousands of hopefuls, who would play Kate Middleton in the final season of “The Crown” — she was already standing in the shadow of Windsor Castle.

llm: When Meg Bellamy takes on a role, she commits.

human: My mother and I disagree on a lot, but we often put our disagreements aside to enjoy a healthier relationship, even if it’s on a surface level.
She has been anti-abortion my entire life.
We now live on opposite sides of the country and see each other maybe twice a year.
When she visits, she often speaks of abortion as murder; her tone is visceral.
She is very aware of my pro-choice beliefs, but she does not know that I have had two abortions (neither of which I regret).
I am in my 30s, and each passing year my desire to be a mother decreases exponentially.
Recently, she has begun to complain about her lack of grandchildren.
I have chosen not to tell her about my abortions, because this information might be grief-inducing for her.
But as she continues to push her ideologies on me, I feel more and more compelled to share my life experiences and choices.
What do I owe her?— Name Withheld
llm: My mother and I have always had a very close relationship, but there is one thing that has kept us from being completely open with each other: abortion.
My mother is staunchly pro-life; she has participated in marches for life and has written letters to the editor of our local newspaper about her views on the issue.
She believes that women who get an abortion are committing murder, period.

human: Almost everyone on the stage outside San Francisco’s City Hall on Thursday afternoon was a woman: the vice president, the former speaker of the House, the city’s mayor and more.
llm: Almost everyone on the national political scene in the early 1970s was a man.
Then a city supervisor named Dianne Feinstein decided to run for mayor of San Francisco, and won.
When her predecessor was assassinated, she became acting mayor—the first woman to hold the job.
And when she ran for a full term as mayor, she won again, by the largest margin in the city's history.
At that time, only one woman had ever been elected governor or U.S. senator; today there are nine women governors and eighteen women senators.
In this video created for the Women and Leadership Archives at Loyola University Chicago, women leaders look back on Feinstein's historic role, and what it meant for them and their own careers

human: Over the two weeks that dozens of Indian construction workers have been trapped in a Himalayan road tunnel, the authorities have reported meter-by-meter progress toward reaching them and offered hopeful timelines for their rescue.

llm: Over the two weeks of their ordeal, the miners have made it clear that they are not ready to die.

human: It was a relief to learn of the arrest last week of a 21-year-old Cornell University student for threatening to rape and murder Jews on campus in reaction to the Israel-Hamas war.

llm: It was a rhetorical question, of course.
The answer is that they're not expected to live like this on campus—at least not at any other university in the country.

students permitted to camp out for days or
even weeks at a time.
And if those two campuses are anything to go by, then it's only a matter of time before tent cities become a common feature of college life all over California.

human: In the year since OpenAI sparked an artificial intelligence boom with its popular ChatGPT chatbot, start-ups and tech giants have been scrambling to develop semiconductors to power the buzzy technology, hoping to muscle in on Nvidia’s market dominance.

human: “Inspector Sun,” a computer-animated family film released in Spain last year and now arriving in an English-language dubbed version, is very clearly a product of the director Julio Soto Gurpide and the screenwriter Rocco Pucillo’s deep affection for motion picture history.
The movie draws on a range of classics, from silent adventure serials to screwball mysteries like “The Thin Man” to the swashbuckling epics of Douglas Fairbanks and Errol Flynn.
llm: “Inspector Sun,” a Chinese-language action movie, is full of references to classic films.
The story itself is an homage to “The Usual Suspects” (1995), as the detective played by Wang Baoqiang is told a wild tale by a man who has been arrested on suspicion of murdering his wife.
But the movie is also filled with references to other crime classics like “Reservoir Dogs” and “Se7en.”
It’s a strange concoction that doesn’t always work, but there are some fun moments.

human: On Oct. 26, the Department of Commerce announced that gross domestic product grew at an annual rate of 4.9 percent in the third quarter.

President Biden issued a self-congratulatory statement, and the White House echoed it over and over — and Donald Trump’s relative popularity increased.
llm: On Oct. 26, the vice president of the United States gave a speech in which he called for an end to “trickle-down economics.”
The next day, a reporter asked President Obama about it.

human: David Chang is “pausing operations” at Momofuku Ko next week, according to a post on his company’s Instagram account.

llm: David Chang is a pretty good guy.
He has a big ego, sure, but he doesn't let it get in the way of his work.
He's not afraid to be honest about himself and his business, which is why I think this article by Pete Wells is so interesting.
I don't know that I agree with everything he says, but it definitely makes me consider what he's saying.
The more you read about restaurants and chefs, the more you understand that they are just people like everyone else.
They have their flaws, but they also have things that make them great.
You can love or hate what they do, but at least you can appreciate how hard they worked to get where they are.

human: Growing up in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley, the Opinion editorial assistant Adrian J. Rivera was no stranger to processed food.

In this audio essay, he reflects on his relationship with processed food, class and what it’s like to go home with a new set of tastes.
llm: Growing up in suburban Maryland, the closest thing to a Parisian pastry shop was the McDonald's down the street from my house, so it made sense that when I fell under Proust's spell, I turned not to madeleines but to Chicken McNuggets.
After all, everyone has a favorite food, and mine happens to be McNuggets dipped in honey mustard sauce.

human: A couple of weeks ago, a young crowd in Shanghai came out in force to celebrate Halloween.
The street where I live filled with revelers dressed in a range of elaborate costumes — as the white-clad enforcers of China’s Covid lockdowns, as Chinese courtesans or simply as a watermelon.
Halloween allows us to dress up as something that we can’t otherwise be.

It’s a strong impulse right now in China, which remains stuck in a postpandemic malaise marked by job shortages, a trend of disillusioned 20-somethings dropping out of the work force and society and a general yearning for a different way to be.
llm: A couple of months ago, we had a piece in The Diplomat about how China’s “Five Generation” (5G) leadership was beginning to take shape.

At the time, we noted that the most senior members of the fifth generation were already assuming prominent positions within the Chinese Communist Party (CCP), and thus likely to be appointed to top jobs at the 19th Party Congress next year.

human: It was one of New York City’s most enduring crises: For decades, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had warned that it was teetering on the brink of financial ruin.
llm: It was one of the more remarkable public policy turnarounds in recent memory: Just a few years ago, New York City’s subway system — once a global model for efficiency and reliability — seemed to be broken beyond repair.
Then the Metropolitan Transportation Authority (MTA), which operates the subways, began to implement a series of service improvements.
The trains are still crowded during rush hour, but they have become more reliable, with fewer delays.

human: Maj. Gen. Roland Lajoie, who, behind the geopolitical scenes, played a leading role in coordinating U.S.-Soviet relations during the last decade of the Cold War, and who later oversaw the destruction of hundreds of nuclear weapons belonging to the former Soviet republics, died on Oct. 28 in Manchester, N.H.
He was 87.
llm: Maj. Gen. Roland G. Lajoie, a decorated combat veteran of two wars who was assigned to the Pentagon during the Cuban missile crisis and later served as commander of American forces in Berlin when Soviet tanks were rolling through the streets of Prague, died on Nov. 15 in Fairfax, Va.

human: Ever since I was a little girl I’d dreamed of going to Darjeeling.

human: On May 20, 1964, on a hilltop in New Jersey, an unlikely little structure called the Holmdel Horn revealed telltale signs of the Big Bang, and the birth of the universe we live in.

llm: On May 20, 1965, a group of friends gathered in an art gallery on Manhattan's Upper East Side.

Inside, however, the atmosphere was charged with excitement.
The crowd was there for the opening of the Andre Emmerich Gallery, which would soon become one of the most important venues in America for showing contemporary art.
And they were eager to see what its first show had to offer.

human: “Everything needed for the front,” Russia’s finance minister declared, echoing a Soviet slogan from World War II as he talked about the government’s latest spending plans.
llm: “Everything needed for war is being made by us.
We have started to manufacture everything we need, even the most complex equipment,” says Deputy Prime Minister Dmitri Rogozin on a recent episode of the pro-Kremlin talk show 60 Minutes.

human: She flirted with Brando and even Prince Charles.

llm: She flirted with the idea of a career in fashion, but Barbra Streisand says she ultimately decided against it.
“I thought about being a designer,” she tells PEOPLE.
“But I realized that I really like to wear other people’s clothes.
I don’t want to make my own.”
So instead, she’ll just continue to shop for them—a skill she honed at an early age.
“My mother dressed me as a little girl and I loved clothes so much that I was able to pick out things that suited me,” she recalls.
“It was always part of who I am.”

human: A few blocks from where the Cronut was born, a new pastry mash-up by a French chef is making its debut.

Gregory Doyen developed a cakelike confection inspired by brownies and cookies that’s round, about three inches in diameter, fairly dense and with a central opening where a ganache or fruit filling goes.
Mr. Doyen is calling it MOD, for multilayered original dessert.
It’s offered as a single serving ($7.50 each) and in fours ($29), and can be shared and personalized.
In a show of extreme confidence, it’s the only product sold in the bright white shop of the same name he owns with Edward Geyman, his business partner.

A native of the Burgundy region in France who studied pastry-making and has been a pastry consultant in many countries around the globe, Mr. Doyen, 38, arrived in the United States a year ago and began working on this project.
“I didn’t just want to reproduce French pastry,” he said.
The flavor and filling combinations are endless.

For now he has eight colorful examples, including peanut butter and jelly, matcha with white chocolate, walnut with dark chocolate, red velvet with dark chocolate and raspberry, and pecan caramel with milk chocolate chips and sea salt.
He has a featured flavor of the month, which for now is s’mores with a marshmallow topping that he torches before serving.
He said he’s working on a mini size.
llm: A few blocks away, there's another bakery with a name that might be familiar to fans of Ace of Cakes: Charm City Cakes West, which has opened at 8310 W. Third St. (near La Cienega Boulevard).
It's an offshoot of Duff Goldman's bakery in Baltimore and will serve some of its signature cakes as well as cupcakes and macarons.
And if you want something savory, they also have sandwiches and salads on the menu.

human: It will be a long time before any of us understand what happened after Oct. 7, but it seems important first to recognize how news of everything comes to us today.

Newspaper headlines aren’t fixed — they change over the course of a day; social media presents tragedies in fragmented shards, which are then contested and rejected and reaffirmed; television news, especially on foreign affairs, remains too hyper and flashy to take seriously.
Every single one of us had our own individualized experience of that day and the days after it.
No one can confidently say who knew what when.
llm: It will be interesting to see how this book develops over time.
I have read the first edition and it is full of facts, but lacking in interpretation or analysis.
The authors are young and may grow into the task.
They do not seem to know much about the history of terrorism and its impact on American society from 1960 through the 2000's.
It would be helpful if they had some historical perspective on terrorist attacks before 9/11.

human: Trader Joe’s, West Hollywood.
“Your total is $20.69,” announces the cashier at my register.
Seconds later, the cashier at the next register over says to a male customer, “Your total is $20.69.”
Wait, what?
The staff whoops.
Someone says, “No way!”
He and I grin sloppily in the sudden spotlight, paired so arbitrarily by groceries.
Bystander: “It’s a rom-com opening, baby!”
The other $20.69 meets my eyes, testing gently for truth in that idea.
For a moment, I entertain another universe — one where I’m not gay — and smile wide.
Then I say, “Good night.”
— Zoe Marie Bel
llm: Trader Joe’s, Westwood Boulevard, Los Angeles.
Credit Jake Michaels for The New York Times

human: For this landmark biography, Tick, a music historian, leans on a rich trove of archival research — in particular, articles from recently digitized Black newspapers — as well as new material from Fitzgerald’s family, including a scrapbook the jazz legend kept when she was 18.

human: “It is up to us to write our own history,” declares the organizer of the desperate project at the heart of Lauren Grodstein’s latest novel, WE MUST NOT THINK OF OURSELVES (Algonquin, 304 pp., $34).
He’s speaking on a bleak afternoonomg in one of the bleakest places in Poland, the Warsaw ghetto in December 1940.

llm: “It is up to us to make sure we don’t let the world we live in go to sleep.

human: The final game of the playoff series between the Houston Astros and the Minnesota Twins on Wednesday lasted only two hours and 38 minutes.

llm: The final game of the 1968 World Series between the Detroit Tigers and the St. Louis Cardinals was a pitching duel for the ages, with Mickey Lolich of Detroit facing off against Bob Gibson of St. Louis.
The teams were tied at three games apiece.
Both men were on top of their game that day; Gibson struck out a then-World Series record fifteen batters, while Lolich fanned ten.
But the Cardinals' fireballer would not get his name in the record books this time around.
With one out in the seventh inning, Jim Northrup hit a home run to give the Tigers a 4–3 lead, which they never relinquished.

human: During the difficult months of 2020, a writer friend and I decided to read Willa Cather’s fiction together.

human: On Christmas Eve in 2013, Elisa Stead, an American living abroad in Iceland, was ready to celebrate the holiday with her fiancé and his family.
But when she tore open the wrapping on his gift for her, she was disheartened to discover what lay inside: a car-window scraper.
Sure, she lived in a frosty place, but she didn’t own a car.
Receiving such a thoughtless gift made for an unhappy holiday, and the relationship ended within the year.
llm: On Christmas Eve 2016, my daughter and I were invited to a beautiful Christmas dinner in an old farmhouse on the outskirts of town.
The meal was delicious, but as we were leaving, one of our hosts said something that caught my attention.
He had been cleaning up after dinner and, with his back turned to us, he told us about his childhood growing up in that very house.
His father had been a farmer, he explained, and they raised cows, chickens, pigs, sheep and other animals on their property.
It was hard work, he recalled, but it taught him responsibility, and his family always made sure there was enough food for everyone who lived there.

human: Celebrities streamed onto the lush red carpet to pose in front of the floral backdrop for the Golden Globes on Sunday night as the awards ceremony made a return to television (it wasn’t broadcast in 2022, and was moved to a Tuesday evening last year).

human: My wife became pregnant soon after we met, when our relationship was “fluid” and non-monogamous.
We agreed to raise the child together and, at my urging, to have an open relationship.
However, our relationship since has been monogamous.
My wife was injured during the birth of our second child and now finds sex painful and avoids it.
(We had a terrific sex life before the injury.)
When I broached the topic of having other partners and reminded her of our agreement to have an open relationship, she became irritated and said that having kids changed things.
Subsequent discussions resulted in a stalemate.
llm: My wife became a believer in polyamory after reading The Ethical Slut, and we agreed that we would try it out.
But then she changed her mind, and now she’s furious that I hooked up with another woman when I was out of town on business.
She says I violated our marriage vows.
I feel like my hands were tied: She proposed non-monogamy, I tried it, she decided it wasn’t for her, and now I’m the bad guy?

human: The ruins of Mitla sit about 30 miles from Oaxaca in the mountains of southern Mexico, built on a high valley floor as a gateway between the world of the living and the dead.
The site was established in roughly A.D. 200  as a fortified village, and then as a burial ground by the Zapotecs, the so-called Cloud People, who settled in the region around 1500 B.C.
llm: The ruins of Monte Albán, in Oaxaca, Mexico, have been a source of mystery for more than 150 years.
The strange stone carvings found here are reminiscent of the artwork at Chichen Itza and other Mayan sites in the Yucatan Peninsula.

human: For the two days after a gunman killed 18 people and injured 13 in Lewiston, Maine, Patrick Hynes and other residents in the area sat in their own homes, under a shelter-in-place order, facing their grief, their rage, in isolation.
llm: For the two days after the bombing at the Boston Marathon that left three people dead and more than 180 injured, the city of Lewiston, Maine, was under lockdown.
The suspects in the bombing were believed to be hiding in a nearby neighborhood.

human: Israeli citizens, barricaded in their homes in towns near the Gaza Strip, called into television stations as Palestinian gunmen crossed the border into Israel and invaded their communities on Saturday morning.
The Israelis spoke in whispers as they pleaded desperately for help.
llm: Israeli citizens, barricaded in their homes or driving around in cars with shattered windshields, are being terrorized by the rockets from Gaza.
The Palestinians of Gaza, who have nowhere to hide, are being terrorized by the Israeli bombing campaign.
That’s how a war of mutual destruction works: Both sides feel under siege; both believe themselves to be the victim; neither shows any mercy.

human: “Put on your masks!”
llm: “Put on your oxygen mask before assisting others.”
I’m sure you’ve heard this saying.
The idea is that we need to take care of ourselves so we can then be effective in helping others.
We all have limits, and if we exceed those limits, our ability to help will suffer.
It seems like common sense, right?
Yet, it’s not always easy to practice.
In fact, sometimes it feels counterintuitive.
When someone needs us, we want to give everything we’ve got – even if it means depleting ourselves.

human: Fuel shortages in the Gaza Strip have grown so dire that the U.N. agency that has helped feed, school and shelter Palestinians there for decades said Wednesday that it might have to start shutting down operations.
llm: Fuel shortages in the Gaza Strip are hampering humanitarian work and could force a United Nations agency to cut food aid or other services for Palestinians there, officials said Tuesday.
The fuel shortage is the latest manifestation of a broader Israeli policy of tightening its blockade on the territory, home to 1.5 million Palestinians, since Hamas seized control last June.
The siege has brought the economy to a virtual standstill and caused widespread suffering.

human: The Safdie brothers, the filmmaking duo behind “Uncut Gems” (2019) and “Good Time” (2017), are splitting up.
llm: The Safdie brothers, Josh and Benny, are a directing duo who have worked together on films like Heaven Knows What (2014) and Good Time (2017).
But it seems their working relationship has come to an end.
While speaking with Indiewire, the pair explained that they’re done making movies together.

human: Maine’s top election official said on Friday she intended to appeal the ruling by a state Superior Court judge this week that placed on hold her decision to exclude former President Donald J. Trump from the state’s Republican primary ballot.
llm: Maine’s top election official is going to appeal a court ruling that says she must put Donald Trump on the ballot in November.

human: The fate of the sons of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the man accused of being the mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, has long been a source of mystery and controversy.
llm: The fate of the sons is unknown, but it may be linked to an unresolved episode in which Mr. al-Marri was beaten by FBI agents and later pleaded guilty to one charge of providing material support for terrorism.
He was sentenced to eight years in prison and released in January 2009; he returned to Qatar.

human: Nikki Haley ratcheted up her calls this week for the U.S. government to ban TikTok, the Chinese-owned social media platform, after some users, weighing in on the war between Israel and Hamas, promoted “Letter to America,” a text written by Osama bin Laden after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
llm: Nikki Haley ratcheted up her campaign against the popular Chinese video app TikTok on Wednesday after a letter from Osama bin Laden resurfaced online.

In an interview with the New York Times, the former United Nations ambassador reiterated her calls to have the app banned in the U.S., claiming that it poses a national security threat because of its close ties to China's government.

human: What books are on your night stand?
llm: What books are on your summer reading list?

human: When a jury of military officers is assembled this week at Guantánamo Bay, it will be asked to choose a sentence in the 20- to 25-year range for two Malaysian prisoners who admitted to conspiring with an affiliate of Al Qaeda that carried out a deadly bombing in Indonesia two decades ago.
llm: When a jury in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia found Hamdan guilty on August 6, it became the first time that a war crimes trial had been completed by a military commission since World War II.
The tribunal acquitted him on one count and deadlocked on another.
However, Hamdan was convicted of providing material support for terrorism and the judge sentenced him to five and a half years in prison.
He will also be eligible for credit for his time served at Guantanamo Bay since he was captured.

human: A prominent cancer center affiliated with Harvard said it will ask medical journals to retract six research papers and correct dozens of others after a British scientist and blogger found that work by some of its top executives was rife with duplicated or manipulated data.
llm: A prominent cancer research center in Houston is trying to retract 18 scientific papers and correct another three, after an anonymous tip raised concerns about the validity of the data.

human: “I was delighted to learn from this charming song all about the qualities, habits and foibles of the unicorn, or ‘monoceron,’” a character says near the start of “The Hunt,” Kate Soper’s latest work of music theater.
llm: “I was delighted and enthralled by The Hunt.
It is a wonderful, playful piece of theatre that is both funny and profoundly moving in equal measure.
A brilliant cast led by the incomparable Janet Suzman deliver an excellent performance.
I loved every second.”

human: The future of OpenAI is in jeopardy after more than 700 of its 770 employees signed a letter yesterday saying they may leave the company for Microsoft if the ousted chief executive, Sam Altman, is not reinstalled at the high-profile artificial intelligence start-up.
llm: The future of OpenAI is uncertain, and the company may be sold.

human: Aleksei A. Navalny, Russia’s most prominent opposition leader, who is currently serving a 19-year sentence in a Russian penal colony, missed another court date on Monday as his allies expressed concern at not having heard from him for more than five days.
llm: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, has missed a court date in Moscow on Tuesday morning, raising alarm among his supporters and speculation that he had been arrested or detained by law enforcement officials.

human: We’re living through an era of collapsing paradigms.
The conceptual frames that many people use to organize their understanding of the world are crashing and burning upon contact with Middle Eastern reality.
llm: We’re living through a global refugee crisis.
It has become one of the most contentious political issues of our time, with people risking their lives to flee conflict and poverty.
The Middle East is at the center of this issue.

human: Pakistan announced yesterday that it had carried out strikes against what it said were terrorist hide-outs in Iran.
A day earlier, Iran hit what it called militant camps in Pakistan.
The military exchange is the latest example of an expanding set of hostilities connected to the Israel-Hamas war.
llm: Pakistan announced yesterday that it had carried out airstrikes against militant hideouts in Afghanistan, just days after a deadly Taliban assault on a Peshawar school left 148 people dead.
The military said that the strikes were in response to information about attacks planned by Pakistani Taliban fighters hiding in Afghanistan.

human: “It all began with writing,” goes the first line of Adam Thirlwell’s latest novel, in which a young socialite named Celine is slandered in pornographic, anonymously authored pamphlets circulating in prerevolutionary Paris.

Four pages later, Thirlwell clears his throat — actually, Celine’s publicity troubles go back to the Big Bang: “The universe disintegrates into a cloud of heat, it falls inevitably into a vortex of entropy, but within this irreversible process there may be areas of order, portions of existence that tend toward a form, in which it might be possible to discern a design — and one of these was this story of Celine and her friends.”
This could have gone without saying, but Thirlwell can’t help himself.
In “The Future Future,” the English writer compulsively gestures to the biggest picture and decides it’s the gesture that’s profound.
llm: “It all began with a glimpse into a room…”

human: Heather Sellers wrote her Modern Love essay in 2013, about reconnecting with her elderly, estranged father.
Although their relationship was painful, Heather made sure that her last words to her father were “I love you.”
And at the time, that felt like closure.
llm: Heather Sellers wrote this essay about her son's autism, and then changed her mind.

llm: The New York Times has a story about the alleged sexual misconduct of Judge Alex Kozinski.

human: The linen closet did not hold nearly enough sheets to blunt the vengeance of a late-May freeze that turned umbrella-like Astilboides leaves into alien life-forms.
llm: The linen closet in my guest bathroom is so small that it's impossible to open the door without bumping into something.
The door doesn't even open all the way.

human: The collapse of Silicon Valley Bank, the conviction of Sam Bankman-Fried, the reassertion of union power and the turmoil at OpenAI were just some of the big business stories in a year that was full of them.
llm: The collapse of the stock market and its effect on businesses.

human: The president of Harvard, Claudine Gay, will remain in her job, the university announced on Tuesday, despite demands for her resignation because of her testimony in a congressional hearing on campus antisemitism.
llm: The president of Harvard University is the chief administrator of the university and the ex officio chairman of the Harvard Corporation.

Each president is appointed by and is responsible to the corporation; in practice, this has meant that since 1672, presidents have been selected by an influential group within the corporation known as the “board”—made up of the president, treasurer, and five other members—which is self-perpetuating and whose membership is kept secret.
The first president was Henry Dunster; the current president, Drew Gilpin Faust, announced in February 2018 that she would step down at the end of June 2018.
She will be succeeded on July 1, 2018 by Lawrence Bacow.

human: Talk to any friends of the writer Hisham Matar, and he has many, and soon they’ll bring up one of his more notorious pastimes: Have you ever seen how he looks at art?
llm: Talk to any writer, and they'll tell you that writing is a process of discovery.
The story unfolds as the author writes it, and the author may be surprised by what happens in their own book.
In a way, this is true for readers too: A reader can only read a book once for the first time; once you know how it ends, there's no going back.

human: Q: I live in a co-op apartment on the Upper West Side.
There is a rent-stabilized apartment on my floor occupied by an older couple who have lived here for 50 years and have serious health issues.
This morning, one of the occupants, who has advanced dementia, opened my apartment door, which was briefly unlocked, and was standing in my living room!
I was able to gently escort her back to her apartment.
Building management said that they have spoken to the city’s adult protective services, which has investigated and declined to act.
This is a terrible situation — there are no interested family members, and the couple is often unbathed and walking the halls.
What can we do?
llm: Q: I live in an apartment building that is home to several senior citizens.
Over the last few years, I have noticed these neighbors struggling more and more to take care of themselves and their apartments.
I am concerned for their safety as well as my own, since this building has only one exit and it is difficult for some residents to get around quickly.
What can we do?
— Anonymous

human: In late 2016, when the private equity mogul Leon Black was trying to sell one expensive piece of art to buy another without incurring a hefty tax bill, he turned to the one man he knew who could help pull it off: his friend Jeffrey Epstein.
llm: In late 2016, Steven A. Cohen was approached with an offer that would be hard to refuse.

human: After the brass band packed up its instruments, Sergio Solano and two other food delivery workers walked a white bicycle to an overpass within view of the United Nations headquarters.
llm: After the brassy opening number of “The Cher Show,” the jukebox musical about the diva that opened on Monday at the Neil Simon Theater, a single question permeates the theater: Is the actress playing Cher — or Bob Mackie?
The designer’s outré gowns, some re-created from scratch for this show and others plucked from his archive, are the true stars of “The Cher Show.”

human: What happened in the wake of those arrests would expose a juvenile justice system that was playing by its own rules.
For over a decade, this county had arrested and illegally jailed hundreds, maybe thousands, of children.
It would take years, but eventually one lawyer, a former juvenile delinquent himself, asked: Why?
The answer would lead back to a powerful judge, the jailer she appointed and a county that treated this astronomical number of arrests as normal.
llm: What happened in the 1950s to make the kids from the middle-class community of Murfreesboro, Tennessee so different?
How did they grow up to be such a diverse group?
This is a story about the kids who grew up in the fifties and sixties in a small town.
They were not all good, but none of them were bad.
Their lives intertwined, their stories are true.

human: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has long cast himself as a friend of Israel and the Jewish people.
llm: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has been quick to offer condemnations when terrorist attacks hit the West, but he has been more circumspect in his response to the recent attack from Syria on Israeli territory.

human: A New York City carriage driver was charged with animal cruelty on Wednesday in a case arising from a feeble horse’s collapse on a busy Hell’s Kitchen street in August 2022.
llm: A New York City carriage driver was arrested and charged with animal cruelty on Thursday after his horse collapsed from apparent heat exhaustion.
The incident is the latest in a string of incidents that have brought increased scrutiny to the city’s carriage industry, which has been the subject of controversy for years.

human: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau on Wednesday proposed a rule that would sharply limit overdraft charges at the largest banks and credit unions in the United States, a change that the agency estimated could save households up to $3.5 billion a year in fees.
llm: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has proposed limiting the number of overdraft fees a bank can charge to consumers who overdraw their accounts.
The bureau is also considering requiring banks to tell consumers when they are about to incur an overdraft fee.

human: At the top of Mount Hamilton, near San Jose, Calif., Lick Observatory looks out over the dense sprawl of the San Francisco Bay Area.
On a clear day from the 4,200-foot summit, you can see San Francisco to the north, as well as the entrance to Yosemite Valley, 120 miles east, as the crow flies.
At night you can see even farther — millions of light-years into space.
llm: At the top of Mauna Kea on Hawaii's Big Island, there is a cluster of astronomical observatories.
The most famous of these are two huge telescopes: one that was built in 1970 and another that was completed in 2003.
But nestled between them is a small building, just 6 m (20 ft) wide, which houses an older telescope with a much more colorful history.

human: “Two things are true: Israel must do something, and what it’s doing now is indefensible.”

llm: “Two things are infinite: the universe and human stupidity; and I'm not sure about the universe.” - Albert Einstein.

human: It was just after noon on an early September Saturday when the first call came.
llm: It was just another night in Los Angeles, and I was alone.
The sun had set a few hours before, but it was still hot enough for my roommate to open the sliding glass door that led out to our patio.
She had gone to bed already; I was procrastinating, as usual.

human: Apparently, some time in 1964, a professional ice skater and animal trainer named Dave Pitts, on the road with his chimp Spanky, picked up a young hitchhiker who was in the middle of a killing spree.
The story of Pitts’s encounter with Larry Lee Ranes, whose brother also became a serial killer, was fictionalized in Conrad Hilberry’s book “Luke Karamazov.”
That book is the source of “He Went That Way,” the picturesque feature directing debut of the cinematographer Jeff Darling, who died in a surfing accident in 2022.
llm: Apparently, some time back, I was given the opportunity to review this book.
However, due to circumstances beyond my control, I was unable to get it read and reviewed in time.
The author was gracious enough to send me another copy for this review.
Thanks goes out to him for that.

human: Donald J. Trump is showing surprising resilience on the abortion issue, appearing less vulnerable than fellow Republicans despite his key role in shaping the Supreme Court that overturned Roe v. Wade.
llm: Donald J. Trump’s history of supporting abortion rights has led some Republicans to consider him the most vulnerable presidential candidate in years on the issue, which is often a major factor in voting decisions.
But Mr. Trump’s comments about Planned Parenthood and his past support for abortion access could make it difficult for Hillary Clinton to attack him effectively, pollsters say.

human: As the Kremlin reveled in the failure of Congress to approve new military assistance for Ukraine and President Biden railed against Republican lawmakers for “kneecapping” an ally in their hour of need, Ukrainian soldiers, political leaders and Kyiv’s allies were all left asking the same question on Thursday: What happens if the United States stops providing military assistance?
llm: As the Kremlin-backed war in eastern Ukraine drags on, there are signs that the United States is quietly backing away from its commitment to provide Kiev with military assistance, further evidence of waning American resolve to counter Russian President Vladimir Putin’s renewed aggression.

human: The math performance of U.S. teenagers has sharply declined since 2018, with scores lower than 20 years ago, and with American students continuing to trail global competitors, according to the results of a key international exam released on Tuesday.
llm: The math performance of students in the United States has dropped over the last two years on a global exam administered every four years to 15-year-olds in dozens of countries.

The results from the National Center for Education Statistics, which released them this morning, show that U.S. students' average score on the Programme for International Student Assessment fell by seven points between 2015 and 2018.
That's lower than the average score in most other developed countries.

human: Good morning, dear connectors.

human: A man rented a room in an Atlanta suburb on Airbnb last week, and then robbed the host at gunpoint, the police said.
llm: A man rented a room on Airbnb and robbed the host at gunpoint.

The police report also stated that Mr. White used a stolen credit card to book the stay.
This is the first incident of this kind involving Airbnb.

human: So the federal government wasn’t shut down over the weekend, although we may have to go through this whole drama again in six weeks.

Kevin McCarthy, the speaker of the House, ended up doing the obvious: bringing a funding bill to the floor that could pass only with Democratic votes, because the hard-liners in his own party wouldn’t agree to anything feasible.
And the bill didn’t include any of the spending cuts Republicans have been demanding, except for one big, bad thing: a cutoff of aid to Ukraine.
llm: So the federal budget is balanced.
The deficit is gone, and the national debt is actually going down (not up).
In fact, it's gone so well that we can afford to give a huge tax cut for the richest 1% of Americans.
And all this will be paid for by cutting health care programs for the poor.
Or something like that...

human: Former Gov. Nikki Haley of South Carolina has tried to carve a more moderate path on the contentious issue of abortion than many of her rivals for the Republican nomination for president.
llm: Former Gov. Nikki Haley told the Washington Examiner on Tuesday that she would have signed a bill banning abortions after six weeks if it had been put in front of her while she was still governor of South Carolina.

human: New Haveners and Yale graduates alike size one another up with a handshake and a single question: What’s your favorite pizza place?

human: In Britain, Armistice Day is usually an understated affair, marked only by two minutes of silence at 11 a.m.
This year was considerably more eventful, as two very different protests descended on London.
llm: In Britain, Armistice Day is known as Remembrance Day.
The red poppy is worn to remember those who died in the two world wars and subsequent conflicts.
This year, the remembrance of those who gave their lives for their country has become a focal point for the debate over the nature of Britishness.
In the 2016 referendum on Brexit, the majority of voters in England and Wales voted to leave the European Union, while majorities in Scotland and Northern Ireland voted to remain.
Now, some pro-EU Scots are refusing to wear the traditional poppies as an act of defiance against Brexiteers whom they accuse of hijacking British patriotism.
Meanwhile, the far right is trying to appropriate the symbolism of the poppy to its

human: The word congenial has appeared in 38 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Dec. 7 in “Day 7: Finding Inner Peace While You’re Underground” by Jack Denton:
llm: The word congenial has been around in English since at least 1580.
It comes from the Latin word congenium, which means “born with,” and its original meaning was “born together.”
In English it came to mean “agreeable” or “suitable.”
A person who is agreeable is someone whose company you enjoy; a suitable person is one who fits well into his or her surroundings.
If something is suitable for an occasion, then it’s appropriate for that particular time and place.

human: American shoppers, burned by more than two years of rapid inflation, are getting some welcome relief this holiday season: Prices on many products are falling.
llm: American shoppers, burned by the recession and feeling the pinch of a slow recovery, have become addicted to discounts.
They are holding out for bigger sales before they buy — or simply not buying at all unless it is at a steep markdown.
The result has been one of the longest and most pronounced declines in retail prices since the 1930s, leaving stores struggling with flat or lower sales.

human: The South African police have arrested a man who confessed to having caused a fire that killed 77 people in a derelict building in downtown Johannesburg last year after a drug dispute led him to strangle a man and set the body alight, a police spokeswoman and a victims’ advocate said on Wednesday.
llm: The police in South Africa have arrested a man accused of setting fire to a building where 87 people died.
The man has been charged with 76 counts of murder and one count of arson.
The police said he had confessed to the crime.
He was caught trying to leave the country.

human: The military junta in the West African country of Niger claimed that it had disrupted an attempt by the ousted president, Mohamed Bazoum, to escape on Thursday from the presidential residence, where he has been detained since he was overthrown in a coup nearly three months ago.

human: The good news is that it’s been a great year for movies.
llm: The good news is that the Academy of Motion Pictures Arts and Sciences has expanded the number of nominees for best picture from five to 10.

human: Forget whipping out your phone to show off your family photos or tucking a loved one’s face into a locket around your neck.
What if you could wear your favorite memories on your back?
llm: Forget whipping out your phone to take a selfie with your family, or taking the kids to get their portrait taken at JC Penney.
If you really want to capture that special moment with your loved ones and hang it on the wall for everyone to see, then you need to hire professional photographer Sharon Tenenbaum.
Her style is chic and modern, but her photos are still very warm and intimate.
She has been featured in publications like Vogue, Elle Decor, Domino, Town & Country, New York Magazine, Apartment Therapy, and many more.

human: As the Israel-Hamas conflict intensifies, raising the prospect of a wider war, China has stepped up efforts to pitch itself as a neutral broker for Mideast peace.
llm: As the Israel-Hamas conflict escalates in Gaza, Chinese netizens are taking to social media to express their views on the matter.
Although China has historically played a small role in Middle East affairs, its increasing economic and diplomatic influence have prompted some to call for more engagement with the region.
As such, it’s not surprising that many netizens have turned their attention toward the recent events in Gaza.
Unfortunately, the results of this discourse have been less than encouraging.
According to research by Anti-Defamation League (ADL), antisemitic postings on Chinese social media have spiked dramatically in the wake of Israel’s offensive in Gaza.
The ADL study found over 20,000 postings on Chinese social media platforms, including We

human: The Connecticut River faces a crisis: An aggressive invasive plant that grows in thick underwater mats is spreading swiftly.
llm: The Connecticut River, which begins in New Hampshire and ends in Long Island Sound, is the longest river in New England.
The river has a long history of pollution, but efforts to clean it up are still ongoing.

In this video segment from EARTH: The Operators' Manual, learn how one state is attempting to reduce nitrogen levels that contribute to algae growth and hypoxia in the waters off the coast of Long Island.

human: A man was arrested early Tuesday after breaching the Colorado Supreme Court building, holding a guard at gunpoint and opening fire inside, the local authorities said.

llm: A man was shot by a Denver police officer inside the Colorado Supreme Court building early Friday morning.

human: Investigators looking into the cause of a deadly fire at a wedding hall in northern Iraq called on Sunday for the firing of a half-dozen provincial and local officials for their failure to enforce compliance with even minimal safety standards in the hall’s construction and operation.

human: “Kevin Hart & Chris Rock: Headliners Only,” a slick, self-mythologizing piece of Netflix content that follows the two comedians on the recent arena shows they teamed up on, is aimed at comedy fans — even if much of it will be familiar to them.

The new president doesn’t have any executive experience (he was a mayor in his home town but that was before he became famous).
And his party, Cambiemos, is made up of all sorts of people, many of them politicians who are just looking out for themselves.

human: When Scotty Scott was about 8 years old, his aunt Yvonne made him stem pounds and pounds of green beans for a big holiday dinner.

Young Scotty figured that if he intentionally left on some of the ends and kept most of the pods long and floppy — in other words, did a bad job — he’d never again be tasked with such an arduous responsibility.
But Aunt Yvonne caught on quickly.
“What are you doing, man?”
she asked when she saw his pile of odds and ends.
“No, no, no, no — get back in there!
You know how to snap beans.”
llm: When Scotty Scott, the owner of Scotty's Farm in Georgia, first started his business, he grew mostly produce.

human: Hoosen Coovadia, a pediatrician who used science to fight for racial justice in apartheid South Africa and later transformed the approach to H.I.V. treatment for pregnant women in Africa and beyond, died on Oct. 4 at his home in Durban.

Dr. Coovadia (pronounced CO-va-dee-a) was born in 1937 in Durban, where he grew up in a middle-class family with Indian roots that had been in South Africa for generations.

human: If you loathe cockroaches, you’re going to love the emerald jewel wasp.
llm: If you loathe cockroaches as much as I do, you'll be delighted to hear about a new parasitic wasp that's been found.
It literally eats the heart out of its host, leaving it with no choice but to die.
The newly discovered species is named Idris elba (no relation to the actor), and like other Idris wasps, it has an extremely bizarre life cycle.
Females lay eggs inside developing cockroach embryos, where they hatch into larvae and proceed to devour the roach from within.
But now we know that this particular species doesn't stop there: it goes on to feast on the roach's internal organs, including its heart, killing the poor bug in the process.

human: Children, according to the old disciplinarian maxim, should be seen and not heard.

human: The stretch of time that unfurls in the sublime Japanese drama “Monster” begins with a fire and ends during a monsoon.

human: Anthony Vidler, an architectural historian who, beginning in the 1960s, reshaped his field by setting aside dry chronologies of styles and movements for an interdisciplinary approach borrowing from psychoanalysis, French literary theory and cultural studies, died on Oct. 19 at his home in Manhattan.
He was 82.
llm: Anthony Vidler, an architectural historian and theorist whose scholarship helped transform his field into a more theoretical, less empirical discipline, died on Feb. 17 in New York City.
He was 82.
The cause was complications of Alzheimer’s disease, according to his wife, Teresa.
Vidler joined the faculty of the Cooper Union School of Architecture in Manhattan in 1965 and taught there until retiring in 2004 as Vincent Astor Professor of Architectural History.
In 1973 he founded and became editor-in-chief of the journal Assemblage, which is now published by MIT Press.
The journal has been instrumental in pushing architectural theory forward for decades, said David Ruy, director of KTH Stockholm’

human: Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who is running for president as an independent, announced on Tuesday that he had filed paperwork to create his own political party in six states — an effort to get his name on the ballot with fewer voter signatures than would be required for an unaffiliated candidate.
llm: Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. has tried getting his name on the ballots of several states for the presidential election this November.
He filed paperwork with New York’s Board of Elections, and is also trying to get on the ballot in California, Indiana, North Carolina, Oregon and Texas as well.
In order to do so, he would need to create his own party because he missed the deadline to enter the Democratic primaries.
However, there are doubts about whether or not he will be successful.

human: Wall Street strategists are issuing forecasts for the performance of the stock market in 2024.
llm: Wall Street strategists have a spotty record when it comes to predicting where stocks are heading over the next year or two.

human: Al-Shifa, Gaza’s main hospital complex, has been cut off from electricity for days.
Hospital officials warn that the lives of roughly three dozen premature babies are under threat now that the incubators needed to keep them alive are without power.
llm: Al-Shifa, Gaza’s main hospital, was the target of a massive bombing attack by Israel in 2014.
The attacks destroyed much of the facility and killed several medical staff.
Today Al-Shifa is still struggling to provide services to the people of Gaza.
In this briefing we will hear from Dr. Alaa Alwash, head of the ICU at Al-Shifa Hospital about the state of healthcare in Gaza today and what we can do to help.

human: They are some of the most determined voters in the world.
llm: They are some of the most passionate voters in America.
Yet for many Taiwanese-American citizens, casting their ballots means more than just showing up at the polls or mailing them in — it requires a 12,000 mile round trip.
That's because unlike other foreign nationals living in the United States, Taiwanese citizens cannot vote by absentee ballot.
They must travel back to Taiwan if they want to exercise their democratic right to vote.
In a presidential election year, that could mean missing out on a historic moment in U.S. history.
"I think it's kind of silly," said Chih-Wei Hsu, a New York University graduate student who was born and raised in Taiwan but is now a naturalized American citiz

human: The history of Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh was ended in the old manner of conflict resolution: siege, conquest, expulsion.
After a 10-month blockade, Azerbaijan launched an attack on Sept. 19, claiming the enclave in a day and causing nearly the entire ethnic Armenian population to flee.
Give war a chance, as the saying goes.
llm: The history of the world is defined by those who can do and not by those who say.
The future will be no different.

human: For many years, Rebecca Chamberlain designed clothes for famous brands, mostly to make ends meet.

llm: For many years, I've been an avid collector of vintage fashion and accessories.
In 2013, I decided to launch my own line of upcycled clothing and jewelry made from secondhand materials.

llm: Anemona Hartocollis, a reporter for the New York Times, wrote an article in which she examines how a course at Oberlin College about contemporary issues has become a flashpoint for campus politics.

human: Using only your smartphone you can study dance moves in Berlin, shout along with protests in Iran, watch opera in Finland or witness catastrophe in the Middle East, if not live then close to it.

In other words, it’s easier than it’s ever been to believe you’re everywhere when you’re actually nowhere, to feel as if you’re acting when you’re only reacting, to think you’re making connections when you’re totally alone.
llm: Using a new feature, you can search for videos with the same dance move as the one you just performed for the camera.
You find a video from five years ago — and your doppelgänger is dancing back at you, somewhere on the other side of the world.
She smiles, you smile.
The algorithm did its job.
In that moment, a bond forms between two strangers who have never met, but who share an experience through movement, music, and community.

human: It was Nov. 17, 2022, and Kenneth Smith was lying on a gurney inside Alabama’s execution chamber, his arms and legs strapped down as he waited to be put to death.

llm: It was Nov. 8, 2017, when the State of Alabama tried to execute Mr.
[Ronald Bert] Smith Jr. using its preferred method: lethal injection.

human: An article on Sunday about the rise of net migration to Britain since its exit from the European Union incorrectly described the role of the Conservative Party in the Brexit campaign.
It was the party’s Brexit-supporting lawmakers, including the current prime minister, who played on fears of a foreign influx, not the entire Conservative Party.
llm: An article on Wednesday about the sale of the New York Daily News to Tronc misstated the number of years since Mortimer B. Zuckerman bought the paper.

human: When Mayor Mike Duggan talks about his accomplishments in Detroit, the list is both impressive and sad.
He had the streetlights turned back on, and reopened closed parks.
In the decade since he took office, the city has demolished some 25,000 blighted homes whose rusty debris and incubation of crime drag down neighborhoods.
llm: When Mayor Mike Duggan first took office in Detroit in 2014, he announced that his administration would seek to reform the city's property tax system by switching from a state equalized value (SEV) based assessment methodology to one based on market value.
The change was intended to ensure that property owners were paying their fair share of taxes and to eliminate the unpopular annual inflationary increase in assessed values known as "taxable value."

human: Peter Coy: Paul, I think the economy is going to be a huge problem for President Biden in 2024.

llm: Peter Coy: Paul, I'm going to start with a big picture question.

human: Jasmine, one of two protagonists in Jean Kwok’s intriguing fourth novel, “The Leftover Woman,” reveals little to the reader at first.
Seeing her on the streets of Manhattan’s Chinatown, we quickly understand that she’s a woman with a complicated past.
But like the frumpy clothes she wears to disguise her appearance, her thoughts and words are meant to throw us off the track.

As Jasmine trudges from one job interview to the next, searching for work that will help pay off the “snakeheads” who helped her emigrate from China, she remains as invisible to readers as she is to her pursuers.
llm: Jasmine, one of the characters in Mr. Nguyen’s new novel, is a young Vietnamese refugee who has spent her life trying to make sense of her place in the world.
She is an immigrant, a woman and a lesbian, and she lives with the knowledge that her parents have died because they were not accepted by either country — America or Vietnam.
The loss of her parents and her sexual orientation are two parts of Jasmine’s identity that she feels unable to share with anyone.
So when she meets a man named Ivan, a recent widower, at a party hosted by her sister, Jasmine decides to pass herself off as straight, and to tell him only half-truths about herself.
“I wanted to be with this person,” she says.
“This

human: Kali Uchis basks in pleasure on her fourth studio album, “Orquídeas.”
Make that pleasures: carnal, material, romantic, sonic, competitive and, if necessary, vengeful, all with a girlish nonchalance.
The album begins with loops of laughter and ethereal oohs and ahs; it ends with Uchis thanking listeners with a “mwah” kiss.
It’s an album of breezy confidence and sly ingenuity, easily moving among futuristic electronics, 1990s nostalgia and Latin roots.
llm: Kali Uchis basks in the glow of her success and looks forward to even brighter days ahead on “Orquídea,” a new song from the singer’s forthcoming debut album Isolation.

human: A judge decided on Thursday that rap lyrics by the Atlanta artist Young Thug and his collaborators will be allowed as evidence in the racketeering trial of YSL, a chart-topping hip-hop label and collective that prosecutors say is also a criminal street gang responsible for violent crimes.
llm: A judge decided Tuesday that lyrics from Young Thug’s 2017 mixtape “Beautiful Thugger Girls” can be used as evidence against the rapper.
He is on trial for a number of federal charges, including RICO conspiracy and possession of firearms and ammunition.
The prosecution claims that some of his lyrics point to him being involved in a gang.

human: I’m near-term slightly more optimistic but long-term pessimistic about the ability of the United States to deal with its budget problems.

The article reported that Israel had carried out a strike on Al-Wafa hospital in Gaza City and claimed that Hamas fighters were firing from the building.
