human: The House of Representatives has been enmeshed in chaos since the Republican speaker Kevin McCarthy was voted out on Oct. 3 by members of his own conference.
Steve Scalise then ran for the speakership but withdrew his candidacy, and multiple votes failed for Jim Jordan, the next candidate, as well.
llm: The House of Representatives has been in session for nearly three weeks, and so far it's done almost nothing.

No legislation has passed either chamber of Congress, the president hasn't signed a single bill into law, and to the extent that anything has happened at all, it's mostly involved Republicans attacking one another.

The infighting has gotten so bad that it seems increasingly likely that Congress will have to pass yet another continuing resolution to fund the government for a few more months—kicking the can down the road, rather than doing its job and passing an actual budget.

human: President Biden expressed hope that the four-day truce between Israel and Hamas could open the door to a longer cease-fire.
llm: President Biden expressed relief today that the first group of hostages had been released, but he cautioned that “this is only a start.”
He also stated his intention to continue working with Israel in order to secure the release of the remaining captives.

human: Last fall, as The Learning Network celebrated 25 years of helping people teach and learn with the news, it seemed to us that education issues were making more headlines than ever.
llm: Last fall, as part of our ongoing series about the future of high school, we invited students to submit their best ideas for what the classroom should look like in 2023.
We asked them to design an infographic or multimedia presentation that illustrated how they would rethink the high-school experience and prepare students for life after graduation.

human: Barring a political miracle or an act of God, it is overwhelmingly likely that Donald Trump will again be the Republican Party’s nominee for president.
Assuming the Democratic nominee in the fall is Joe Biden, polls show Trump with a better-than-even chance of returning to the White House next year.
llm: Barring a political earthquake, Donald Trump will be the Republican nominee.
That is bad news for America and the world, but it need not be disastrous.
In the end, he will lose — badly and decisively.

If there are any silver linings in this ugly cloud, they are that Trump will not win; that Hillary Clinton will be elected as our first woman president; and that she will have a strong Democratic majority in Congress to work with.

human: The soaring number of people crossing into the United States from Mexico has been a political vulnerability for President Biden for the past three years, chipping away at his approval rating and opening him up to political attacks.
llm: The soaring number of children and families being apprehended at the U.S.-Mexico border has put pressure on an already overburdened system.

But a 2014 law intended to keep migrant kids out of dangerous detention facilities has become part of the problem, experts say — and it could also threaten one of former Vice President Joe Biden's signature policy achievements.

human: Born in Mulhouse, France, in 1907, Jean Schlumberger was constantly sketching as a child.
He dreamed of becoming an artist one day, but his parents, who hoped he’d take over the family textile business, sent him to Berlin to practice banking instead.

In his early 20s, he defiantly moved to Paris and opened a jewelry workshop on Rue La Boétie, where he handcrafted delicate floral brooches out of Meissen porcelain, antique cameos and decorative Victorian objects he found at the Marché aux Puces.
His fantastical creations soon captured the attention of the fashion world.
After spotting Princess Marina of Greece and Denmark in a pair of his earrings in 1937, the Italian couturier Elsa Schiaparelli commissioned him to design buttons shaped like fruits and insects.
llm: Born in Mulhouse, France, designer Marie-Lou Desage has lived and worked in Brussels since 2015.

She began her career working for a few years as an independent jewelry designer, but she soon realized that she would have more control over the design process if she learned to fabricate her own pieces.
In order to do so, she enrolled in La Cambre’s jewelry program.
“I wanted to be able to see my ideas come to life without having to rely on someone else,” she says.
“It was a challenge to go back to school at age 34, but it’s been one of the best decisions I ever made.”

human: Hundreds of people gathered in Columbus Circle in Manhattan on Thursday evening, the first night of Hanukkah, to light candles for the holiday and to call for a cease-fire in Gaza.
llm: Hundreds of people gathered at Congregation Shearith Israel on the Upper West Side to celebrate Hanukkah.

llm: Jerome H. Powell, chairman of the Federal Reserve, testified on Wednesday before a House committee.

human: Caboodle was a sweet but average cat.
Not especially beautiful, intelligent, affectionate or agile, she lived a long, happy, uneventful life.
When she died in September 1999, my husband and I buried her under a rose bush in our backyard.
That October, the month of my 50th birthday and long after the last rose had faded, a single bloom emerged.
For about 10 years after Caboodle’s death, a single rose would bloom in mid-October.
Pretty extraordinary, for an average cat.
— Judith Karp
llm: Caboodle was a wonderful word.
It made me think of a small dog named Buddy that I had as a child and it reminded me of my father who used to say things like “cahoots” and “dilly dally.”
He also said “I don’t know for the life of me why you don’t just get out of bed when your alarm goes off in the morning,” but that’s another story.

human: An article on Monday about the Ukrainian Orthodox Church’s decision to move Christmas to Dec. 25 referred incorrectly to the Eastern Orthodox Church in Finland.

llm: An article on Tuesday about the first day of legal recreational marijuana sales in Colorado misstated the surname of a woman who was the first to buy marijuana at one dispensary.

human: The demise of Mint, the beloved budgeting app, has caused its millions of users to consider alternatives.

llm: The demise of Mint was a shock to many users because it was one of the first financial aggregation apps on the market and had earned an excellent reputation for accuracy.

human: Because of severe cold weather, schools across a wide swath of the South — from Texas and Tennessee to Alabama and Arkansas — were closed on Tuesday, affecting about one million children in a region known for its mild winters.

human: The Supreme Court said on Monday that it would not hear a First Amendment challenge to a Washington State law banning professional counseling services intended to change a minor’s gender identity or sexual orientation.

human: Soft lights in warm colors or bright LEDs?

human: When King Charles III travels to Kenya this week, it will be a journey steeped in family memory for Britain’s new monarch:

llm: When King Charles III of England and Queen Camilla arrive in Nairobi this week for a state visit to Kenya, they will be walking into a historical minefield.

human: In her short 17 years on earth, Amira Ismail had never been called a baby killer.
llm: In her short story, "A Dispatch From the Muslim Girl Scouts of Astoria," Ms. Rizvi introduces us to a diverse group of girls who meet once a week in an Islamic center for their Girl Scout troop meeting.
The story opens with a group of girls having a heated discussion about whether or not they should wear hijabs (headscarves).
When I read this, I was immediately transported back to my own childhood wherein my friends
and I would often have similar debates over how we should dress.

human: After her husband died, a retired librarian decided to leave their townhouse and strike out on her own in a one-bedroom apartment nearby.

llm: After her husband died, Carolyn Bates wanted to move out of their apartment in the West Village.

human: In Estonia, the smoke sauna is an 800-year-old tradition carried out with regularity — to this day — by the Voro community in the southeastern part of the country.
llm: In Estonia, the sauna is a place for women to be together.

human: The corruption trial of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel resumed on Monday, bringing back into focus the legal and political challenges he faces even as he presides over the Israeli military’s war against Hamas in Gaza.
llm: The corruption trial of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu resumed on Wednesday after a seven-month pause during which Israel held two elections and failed to form a government.
It was the first session since Attorney General Avichai Mandelblit announced in November that he intended to indict Mr. Netanyahu on charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust, pending a hearing.
The attorney general also said he would charge Mr. Netanyahu with fraud and breach of trust in two other cases.
If the hearings go ahead as planned, Mr. Netanyahu will be the first sitting prime minister to face criminal charges.
He has denied wrongdoing.
The hearings are expected to take place over several days starting next week.

human: The Commission on Presidential Debates on Monday announced the dates and locations of three presidential debates to be held during the general election campaign next year, as well as one vice-presidential debate.
llm: The Commission on Presidential Debates announced the dates and locations for the three presidential debates, as well as one vice-presidential debate, that will take place this fall.

The first debate will be held on September 29 at the University of Notre Dame in Indiana; the second will take place on October 7 at Washington University in St. Louis, Missouri; and the third will happen on October 15 at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City.
The lone vice-presidential debate will occur on October 7 at Centre College in Danville, Kentucky.

human: In recent months, abortion opponents in Texas have succeeded in passing a growing number of local ordinances to prevent people from helping women travel to have abortions in nearby states that still allow the procedure.
llm: In recent months, anti-abortion groups have been pushing similar ordinances in cities around the country.
The ordinances are part of a wave of hundreds of new state laws restricting abortion that have passed since Republicans took full control of state legislatures across the South and Midwest in 2010.
But the local measures may be even more effective than the state ones at shutting down clinics, since they apply to all women in the community, not just those living in the immediate state.

human: Fifty years ago last month, Erica Jong published a debut novel that went on to sell more than 20 million copies.
“Fear of Flying,” a book so sexually frank that you may have found it hidden in your mother’s underwear drawer, broke new ground in the explicitness of writing by and for women.
Jong’s heroine, Isadora Wing, was a live wire.
She was also a dead end, certainly for Jong, and maybe for feminism, too.
llm: Fifty years ago, the publication of “Fear of Flying” caused a literary sensation and helped to launch the sexual revolution.
The author Erica Jong said she wrote the novel because she couldn’t find one that spoke honestly about female desire.
Her heroine was Isadora Wing, a poet who had a lust for life and sex (and her analyst).
Ms. Jong’s frankness made her an overnight feminist celebrity.
But today, many women say they can’t relate to her dream of freedom through sex.
For them, fear of harassment has replaced the fear of flying.

human: Amid terrible events abroad and the takeover of the Republican Party by agents of chaos, the U.S. economy has been delivering lots of good news.
All indications are that real G.D.P. is still growing fast; we’re adding jobs at an extraordinary pace, even as inflation continues to fall.
llm: Amid terrible events like those in Haiti, people often ask why God would let such a thing happen.
I don't know what you believe about that, and I certainly won't try to tell you what to think.
But for me, it helps to remember that we are part of an ongoing creation story, and it is up to us to help write its ending.
It also helps to focus on the good news coming out of Haiti, like this story about a 10-year-old boy who was rescued after eight days under the rubble.
The power of prayer has helped him survive, he said; now it's up to us to keep praying—and working.

human: At the risk of evoking unpleasant memories of high-school English, can we please discuss the word allegory?
It refers to a story or a painting that comes with a moral or a lesson, perhaps a social or political one.

And, in an era when figurative art has returned to prominence, the New York galleries are filled with a profusion of both allegorical paintings and their very opposite — which is to say, paintings that reject third-person narration in favor of first-person self-exposure.
I caught two shows last week — Dana Schutz’s and Tracey Emin’s — that represent the two extremes.
llm: At the risk of being a little too "meta," it's worth noting that one of the most interesting things about this year's Whitney Biennial is the way the show's curators have gone about their job, and how they talk about what they do.

human: Humans are a remarkably ambitious species.
We came to the edge of lands we could safely chart and built ships that would carry us to the unknown.
When travel by water and land no longer suited us, we took to the skies.
After journeying among the clouds could not sate our spirit, we turned our hearts to the stars.
llm: Humans are a species that is driven by self-interest and selfishness, but this does not mean that we cannot make choices to help others or do things for the greater good.
This also does not mean that humans should be completely selfless, as this would be impossible.

human: Nasreen Parveen decided to run for her life at the same moment she decided not to end it.

human: I’ve written several times about the case for disqualifying Donald Trump via the 14th Amendment, arguing that it fails tests of political prudence and constitutional plausibility alike.

The performance isn't there.
The following is a list of some common mistakes I've seen managers make when they get caught up with the hype.

One of its chapters is dedicated to the prospects and risks of a frozen conflict scenario in Donbas, which is quite timely given that this topic has recently become a subject of heated debate among Ukrainian politicians, experts and society at large.

human: In our age of scorched-earth ground offensives and bombed-out hospitals, the prospect of punishing atrocities perpetrated by governments seems particularly distant.

llm: In our age of international war crimes tribunals, it's easy to forget that they are a relatively new phenomenon.

human: There is one particular pulsar, a type of quick-spinning dead star, that holds the current record for the fastest rotation of any celestial body in the known universe — 716 times per second.

By contrast, the blade of a Vitamix can turn around 333 times every second, but a blender is small enough to sit on a countertop, and a pulsar is a city-size ball of neutrons that floats in space and contains the mass of half a million Earths.
llm: There is one thing we know for sure about the universe.
It's weird.
Very, very weird.
The rules that govern the world around us are completely alien on a cosmic scale.
In this talk I will show you how the universe works, and why it seems so bizarre to our puny human minds.
From dark matter to black holes, quantum mechanics to general relativity, I will tell you what we know, what we think we know, and what we still have no idea about.

human: New Zealand’s new right-wing government has said it will repeal a law that would have gradually banned all cigarette sales in the country over the course of several decades.
llm: New Zealand’s new government has said it will scrap a proposed ban on smoking in cars carrying children.
The bill was introduced by the former Labour-led government, but was not passed before its term ended with September’s election.
Prime Minister John Key said the new National Party-led coalition would repeal the legislation.
Mr Key said he did not agree with smoking in cars, but said banning it was not the role of government.
“I don’t believe the state should be telling people how to bring up their children,” he told reporters.

human: For Jeanette Winterson, ghost stories are not old-fashioned or anachronistic in the modern world, but both cutting-edge and primal.

Religion, and specifically faith in an afterlife, “can be considered as humankind’s first disruptive start-up,” she writes.
“What’s being disrupted is death.”
llm: For Jeanette Winterson, the ghosts that haunt us are often metaphorical.
She explains how she came to explore literal ghosts in her latest novel, “The Daylight Gate.”...

human: On a Cape Cod beach last January, I braced for my daily cold water plunge.
“Can I join you?” asked a stranger.
I hesitated.
But her red hair and wide smile reminded me of my younger self.
“Sure,” I said.
Ashley is 29.
For seven minutes in frigid water, we shared our stories: her chronic illness and career change; my failed marriage and struggles raising a child with cancer.
Every day since our first encounter, we’ve met to immerse ourselves in the ocean.
We bond in a daily baptism.
I now can’t imagine braving water, or life, without her.
— Amy McHugh
llm: On a Cape Cod beach, I spotted a man in the distance.
He was alone and reading a book.
I went over to introduce myself and we talked all afternoon.
We fell madly in love, moved in together, got engaged, and had a daughter.
One day he said, “I think it’s time you met my wife.”

human: What makes a house a home?
And what constitutes an American home?
Planted dead center on the stage in “This House Is Not a Home,” a slippery, ever-shifting work by Nile Harris, is a house — a bounce house.
But it’s more than an inflatable plaything.
llm: What makes a house feel like home?
For some people, it’s a specific item.
A favorite chair.
The perfect painting on the wall.
A pair of fuzzy slippers by the front door.
Others might say that the feeling of home comes from being with family or friends.
But for others still, it’s something more elusive and abstract.
Something that’s harder to put your finger on.
And, as the characters in “In a Land of Primary Colors,” this week’s episode of This American Life, find out, it can be easy to confuse the two.

human: Israel’s Supreme Court narrowly struck down a law proposed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu that was meant to limit the court’s own powers.

llm: Israel’s Supreme Court rejected an attempt by the country’s legislature to limit its power, including on matters of religion and state.
The court struck down a law passed last year that would have allowed the Knesset to override decisions by the court with a simple majority vote.
“The Basic Law is intended to harm the status and standing of this court,” Justice Hanan Melcer wrote in the ruling.
“It is meant to ‘cut off the branch’ on which it sits.”
He said the court would not be able to fulfill its role as protector of civil rights if it were subjected to such political control.
The decision was hailed by religious pluralism advocates, who had feared the legislation could be used to block their efforts to gain equal recognition under Israeli law.

human: The first large offshore wind farm in New England has started producing electricity, a milestone for an industry that has struggled to get off the ground over the past year.
llm: The first large-scale offshore wind farm in the U.S. started delivering power to Massachusetts on Monday, according to its developers.
The five-turbine project off Block Island, R.I., is generating electricity for Rhode Island and can send up to 154 megawatts of power to New England through a submarine cable.
That's enough to supply about 30,000 homes.
Deepwater Wind, which developed the $290 million facility, says it will help reduce carbon emissions by more than 40,000 tons per year — equivalent to taking nearly 10,000 cars off the road.

human: Michael Bennett, the former N.F.L. player, started designing furniture as a way to reconsider architecture and the spaces that Black people occupy.

Inspired by his upbringing in Louisiana and Texas, as well as by trips to Senegal, where his ancestors are from, Bennett began to think about the objects that “bring Black people together in public spaces” as a way to deepen his longtime activism work focused on racial justice.
After retiring from football in 2020, he founded the design practice Studio Kër.

Bennett’s exploration of the Black home led him to create an 11-piece collection of sculptural furniture that he’s debuting this month in “We Gotta Get Back to the Crib,” his inaugural exhibition for the Los Angeles art gallery Marta, presented at Theaster Gates’s Rebuild Foundation in Chicago.
(In the spring, the show will travel to Houston.)

The collection reimagines objects of communal gatherings; pieces include the Gumbo lounge chair, a lush take on the stackable monobloc chair, and the Pew couch, a nod to the church bench, made of leather and ekki wood.
“For me, the show is about celebrating Black ingenuity and connecting back to that African diasporic design language,” says Bennett.
“We Gotta Get Back to the Crib” is on view from Jan. 12 through Feb. 10, marta.la.
llm: Michael Bennett, the Seahawks defensive end and a former member of the Super Bowl–winning New England Patriots, has just launched his own line of furniture.

human: In recent years, much of my life as a consumer has shifted to what I like to call background spending.

llm: In recent years, a growing number of companies have adopted the subscription business model.
In this model, consumers pay for products or services on an ongoing basis rather than making one-time purchases.
This approach has proven to be popular with both consumers and entrepreneurs alike.
On the consumer side, there is often convenience in being able to receive regular shipments of items like razors, makeup, clothing, or pet food.
For entrepreneurs, it can help create predictable revenue streams and improve forecasting capabilities.

human: On Tuesday, Cillian Murphy was at his parents’ home in Cork, Ireland, drinking a cup of tea when his phone started buzzing.

he told Vulture over the phone on Thursday.

human: Depending on where you fall on the scale from “extremely superstitious” to “not at all,” Friday may be the most frightful day of your year.
llm: Depending on where you are in the world, today may be your lucky day or it may not be so lucky.
In the Western world, many people regard Friday the 13th as an unlucky day.

This fear of the date has even been given a special name: friggatriskaidekaphobia (Frigga being the name of the Norse goddess for whom “Friday” is named and triskaidekaphobia meaning fear of the number thirteen).
The phobia is also sometimes called paraskevidekatriaphobia, from the Greek Paraskeví (Παρασκευή), meaning Friday.

human: On the day before my sister Julie died, I lay down on her bed and held her gingerly in my arms, afraid that any pressure would hurt her.
She had lost so much weight that she looked like a stick figure I might have drawn when we were kids.
As her body had wasted, her tumors had grown — now several of them bigger than baseballs.
Her abdomen looked like the lunar landscape, with protrusions everywhere, the sources of her pain plainly visible.
llm: On the day before she died, my sister told me that she had promised herself she would not die alone.
When she was admitted to the hospital a week earlier, we were sure it was for a few days of antibiotics and fluids and then she'd be back home again.
We thought we still had time.
But now, in her private room on the palliative care floor, there were no more treatments or procedures available.
The only thing left to do was wait.
And so she asked if I would stay with her until the end.

human: Millions of people play Wordle every day, and share, discuss and debate how they tried to win.

human: As it has done every year for the past seven straight decades, the Winter Show, the venerable arts and antiquities fair, which benefits the East Side House Settlement in the Bronx, has brought together an incredible range of objects, most of those years under the capacious roof of the Park Avenue Armory.
A concert piano with a curved keyboard, designed by the architect Rafael Viñoly and built by Chris Maene.
(Bernard Goldberg Fine Arts, LLC, C1).
A couple of Bonnards for the foyer (Jill Newhouse Gallery, A7).
A contemporary painter responding to Italian old masters (Robert Simon Fine Art, C10).
A red, white and blue Centennial-year bird cage in the shape of the U.S. Capitol (Focus: Americana, curated by Alexandra Kirtley of the Philadelphia Museum of Art).
What about a butter dish shaped like a bundle of asparagus (Michele Beiny, D1)?
Or first editions of Edmund Spenser’s “The Faerie Queene” and “Leaves of Grass” (Peter Harrington, C12)?
llm: As it has for 64 years, the Winter Antiques Show is offering museum-quality furniture, silver and art from around the world.

But this year’s fair also offers some truly bizarre items: a bird cage shaped like the United States Capitol building; a pair of candlesticks in the shape of Napoleon Bonaparte’s legs; a “painted satinwood and mahogany mechanical lion,” which, when wound up, can roar and move its head and tail.

human: The complex dance of doubt and religious faith is frequently cast in terms of a quest.

One might be “on a faith journey,” or be “a lost soul,” or be “searching” for meaning and the divine — all images derived from the idea of starting at one place, keeping your eyes open, and ending up, ultimately, in some final destination.
Small wonder that many human cultures imagine a wander in the wilderness, literal or metaphorical, as pivotal to one’s initiation into maturity.
Some fresh wisdom and revelation comes from walking around in circles for a while.
llm: The complex dance of humanity and nature, of humankind and its environment, is an inescapable part of life.
The relationship between man and his surroundings has been explored by artists throughout history.
In the 19th century, Romanticists such as Caspar David Friedrich and John Constable saw the natural world as a place to connect with God.
By the 20th century, modernist painters such as Georgia O’Keeffe and Piet Mondrian reduced their subjects to basic forms, creating artworks that expressed spiritual qualities through abstraction.

human: Three years after Bayer agreed to pay $10 billion to settle claims that its weedkiller, Roundup, caused cancer, juries continue to award plaintiffs in additional cases billions of dollars in damages, even as the German drug and chemicals giant insists it will continue its fight in court.

human: When the Spanish singer María José Llergo talks about flamenco, it often sounds as though she is describing something springing from beneath her feet.

llm: When the Spanish singer María José Llergo sings “I Am a Woman,” her voice is an instrument of passionate self-possession and empowerment.
She leans into the song, which is written in Andalusian Arabic dialect, with defiance and pride.
The song was recorded by Ms. Llergo for the 2018 documentary film “Yo, la peor de todas” (“Me, the Worst of All”), about the life of the 17th-century Mexican nun and poet Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz.
It is one of many songs that she has collected, preserved or created as part of her mission to amplify the voices of women who have been historically ignored.

human: Modestly scaled and tonally perfect, “Fallen Leaves” opens in a fluorescent hell-on-earth and ends with a vision of something like paradise.
In between, there are lonely nights, fleeting joys, ordinary degradations, laborious work, karaoke reveries, many cigarettes and more drinks.
A lot of the drinks are downed hurriedly and often furtively by a man, while elsewhere a woman listens to sad songs.
Outwardly, these two are leading lives of quiet desperation, though because this is an Aki Kaurismaki movie, their despair comes with great comic timing.
llm: Modestly scaled and smartly written, “Fallen Leaves” is a comedy-drama that shows how the human spirit can rise above adversity — in this case, the aftermath of a natural disaster.
The film offers its creators a stepping stone to larger things.

human: When people ask me what my favorite horror movie is, John Carpenter’s groundbreaking shocker comes out on top.
Jamie Lee Curtis plays a high schooler who gets stalked on Halloween night by an escaped lunatic named Michael Myers.
Today it sounds like any old horror movie.

But Carpenter was prophetic with narrative choices that horror now takes for granted: a masked killing-machine villain, a strong-willed final girl next door, creatively depicted deaths, touches of dark comedy.
(And a score that sounds like a chase.)
Together they make “Halloween” my top Halloween treat.
llm: When people ask me what my favorite horror movie is, I always tell them “The Shining.”
And I’m not alone: the 1980 film adaptation of Stephen King’s novel frequently makes lists of the best horror films ever made.
The Stanley Kubrick-directed picture stars Jack Nicholson and Shelley Duvall as a couple who take their son on a winter caretaker job at an isolated hotel that goes horribly wrong.
It was recently added to Netflix in the UK, so you can stream it there now.
But for us Yanks, it’ll have to wait until Halloween night — which is when you should really watch this one anyway.

human: In 1988, Oprah Winfrey tugged a red wagon filled with fat across the stage of her television show to represent the 67 pounds she said she had lost on a liquid diet.

human: Poetry makes nothing happen, W.H. Auden said in 1939, when words must have seemed especially impotent; but cinema is another matter.

For several decades after the end of the Second World War, what’s come to be seen as its central catastrophe — the near-total destruction of the European Jews — was consigned to the status of a footnote.
The neglect was rooted in guilt: Many nations eagerly collaborated in the killing, while others did nothing to prevent it.
Consumed by their own suffering, most people simply didn’t want to know, and a conspiracy of silence was established.
llm: Poetry makes nothing happen, Auden said.
But that was before the Internet.
Nowadays, poetry is everywhere — on T-shirts and greeting cards, Facebook pages and blogs, and even in the news sometimes.
A poem by Somali poet Warsan Shire shows up at the end of Beyonce's visual album Lemonade; Lin Manuel Miranda incorporated passages from Walt Whitman into his Broadway musical Hamilton.
And then there are the Poetweet poets like Patricia Lockwood who tweet their poems to followers all over the world.

human: Last year was the warmest in recorded history.

Some offered earworm-y slogans and haunting visuals.
Whatever their approach — bright, witty, somber, blunt, even sexy — they sought an image, a phrase, that could change enough minds to literally save the world.
llm: Last year was the hottest on record.
This year is set to be hotter still, with May marking the 351st consecutive month that global temperatures have been above average.
It’s not looking good for the future of the planet—and the posters that were produced in the early days of the environmental movement in the 1960s and ’70s are a stark reminder of this fact.

human: For my entire professional life, I have started nearly every weekday morning with an extremely important productivity ritual: I make a coffee, I sit down at my computer, and I mess around on the internet for an hour or so.

llm: For my entire life, I've lived in a world where the internet was a place for me to be myself.
The internet was a place for all the weird kids who didn't have any friends and wanted to connect with other weird kids like them.
The internet was the only place you could find people who understood what it felt like to be bullied or harassed at school every day.
When I was 13 years old, the internet was a sanctuary.
It was a safe haven from everything bad in the real world.
It was a place where I could talk to people who had similar interests as me.

human: For over a year, The New York Times has been asking musicians, writers and scholars to share the music they’d play for a friend to get them into jazz.

llm: For over a decade, I've been working on the Thelonious Monk biography that will be published by Simon & Schuster in 2017.
During this time, I have often been asked, "What do you think of John Coltrane?"
My answer is always the same: "Monk."
When it comes to jazz, there is no more important musician than Monk.
He did not just influence other musicians; he transformed how we hear jazz and, as a result, how we hear music.

human: In the months following Suleika Jaouad’s second bone marrow transplant, her TikTok algorithm started serving her videos of bearded dragons shedding their skin.

llm: In the months that followed, she began to write again.

She wrote for herself, and for those who would never have their stories told otherwise: the women of the Holocaust, the wives and mothers who were sent to concentration camps with their children; the victims of the siege of Leningrad, where more than one million civilians died of starvation during World War II.
Their experiences became the basis for her first novel, The Women in the Castle (2017).
It was named an Amazon Best Book of April 2017, received the Medici Book Club Prize, and is being translated into 15 languages.

human: For more than a quarter century, the fortunes of the United States and China were fused in a uniquely monumental joint venture.
llm: For more than 30 years, a joint venture between General Motors (GM) and Toyota produced cars in Fremont, California.
The New United Motor Manufacturing Inc., or NUMMI for short, was at one time the most successful auto plant in North America, with high productivity and quality.
In 1984, GM and Toyota agreed to end their partnership, but due to contractual obligations they continued to produce cars together until March 2010 when the last Corolla rolled off the assembly line.
This case tells the story of how GM and Toyota came to collaborate, how the partnership was organized, and why it ultimately failed.
It focuses on the challenges that arose from the two companies' different cultures

human: Until 2011, conscription was mandatory for German men, with the option to refuse armed service and do civil service at home or abroad instead.
In 2009 at age 19, I chose to go abroad as part of a development aid program, hoping that I would have the opportunity to contribute meaningfully to a community.
I went to Senegal for a one-year civil service assignment for a German nongovernmental organization that I picked from a list of options provided by a ministry’s website.
llm: Until 2011, conscription was mandatory in Switzerland, which maintains a military force of about 350,000 men and women.
Now, citizens are allowed to choose between compulsory service and an alternative program called Zivildienst (Civilian Service).

The Swiss government has also begun accepting some asylum seekers into the army, but this is limited by the country's restrictive policy on immigration: foreigners must be born in Switzerland and have resided there for at least ten years before they can apply for citizenship.
This means that even if an immigrant serves in the army, he or she may not be eligible for permanent residency in the country.

human: Five years ago, what would become the deadliest wildfire in California history erupted in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.

More than 3,000 families lost their homes.
Today, about half of those families have returned to Paradise.

human: Philip Glass wanted to become a better pianist.
llm: Philip Glass wanted to be a novelist.
He studied at the University of Chicago, The Juilliard School and in Aspen with Darius Milhaud.
Finding himself unable to compose music, he drove a New York City cab and worked as a plumber and a furniture mover.
Then, taking a summer course in Europe, he encountered sitar virtuoso Ravi Shankar.
He wrote a piece for him, met violinist Yehudi Menuhin and returned home to become a composer.
Now 76, he is one of America's most influential composers.
His opera Satyagraha played in Los Angeles this spring.
Next month his memoir Words Without Music will be published by Liveright.

human: Hollywood horror often attempts to work out collective anxiety about the suburbs, that place full of pleasant-looking houses creaking with ghosts and terrors.
Suburban life is, admittedly, fundamentally strange, with neighborhoods full of atomized worlds and natural features turned into individual, highly-controlled assets.
A forest becomes manicured bushes.
A lake becomes a pool.
llm: Hollywood horror often seems to be a genre without a country.
The movies are too often either dull or dumb, and the rare films that are actually good tend to come from outside the studio system.

But Hollywood is also where all the money is; so it’s no surprise that “Night Swim” has landed at Amazon Studios, with a budget that allows for some nifty special effects, excellent cinematography by Todd Banhazi, and an eclectic cast.
And yet, despite its polish, it’s not a Hollywood movie — it doesn’t have any of those blockbuster aspirations.
This is a film about one thing only: A woman who wants to swim in the ocean at night.
That’s it.
And she does

human: Q: We live on the first and second floors of a brownstone in East Harlem, and we love the backyard.
Two buildings over, a neighbor in the second-floor apartment has put a litter box on the fire escape outside their window for community cats to shelter.
The neighbor also puts out food for them.
In the morning, there are usually half a dozen adult cats lingering around the box and the stairs.
Inevitably, they end up roaming in our backyard, peeing, pooping and fighting.
The odor in the summer is terrible.
We’ve had two female cats give birth in our backyard this year alone.
The kittens are cute, their cries not so much.
What can we do?
llm: Q: We live in a rural neighborhood.
A woman across the street has been feeding stray cats for about two years now.
She also leaves food out for them to eat at will, which attracts raccoons and other wildlife.
As you might guess, this is not good for our property values.
We have complained to her, but she doesn't care what we think.
We've called animal control, but they say there is nothing they can do.
I'm afraid that if we complain too much, our neighbors are going to turn against us.
What else can we do?
—C.S., via email

human: Long before he was switch-hitting for the New York Yankees, a young Mickey Mantle was taking swings against his right-handed father and his left-handed grandfather in front of a shed next to his family’s humble 670-square-foot house in tiny Commerce, Okla.

llm: Long before he was the Mick, Mickey Mantle was just a kid from Commerce, Oklahoma, where his family home is now for sale for the first time in 90 years.

human: In charting the flight of the battery-powered CX300 aircraft recently, The New York Times was back where it has spent a lot of time over the last 120 years: in the clouds.
llm: In charting the course of aviation history, we’ve tended to fixate on the milestones that made headlines—the first solo flight across the Atlantic; Lindbergh’s flight from New York to Paris; the inauguration of passenger service by Pan Am and other airlines.

But there was another kind of progress as well, one that is less celebrated but arguably just as significant: the development of a new way of thinking about the world, of how to get around in it, of how far away places related to each other.

human: Have you ever spent quality time with a chicken?

They’re honestly not very bright.
Yet they’re like living cartoons, weird and funny to watch, with spindly little legs holding up plump little bodies.
They cluck disapprovingly when you take their eggs, and they’ll eat anything you dump in their yard (including, uh, chicken).
llm: Have you ever wondered how chickens got their freedom?
Or maybe, have you ever imagined that they could live a better life than just being eaten?

human: Violence in the West Bank, where millions of Palestinians live under Israeli military occupation, continues to simmer amid the war in Gaza.

human: After years of rising overdoses and an exodus of business from central Portland, Gov. Tina Kotek of Oregon said on Monday that state and city officials are proposing to roll back a portion of the nation’s most wide-ranging drug decriminalization law in a bid to revive the troubled city.

human: The moon stands alone.
It is unique in the known cosmos: a solitary rock one-fourth the width of its host planet, the only place life has ever been found.
And the moon is alone: It is a desolate, sunbaked and crater-pocked wasteland that harbors little except what we bring to it, either with our minds or with our spaceships.
But that is about to change.
llm: The moon stands in the sky, a rocky sphere orbiting Earth and reflecting the light of the sun.
For thousands of years it has been a familiar sight, a beacon for travellers and sailors, an inspiration for poets, artists and romantics, and a symbol of love and beauty.
But now, as humankind is about to return to its surface, the moon's familiarity is giving way to scientific discovery that will transform our understanding of our nearest celestial neighbour.

llm: Three of the four reports were released on Friday, with one remaining to be released at a later date.

human: A change taking place right now has the potential to do more good within U.S. prisons than any policy in a generation — good that will extend far beyond the realm of criminal justice.

The grants are small, but they are critical to rebuilding one of the most important tools we have to reduce crime and mitigate the harms of mass incarceration: college education.
llm: A change taking place behind bars is not just about faith, but also about the power of community.

human: The agony came in waves as the wounded Ukrainian soldier in the back of the ambulance slipped in and out of consciousness.

human: As dinner tables and snack menus feature far more chicken and cheese, farms are expanding where water is scarce.
llm: As dinner tables and supermarket shelves are stocked with more foods from plants, it’s important to consider how our choices affect the water supply.
A new study published in Environmental Research Letters shows that a typical vegetarian diet requires 320 gallons of groundwater per day, while a meat-rich diet needs just 170 gallons.
The reason is simple: it takes a lot of water to grow crops, especially ones high in protein like nuts and legumes.

human: Guy Stern, who fled rising antisemitism in Nazi Germany at 15 for a new life in the United States but returned to Europe during World War II as a member of a military intelligence program that trained him to interrogate prisoners of war, died on Dec. 7 in West Bloomfield, Mich.

llm: Guy Stern, who was forced to flee his native Germany in the late 1930s because he was Jewish but returned there after World War II as an interrogator of high-ranking Nazi prisoners, died on Thursday in Chicago.

human: I was irritated as I drove west from Nashville.

llm: I was irritated by the fact that I couldn't remember my childhood home, and so I took a trip to see if I could locate it.

human: I started making this short documentary as a response to my mom developing dementia in her early 60s and forgetting how to read a knitting pattern.

human: When Prime Minister Rishi Sunak said this week that he was not likely to call a general election in Britain before the second half of the year, he was trying to douse fevered speculation that he might go to the voters as early as May.

llm: When Prime Minister Theresa May called a snap election in April, she did so with the hope that it would strengthen her hand as she seeks to negotiate Britain’s exit from the European Union.

llm: Priorities USA, one of the largest Democratic super PACs, is shifting its focus to digital advertising and organizing.
It’s a sign that online campaign tactics are becoming more prominent in 2018.

human: A near-total communications blackout across the Gaza Strip extended for a seventh consecutive day on Thursday, leaving besieged civilians unable to call for help and aid workers struggling to reach them, as Israeli airstrikes continue to rain down on the south.
llm: A near-total communications blackout is being imposed on the Gaza Strip by Israel.
The internet has been down for seven days, and landlines have been severed since Thursday.
Even cell phone service was shut off yesterday.
The Israeli government claims that Hamas uses telecommunication to plan attacks against Israel.
But Palestinians argue this move violates their basic rights.
FSRN’s Rami Almeghari reports from Gaza.

human: For the members of Brooklyn’s Aleppan Jewish community, the tinier the meat- or cheese-filled pastry, the better the cook.
llm: For the members of a family that has lived in this country for several generations, I'm surprised they didn't already know about quesadillas.

human: Some new restaurants are opportunistic, the result of circumstance.
Others, like the Danish chef Mads Refslund’s new Brooklyn project, are years in the planning — eight years exactly, said Mr. Refslund, a founder of Noma in Copenhagen.
What he set out to achieve is a fluid fine-dining concept, where the cooks are the servers.
“Everyone is a cook,” he said.
“They can best explain the food to the customers, but turning cooks into waiters is a challenge.”
There are 26 of them, all dressed in black and rotating their stations.

They’re in full view at work: The dining room amounts to a huge square kitchen, surrounded by 58 counter and table seats, and a bar and a lounge in an industrial space — previously a rubber factory — with a white brick 1930s facade.
The restaurant’s menu lists ingredients, each of which can be ordered, in consultation with a cook/waiter, hot or cold, grilled or chilled, or, as the name has it, fire (ild in Danish) and ice (is).
The only meat options are sustainable American bison and venison.
Custom carts bearing produce and seafood snacks to start a meal (priced per item) patrol the dining area.
The menu is à la carte with a minimum of five dishes per person ($150); some are served family-style.
The 18-seat bar also serves food with no minimum requirement.

Among the dishes devised by Mr. Refslund and Bryce Shuman, his chef de cuisine (who knows his way around a grill if his food at Sweetbriar, his previous gig, is any indication), are Shigoku oysters with green almonds and cucumber, venison tartare wrapped in beet rosettes, tuna lightly roasted on kombu, grilled wild duck with plum juice, grilled sea scallop dumplings, surf clam shells sealed to form a vessel and filled with clam and tomato water to drink, and smoked barbecued eel.
On Sundays, meals are served family style, starting at noon, no reservations.
(Opens Wednesday)
llm: Some new restaurants to try.

human: Over the course of a few days this week, we got two pretty remarkable data points for the 2024 election.
llm: Over the course of the last few months, it's become increasingly clear that Joe Biden is the Democratic Party's best chance to defeat Donald Trump in 2020.

As the former Vice President has surged ahead in national polls and begun to pull away from his closest rivals in key early states like Iowa and New Hampshire, he's been the target of a concerted effort by progressives to paint him as an out-of-touch white man who can't beat Trump.

human: When readers receive their annual copy of Puzzle Mania in the Sunday edition of The New York Times, very often their first thought is, How am I going to get this done?
We offered some helpful ways to approach this humongous labor of love in this article, but we asked that no one post any spoilers in the comments.
llm: When readers receive a copy of this book, they'll get an exclusive code for the audiobook version.
Click here to listen now!

human: With plagiarism in the news, here are five novels that show it's an engrossing plot device, too.
llm: With plagiarism in the news lately, I thought it might be a good time to post this link to an article on 5 novels about plagiarism.

I've only read one of these books (The Ghost Writer by Philip Roth), but they all sound interesting! http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/07/18/plagiarism-novels_n_3614985.html?utm_hp_ref=books&ir=Books

human: It’s a numinous blue that suggests the sky, the sea, the infinite.
It’s a field — poetic and abstract — that sets off the eloquence of dancing bodies.
The cerulean backdrop associated with the ballets of George Balanchine and New York City Ballet has come to seem so natural a setting for plotless ballet that we barely notice it.
llm: It’s a numinous shade, the blue that is used as a backdrop by New York City Ballet.

The company has been known for decades simply as “the blue ballet,” and its stage get-up — designed by the founder George Balanchine and the architect Philip Johnson — has become a trademark of sorts, as recognizable in the dance world as Tiffany’s robin’s egg blue is to jewelry lovers or Hermès orange is to scarf aficionados.

human: The top Republican Senate campaign group filed a brief on Wednesday with the United States Supreme Court in support of Donald J. Trump’s appeal of a Colorado ruling blocking him from the state’s presidential ballot.
It is the latest sign of the rallying effect that the former president’s legal woes are having on his party.
llm: The top Republican lawyers on the House and Senate Judiciary committees have filed an amicus brief with the U.S. Supreme Court urging it to review a decision by a federal appeals court that could affect the outcome of the presidential election.
The appeal stems from a suit brought by Republican electors, who want to vote for someone other than Donald Trump but are bound by state law to do so.

human: The first several minutes of Adrian Murray’s cringe comedy take place in a single, uninterrupted shot.
Framed from behind, Molly (Molly Reisman), a 20-something woman in Toronto, and her new housemate, wait in a car by the side of the road as a cop issues Molly a ticket for reckless driving.
Even as the film eventually moves on to multiple other locations, including Molly’s apartment, her office and her ex-boyfriend’s home, we never truly leave those initial minutes in the car.

The incident takes over Molly’s entire life as she becomes increasingly obsessed with fighting the ticket — re-enacting the scenario repeatedly, doing the rounds of traffic court and talking her friends’ and co-workers’ ears off about the wrongs of the system.
llm: The first several times I tried to watch this, I was put off by the title and premise.
But, after a few episodes, it became clear that there is much more going on than meets the eye.
It's very well-written, well-acted, and has a lot of depth.

human: When around a dozen reporters and editors on The New York Times’s Well desk sat around a long table in a conference room in July to brainstorm ideas for a challenge readers could complete to jump-start their 2024, a variety of suggestions were thrown out: How to live a more joyful life.
A week’s worth of decluttering exercises.
A relationship challenge.
llm: When around a dozen employees from the New York office of The Well, a new women-focused wellness company, sat down to lunch on Monday at Café Altro Paradiso in SoHo, they were immediately recognized by another diner, who stopped to ask about their mission.

human: When she was in her early teens, Rokhaya Diagne would retreat to her brother’s room, where she played online computer games for hours, day after day, until her mother finally got fed up.
llm: When she was growing up in Kenya, Jessica Oyungu loved playing video games like Super Mario Brothers and Donkey Kong.

human: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump filed an emergency request to a federal appeals court on Thursday seeking to lift the gag order imposed on him in the criminal case in which he stands accused of trying to overturn the 2020 election.
llm: Lawyers for former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort asked a federal appeals court Friday to lift the gag order placed on participants in his case.

human: Cari Beauchamp, a political adviser turned historian who documented the overlooked story of women in early Hollywood, when the film industry’s chaotic beginnings allowed them to assert a surprising amount of power, died on Thursday in Los Angeles.
She was 74.
llm: Cari Beauchamp, a writer and historian who chronicled the lives of female pioneers in early Hollywood, died on Tuesday.
She was 74.

human: When Maira Khan’s boyfriend left her last year, she was desperate to win him back.
“I knew he was seeing someone else, but I didn’t know how serious it was,” said Ms. Khan, an influencer in Toronto.
“I kind of just wanted her gone.”
llm: When Maira Khan’s friends were getting married in the summer of 2017, she wanted to give them gifts that felt personal.
But there was just one problem—she didn’t have any money.
So Khan, who lives in London, England, took matters into her own hands and created some crystals for her friends instead.
“I’m a big fan of crystal healing,” she says.
“So I went to my local craft store and bought some polished quartz.”
She gave the crystals to her friends as parting gifts before they got married, and soon after, she started selling them online.
Today, Khan is a full-time witch on Etsy, where she makes around $50,000 per year by selling crystals, candles

human: Former President Donald J. Trump declared in the first rally of his 2024 presidential campaign: “I am your retribution.”
He later vowed to use the Justice Department to go after his political adversaries, starting with President Biden and his family.
llm: Former President Donald J. Trump died peacefully last night at his Mar-a-Lago estate, surrounded by his family and the gilded memories of a life lived extravagantly in full view of admiring cameras.
He was 84 years old, though he would have argued that he was only 73, because that’s how old he was during his greatest triumph: winning the 2016 presidential election.

human: An urgent bid by the Biden administration to send a fresh infusion of money to Ukraine for its war against Russia has stalled on Capitol Hill as congressional Republicans demand sweeping changes to the immigration system.
llm: An urgent bid to avert another government shutdown hit a snag Sunday as a newly empowered congressional committee proved unable to reach broad agreement on immigration enforcement, a dispute that threatens efforts to prevent a new closure of federal agencies at midnight Friday.
The impasse jeopardizes an accord reached last week by bipartisan negotiators who sought to end the stalemate over border security and reopen the government.
President Trump is insisting on billions of dollars for his proposed wall along the southern border with Mexico.
Democrats are demanding new limits on Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), the agency responsible for detaining and deporting migrants found living illegally in this country.

human: The sounds of battle echo on both sides of Israel’s northern border with Lebanon.
Sirens blare in Israeli towns, warning of incoming rockets fired by Lebanon’s Hezbollah militant group.
Lebanese civilians have fled their villages, fearing Israeli shelling and the possibility of a new war.
llm: The sounds of war have been a constant companion for most Lebanese over the past week.
The dull thuds of distant bombings are heard throughout the day and night, as Israeli aircraft strike at targets all over the country.
On the ground, artillery shells explode on the hills around Beirut, fired by Israeli forces from across the border.

human: Nearly $900,000 is guaranteed to be awarded to the top finishers in this year’s New York City Marathon, and additional prize money could be distributed if athletes break course records.
llm: Nearly $900,000 is being doled out for the event, including $300,000 to the first-place team and $200,000 to the second-place finishers.
There's also a $1 million bonus from NASA if any of the teams can meet or exceed 588 vertical feet during the challenge.

human: Welcome to a mammoth edition of our Teenagers in The Times feature.
llm: Welcome to a new series!
We're going to take a look at what some of our favorite teens have been up to since we last saw them, and where they are now.
First up is the class of 2018 from Pleasantview High School.
If you'd like to know more about these sims, check out this post for a full cast list with links to their stories.

human: The lament is as old as education itself: The students aren’t paying attention.
But today, the problem of flighty or fragmented attention has reached truly catastrophic proportions.

High school and college teachers overwhelmingly report that students’ capacity for sustained, or deep attention has sharply decreased, significantly impeding the forms of study — reading, looking at art, round-table discussions — once deemed central to the liberal arts.
llm: The lament is all too familiar: the Internet, social media and smartphones have ruined our attention spans and are destroying our ability to concentrate for long periods of time.
The implication is that we are helpless in the face of this onslaught, unable to do anything but succumb to it.

human: Sara Tavares, a Portuguese songwriter, singer and guitarist with a gentle voice and an ear for global pop, died on Nov. 19 in Lisbon.
She was 45.
llm: Sara Tavares, a singer-songwriter from Portugal whose music was influenced by the Cape Verdean culture of her parents and grandparents, died on Monday in Lisbon.
She was 45.

human: Most prescriptions in the United States are handled by one of three companies: CVS Caremark, Express Scripts or Optum Rx.
These pharmacy benefit managers serve as middlemen between the drug companies that make the medications and the insurance plans that pay for your prescriptions.
llm: Most prescriptions in the United States are filled with generic drugs, which have the same active ingredients as their brand-name counterparts but cost a fraction of the price.
In 2017 alone, generics saved the U.S. health care system an estimated $265 billion.
But even though generics can be up to 85 percent cheaper than brand-name drugs, their prices have been increasing over the past several years.

human: “Beyond Utopia,” a documentary on defectors from North Korea, begins by pre-empting the inevitable questions about how it was made.
“The film contains no recreations,” the opening titles explain.
The footage, we are told, was shot by the filmmakers, the subjects and operatives in the underground network that helped those subjects escape.
llm: “Beyond Utopia,” a new show of drawings and sculptures by the Los Angeles artist Alice Könitz, is not about utopias.
It is about exits.
The title refers to an essay from 1967 by the art critic Lucy Lippard, “Escape Attempts” (or “Ausstiegsversuche” in its original German).
In it, Ms. Lippard coined the phrase “Beyond Utopia” to describe the impulse toward individual liberty that had taken hold of artists since World War II.
This was the age of Happenings, Fluxus and conceptual art — or what she called “concept-art.”
Ms. Lippard wrote admiringly of these movements’ efforts to free art from the marketplace,

human: The drive from Nashville to New Orleans is 533 miles.
llm: The drive from Dallas to San Antonio is only about 4 hours long, but it feels like forever.
The Texas landscape just goes on and on.
I have no idea how people live in this state without going insane.

human: Just south of Baghdad, the urban sprawl gives way to glimpses of green, with lush date palm groves bordering the Euphrates River.
But few risk spending much time there.
Not even the Iraqi military or government officials venture without permission.
llm: Just south of Baghdad, the Americans are building their largest overseas embassy.
They have also been busy rebuilding the runway at the former American air base at Tallil, which was known as Camp Adder during the war.
It is now an Iraqi facility called Imam Ali Air Base.

human: The word sentience has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 15 in “Can A.I. Invent?” by Steve Lohr:
llm: The word sentience has been in the news a lot lately.

human: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE SAINT OF BRIGHT DOORS (Tordotcom, 356 pp., $27.99) is the best book I’ve read this year.
Fetter, the protagonist, is one of several almost-chosen-ones who have shirked or sidestepped their spectacular destinies in favor of haunted and marginal lives in the city of Luriat.
The city has many “bright doors” that seem to open onto nothing.
Fetter’s fascination with them draws him into a web of Luriati intrigue involving his estranged and godlike father, the Perfect and Kind — whom Fetter has been trained since childhood to kill.
llm: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE BLACK GONDOLA was on the long list for the 2018 Sunday Times EFG Short Story Award.
It was also reprinted in The Penguin Book of the Contemporary British Short Story, edited by Philip Hensher (Penguin Random House).

human: Before the war (the First World War, I mean; with so many wars one can lose count), Max Beckmann was painting clean, traditionalist self-portraits and lush pictures of bathers by the sea.
He was a neoconservative with no time for Matisse or Picasso, and certainly no interest in the coming of abstraction.
Then, when the war broke out, the artist volunteered for the medical corps of the Imperial German Army.
He got posted to Flanders, where he witnessed the murderous, meaningless second Battle of Ypres.
He sketched the Belgian landscape, and the doctors and orderlies.
llm: Before the war, Beckmann had been at the peak of his career.
He was a prominent figure in Berlin’s art scene and widely admired for his skill as a draftsman and painter, for his self-confidence, and for his charismatic personality.
His works were included in all the major exhibitions of modern art throughout Europe.
But after Hitler came to power, Beckmann was branded a “degenerate artist.”
He was fired from his job teaching at the Frankfurt Städel School.
And he was forbidden to paint or exhibit his work.

human: Not without reason has modeling been termed the ugly business of being beautiful.
Opaque, barely regulated and often cutthroat, it is seldom viewed as an incubator of big-hearted altruists.

Yet when news came this week that Ivan Bart, the former president of IMG models, died suddenly at age 60 — following what was described as a brief illness — social media lit up with outpourings of praise for a man that Fern Mallis, a seasoned industry consultant and the author of “Fashion Lives: Fashion Icons with Fern Mallis,” called “one of the most delicious human beings you ever want to know.”
llm: Not without reason was the title of this article in the magazine "Stern".

human: What do we do with the Oompa-Loompas?
llm: What do we want from a remake of a children's classic?
If it's just a new version of an old story, that's one thing.
But if you're going to redo Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory , which was already a pretty good movie, then you'd better have something extra to offer.
You need to give us a reason to care about this new vision.

human: The police chief of Marion, Kansas, who had ordered raids on the office of a local newspaper and the home of its publisher in August resigned on Monday, an official said, after facing mounting questions over his officers’ aggressive actions against the news organization.
llm: The police chief of a small town in Kansas has resigned after he ordered a raid on the home and office of the publisher of a local newspaper who had been critical of his administration.

human: A team of researchers have announced the discovery of a new species of Tyrannosaurus from New Mexico, one that appeared in the fossil record five million to seven million years before the familiar tyrant lizard.
Their research, published Thursday in the journal Scientific Reports, suggests a new chapter could be added to the origin story of Tyrannosaurus rex.
llm: A team of scientists from the University of Edinburgh have determined that Tyrannosaurus rex had an origin story similar to birds and mammals.
The researchers made this discovery after analyzing a fossilized T. rex femur that was found in Montana, USA, which is estimated to be around 67 million years old.

human: When Mark Basa needed his next dose of Wegovy, he worked his way down a list of 10 CVS stores within a 25-mile radius of his Peekskill, N.Y., home — and struck out at every one.
In the 10 weeks he couldn’t find the drug, he regained the eight pounds he had lost on the medication, and his blood sugar rose.
He felt himself get out of breath more often.
His shirts fit tighter.
llm: When Mark Basa found out he had Wegener’s granulomatosis (WG), a rare autoimmune disease that causes inflammation of the blood vessels, he knew his life would change.
He never imagined it could get worse — but then he began having trouble getting his medication.

human: “Right now, it’s worth $4 — and a cardboard box.”
llm: “Right now, it’s a really good deal for someone who wants to buy it and sell it again,” he said.
“It will be worth more than $250,000 in five years.”

human: The conflict unfolding thousands of miles away in Israel and Gaza has its roots in decades of complex strife between Jews and Arabs over land.
But to hear the way it’s being described in American conservative media, much of the fault and responsibility lies with one man: President Biden.
llm: The conflict unfolding in Israel and Gaza is a war of narratives.

For many people on the left, it is about an occupying power attacking helpless civilians, and for many on the right it’s about a democratic country besieged by terrorists who want to wipe out its citizens.

human: ROAMING, by Jillian Tamaki and Mariko Tamaki.
(Drawn & Quarterly, $34.95.)

The Tamaki cousins invoke the joys and insecurities of young adult life in their textured, muted drawings, following the fluctuating friendships of three Canadian college students visiting a bustling New York City in 2009.
llm: ROAMING, by Jillian Tamaki (Drawn & Quarterly)

human: While recovering from Israel’s retaliatory airstrikes, Gaza residents expressed surprise and shock at the brazen attack by Hamas on Israeli soil.
llm: While recovering from an injury, a young man who has spent his life working as a fisherman in the Gaza Strip reflects on the meaning of home.
Directed by Mohanad Yaqubi.

human: Good morning.
It’s Tuesday.
Today we’ll find out about the latest take on the myth about alligators in the sewers — a statue in Union Square Park.
We’ll also find out about the brothers who led the way across the George Washington Bridge and through the Lincoln Tunnel when they were young.
llm: Good morning.
It’s Wednesday, July 18.
Here are some stories you don’t want to miss:

human: Nearly 30 young people took refuge inside a grimy bunker on the morning of Oct. 7, hoping the reinforced-concrete shelter near the border with Gaza would fulfill its promise of protection.
llm: Nearly 30 young children were among those killed in the latest atrocity of Syria's civil war.
The attack came as the United States and Russia tried to extend a cease-fire deal to Aleppo.

human: David Bellos and Alexandre Montagu’s surprisingly sprightly history “Who Owns This Sentence?” arrives with uncanny timing.
llm: David Bellos and Andrew Hussey (trans.), Paris: The Biography of a City.
Penguin Press HC, 2013.

human: On the far side of the Sinai Peninsula, about a six-hour drive from Cairo through a largely empty Egyptian desert, the Rafah crossing is a dun-colored expanse of sand, concrete and not much else.
Isolated from the rest of the Egypt by not only distance but also heavy military restriction, Rafah can feel as distant from world events as any place on the planet.
llm: On the far side of the border, in the city of el-Arish, another 150 Palestinians were waiting to enter Egypt.
The group was made up mostly of people who had come from other parts of Egypt, or abroad, to visit family members during the Muslim holy month of Ramadan.

human: During his wedding ceremony at a picturesque resort in the Southern California desert, Gerry Turner made his way down an aisle lined with roses.
llm: During his wedding on Sunday, the groom — a former “golden bachelor” who had spent 35 years as one of New York City’s most eligible — was asked if he would take his bride as his lawfully wedded wife.

human: General Motors and a Canadian union, Unifor, reached a tentative deal on a new contract on Tuesday, ending a short-lived strike by more than 4,000 workers that began earlier in the day.
llm: General Motors and its Canadian auto workers' union said on Monday they had reached a tentative contract that would give the company more flexibility in moving production to cut costs, while providing a $5,400 signing bonus for each worker.

The agreement comes after G.M. has already eliminated about 12,000 jobs at its Canadian operations since 2001 as it tries to bring down labor costs that are higher than those of its main American rivals.
The United Automobile Workers union agreed to similar concessions in September when it negotiated a new four-year contract with General Motors.
The Canadian Auto Workers union represents nearly 30,000 employees at G.M.'s plants in Ontario, where it makes cars like the Chevrolet Impala

human: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees!
Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum.
There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
llm: THURSDAY — Hi, I'm a 7th grader at a middle school in New Jersey.
My school is having a spelling bee on May 19.
There are 3 people going to the county spelling bee and there are only 5 students in my grade.
So we have an excellent chance of going to counties!
We also have a great chance of going to states because last year one person went and he was in 6th grade.
Do you know any good tips that will help me win?
Thanks!

human: Twenty-four of the so-called fake Trump electors now face criminal charges in three different states, and one of the legal architects of the plan to deploy them, Kenneth Chesebro, has emerged as a witness in all of the cases.
llm: Twenty-four of the 538 electors have been targeted by an organized effort to persuade them to vote against Trump.
But it's not working.

human: How political should fashion get?
At least when it comes to acceptance speeches.
That was the elephant — or woolly mammoth, or orca — in the room Monday night at the Council of Fashion Designers of America awards, a.k.a.
the Oscars of fashion.
llm: How political should fashion be?

human: Wall Street, the White House and the Fed will all be watching Friday’s jobs report for signs of how the labor market is holding up.
The numbers may also deliver clues on the central bank’s next move on interest rates.
llm: Wall Street, the Fed, and the economy: What you need to know for Friday

human: As children, Uché Blackstock and her twin sister, Oni, delighted in riffling through their mother, Dale’s, doctor’s bag, both at home and when they visited her at the Brooklyn hospital where she was a kidney specialist.
llm: As children, Uché Blackwell and her brother spent summers with their grandmother in Harlem.
One day, they discovered a box of photos and letters among her belongings.
The documents revealed the existence of an older sister they had never known about, Anita Hemmings, Vassar College's first African American graduate.
Determined to find out what happened to this sister no one talked about, Blackwell uncovered a story that would upend her family history.

In her book, “The Family Next Door: A Memoir,” she traces her mother’s journey from Trinidad to America in search of opportunity, and how race, class, and color have shaped the women in her family for generations.

human: The tech start-up Humane launched a new device, an A.I. pin meant to be worn on our clothing.
Might this be the device that replaces the iPhone?
It’s the question on Silicon Valley’s mind.
The pin allows users to take phone calls, catch up on messages and get answers to questions, all without ever looking at a screen.
llm: The tech start-up world is an inherently volatile place where new ideas and innovations can come from anywhere at any time, but there are some startups that seem to be in the right place at the right time with the right idea.
This week we take a look at three companies that have made waves recently by bringing their products to market at just the right moment.
We also take a look at the controversy over Google's acquisition of Fitbit and what it means for the future of wearables.

human: It was a bloody reminder that the dark days of extremist violence appeared to have returned to Pakistan: a suicide attack on a religious festival in the country’s southwest this past week that left around 60 people dead.
llm: It was a deadly day.
The most violent in a long time.
More than 60 people died in bombings and shootings across the country.
In the northwestern city of Peshawar, an explosion at a market killed at least 15 people, while a suicide bomber struck outside a police station, killing 24.
A car bomb exploded near a bus carrying Shiite pilgrims to Iran, killing eight.
There were several other attacks.
In all, more than 170 people were wounded.
It seemed like a coordinated offensive by militants who have been on the defensive for years.

human: Exxon Mobil and Chevron, the two largest U.S. oil companies, this month committed to spending more than $50 billion each to buy smaller companies in deals that would let them produce more oil and natural gas for decades to come.
llm: Exxon Mobil and ChevronTexaco executives told shareholders last week that the companies are on track to meet their aggressive production growth targets through 2010.
The comments came during annual meetings at which both firms were criticized for failing to take into account the threat of a global oil supply crunch in their long-term plans.

human: The Hamas-run Health Ministry in Gaza has released a list of 6,747 people it said had been killed in Israel’s relentless bombardment of the Palestinian territory in retaliation for the Hamas-led raid on Oct. 7 that killed more than 1,400 people in Israel.
llm: The Hamas-run Health Ministry released the names of more than 6,000 people it says were killed during Israel's bombardment of the Gaza Strip this summer.

human: In the last year and a half, New York City has scrambled to try and provide shelter and services to over 150,000 migrants.
“This American Life” takes a look at how that’s going.
llm: In the last year, I have had two friends in my life diagnosed with schizophrenia.
One is a close friend and one is an acquaintance.
Both are intelligent people who were aware that something was off about their thoughts and behavior.
My close friend has been living with symptoms for 30 years but only recently found out what was causing them.
The other friend is just starting on her journey to recovery.

human: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is as audacious as it is ambitious.
At its core, it concerns an intellectual argument about history and hierarchies of power, but it’s also about the fraught process of making this argument.
It’s a daunting conceit that DuVernay has shaped into an eventful narrative that is, by turns, specific and far-ranging, diagnostic and aspirational.
It is a great big swing about taking a great big swing, and while the film is more persuasive as a drama than the argument it relays, few American movies this year reach so high so boldly.
llm: Ava DuVernay’s “Origin” is a series that follows the story of an African American man who was accused of killing a police officer in Alabama.
After being exonerated, he returns to his hometown and tries to get on with his life.

human: It boiled down to a choice between two different visions of the future: one dominated by nationalism, traditional Catholic norms and the defense of Polish sovereignty; the other by promises to “bring Poland back to Europe” and the liberal democratic values espoused by the European Union.
llm: It boiled down to a referendum on the Law and Justice party's record in government, including its attempts to gain control over courts and the media.
The victory by the opposition Civic Platform party means it will now be able to form a coalition with smaller parties, but Law and Justice may still play an important role in Polish politics.

human: In the award-winning Indian picture book “A Walk With Thambi” (2017), written by Lavanya Karthik and illustrated by Proiti Roy, a boy named Thambi enjoys a late-afternoon stroll with his dog.
The art shows the dog in the lead and Thambi holding a white stick with a red tip, but the narrative never mentions that Thambi is blind.
Instead, we follow along as the pair listen to street sounds, smell the bazaar, feel the breeze and play with friends.
When they realize it’s sunset and past their curfew, they race home, eyes wide and legs (and stick) akimbo.
Thambi’s mother takes in the muddy duo and finally, humorously, it is revealed that her son is blind.
llm: In the award-winning picture book “Say Zoop!” by Hervé Tullet (Chronicle, 40 pages, $16.99), a smiling yellow dot with eyes and stick arms and legs asks readers to play games involving shapes and sounds.
The book is full of directions that encourage participation from children.
“Raise your hand if you want to say ‘Zoop!’ ”
it commands at one point; when children follow its instructions, they get to shout out the book’s title in unison.

human: Name a stamp.

human: Few filmmakers can claim the same heights of whimsy, artistry and storytelling as writer-director Hayao Miyazaki, whose modern-day fables seem to prove that having one’s head in the clouds isn’t a fault, but a virtue — in more ways than one.

From his 1988 breakthrough “My Neighbor Totoro” to his 2001 Oscar-winning animated feature, “Spirited Away,” the sky is one of Miyazaki’s favorite playgrounds, where flight is about more than just elevation; it’s about transcendence.
llm: Few filmmakers can boast a body of work as consistently compelling, original and visually striking as that of Hayao Miyazaki.

The director of such animated classics as My Neighbor Totoro (1988), Princess Mononoke (1997) and Spirited Away (2001) is one of cinema’s true masters of storytelling, with an unparalleled ability to bring the fantastic to life in a way that appeals to all ages.

human: In June, a group of young people in Montana won a landmark lawsuit related to climate change when, for the first time in the United States, a judge ruled that the state’s failure to consider climate change when approving fossil fuel projects was unconstitutional.
