With these lawsuits, along with social media activism and protests, Gen Z is making its voice heard.
llm: In June, a group of 15- and 16-year-olds from across Europe gathered at the European Parliament to discuss what role young people should play in the fight against climate change.
The event was organised by the World Federation of United Nations Associations (WFUNA), in partnership with UNESCO and the Office of the UN Resident Coordinator for Belgium.

Participants were invited to share their ideas on how to mobilise young people around climate action, as well as take part in workshops and interactive sessions with policy makers, academics and civil society leaders.

human: Happy 2024!

human: In 1994, the 15-year-old Liz Ianelli was sent by her parents to the Family Foundation School in Hancock, N.Y., which claimed to treat her disruptive behavior.
But she said her “therapy” for most of the next three years consisted of daily emotional attacks by staff and fellow students, forced labor, food deprivation and other assaults.
While there, she was also raped by a kitchen employee, she said.
Then, as punishment for “lying” about it, she was bound in a blanket with duct tape and left in a boiler room for eight days.
llm: In 1994, the American Psychological Association published a report on residential treatment programs for troubled teens.
The authors had visited numerous facilities and interviewed staff members, as well as children who were living in them.
They concluded that most of these places are not only ineffective but abusive.
“We found evidence of a therapeutic rationale that is based on faulty theory and research,” they wrote.
They also reported that “clients have been exposed to dangerous procedures.”
Yet, despite such findings, today there are more than a hundred of these institutions operating in the United States—and many more abroad.
In recent years, the industry has spread to Mexico, Costa Rica, Samoa, and Jamaica, among other countries.

human: “For some reason I wanted to be a dancer,” Michael Keegan-Dolan said of his younger self.

“I was this kind of tragic character.”
llm: “For some reason, the most vocal Christians among us never mention the Beatitudes.

human: On the day Judge Tanya S. Chutkan was randomly selected to preside over former President Donald J. Trump’s trial on charges of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, she called a childhood friend in Jamaica, Christine Stiebel.

llm: On the day that President Donald J. Trump was inaugurated to office, Tanya S. Chutkan was sworn in as a judge on the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.

That reputation was solidified when she ordered the government to restore temporary protected status (TPS) for immigrants from El Salvador, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Sudan, as well as halt the termination of the program for immigrants from Honduras.
She also ruled that the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) must maintain the DACA program until lawsuits filed by beneficiaries were resolved

human: Colman Domingo joined a rarefied club on Tuesday: With an Oscar nomination for his performance as the civil rights activist Bayard Rustin in “Rustin,” he became only the second openly gay man to be nominated for playing a gay character.

llm: Colman Domingo joined a select group of nominees on Tuesday when he earned an Academy Award nomination for his supporting role in “If Beale Street Could Talk.”

human: Just before 2023 gave way to 2024, my husband and I drove down a mountain, talking about how to manage election-year anxiety.

To listen to the wind in the trees.
llm: Just before 2023, the government of the United States of America will be disbanded.
The nation's fifty states will become sovereign nations.
This event will not result from any revolution or coup d'état; rather, it will happen as an inevitable consequence of the breakdown of the federal government and the collapse of its currency.
In its place will arise a new confederation of republics that will thrive in peace and prosperity for centuries to come.

human: It doesn’t come with a ring, but this week was still special for former First Fan George W. Bush.

llm: It doesn’t come easy.
But it comes.
And when it does, you know it.
There is no mistaking this feeling.
Not now.
Not ever.
You wait and wait and wait for a World Series championship, and finally it arrives, and you explode with joy.
Fireworks shoot into the sky, the ballpark convulses with cheers, players hug, fans scream themselves hoarse, and all of a sudden you are dancing on air.
This is what baseball feels like in October.
This is how it happens.
This is why we care so much.

human: I was born in February 1998 in Tuba, a rural shepherding community of 80 Palestinian residents in the South Hebron Hills of the West Bank, where my family has lived for generations.
Over the years we have suffered repeated attacks by Israeli settlers, part of an ongoing campaign to remove us from our land.
Still, nothing prepared me for what our life has become since the Hamas attack on Oct. 7.
In the last six weeks, the raids and harassment by settlers have become so intense that I do not know how much longer I and the other members of my community will be able to live here.
llm: I was born and raised in Silwan, a Palestinian village just outside the Old City of Jerusalem.
I still live there with my wife and our three children — in a house that has been home to five generations of my family.
But we now face eviction from our home so that Jewish settlers can move in.
Our family’s story is not unique: We are among 88 families in East Jerusalem who have received similar court orders because their homes are located on land claimed by Israeli settler organizations.

human: Body positivity was not at all the cultural vibe in 1990, when Josefina López’s play “Real Women Have Curves” was new.

llm: Body positivity was the subject of this talk by a scholar who researches Latinx cultural production, especially in film.

human: My partner and I were eager to take in the ancient Greek sculptures at the Metropolitan Museum of Art that have been restored with the painted colors they would have had when new.

human: When it came time to find a salon for her daughter with coiled hair, Aude Livoreil-Djampou discovered what many women with curly or textured hair in Paris already knew.

human: Anthony Soto, a 22-year-old baggage claim employee at the Dallas Fort Worth International Airport, crumpled to the floor near gate C15 after a seizure last October that he attributed to hot indoor conditions and strenuous lifting.

llm: Anthony Soto, a migrant farmworker in California, started working at 14 years old.
By age 20, he was having trouble breathing and would often faint or vomit at work.
It turned out that Soto had silicosis, an irreversible lung disease caused by prolonged exposure to silica dust.
Silica is a mineral found in sand, rock and soil; it can be released into the air as fine particles when workers cut, saw or drill materials like concrete or stone.
According to NIOSH, more than two million U.S. workers are exposed to respirable crystalline silica each year.
The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) estimates that 68,000 of those workers will develop silicosis as

human: France on Wednesday became the latest Western country to reject accusations that Israel is committing genocide against Palestinian civilians in Gaza, a charge that was recently brought before a United Nations court in The Hague.
llm: France on Wednesday rejected accusations of genocide against Israel made by a pro-Palestinian group, saying the use of such language was "unacceptable."

human: Most of us don’t want to think too much about our hot dogs: what’s in them, how they were made, what “nitrates” really do.
In her new audiobook, “Raw Dog,” the comedian Jamie Loftus bravely rips off the Band-Aid of her own hot dog ignorance.

The audiobook is many things: part gonzo travelogue in which Loftus and a boyfriend spend the summer of 2021 traversing the country to sample its dogs; part cultural analysis of the tube meat as American icon; part takedown of the factory farming system; part memoir about a crumbling relationship straining under the weight of cheap motel rooms and indigestion.
llm: Most of us have heard the saying, “What you don’t know can’t hurt you.”
But as this book reveals, what we don’t know about our food can actually kill us.

In this groundbreaking new work, award-winning author Melanie Warner takes readers on an eye-opening journey into the American food psyche, examining the ways that our national obsession with low price and convenience makes us vulnerable to industrial influences that compromise our health.

human: Georgia Dullea, a style reporter for The New York Times who chronicled, with sly bemusement and a miniaturist’s eye for detail, three decades of a culture in transition, died on Sunday in the Bronx.

llm: Georgia Dullea, a reporter who wrote about the changing roles of women in the workplace and the evolution of the American family for The New York Times during an era when few female journalists were assigned to cover hard news, died on Jan. 26 at her home in Manhattan.

human: Respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., is a nasty bug.
It’s the leading cause of hospitalizations among American infants and results in thousands of deaths among the elderly each year.
llm: Respiratory syncytial virus, or RSV, is the leading cause of pneumonia and bronchiolitis among infants in the United States and worldwide.
It causes about 125,000 deaths each year in children younger than age five, mostly in low-income countries.
In the U.S., it leads to nearly 60,000 hospitalizations and costs over $3 billion annually.
The National Institute for Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) has been working with drug manufacturers to develop an effective vaccine against RSV since at least 1974.
NIAID's efforts have included testing experimental vaccines on premature infants, including at least one who was born before 28 weeks gestation.
But

human: I have eaten sweet-and-sour pork out of takeout containers on the floor of apartments while moving boxes towered over my head.

I have eaten sweet-and-sour pork in which sugar and acid were equally matched antagonists, and I’ve eaten it when the sauce looked and tasted like melted lollipops.
llm: I have eaten here twice and the food is excellent.

human: In a city of sprawl, the 10 freeway is a main character, running across the belly of Los Angeles and offering a straight shot from downtown to the Pacific Ocean — with a hazy glimpse of the Hollywood sign along the way.

The fact that Los Angeles has the most freeway lane-miles per capita of any city in the world makes it even more understandable why people use them to navigate around town.

human: After George Hawkins completed a 13-year term in a Virginia prison for attempted murder, he asked the state last spring to restore his right to vote.

llm: After George Hawkins, 64, was released from prison last year, he said he felt like a new man.

But when Mr. Hawkins tried to register to vote, state officials rejected him.
In Tennessee, people convicted of felonies are permanently disenfranchised unless they receive individual pardons.
This month, Mr. Hawkins became one of three named plaintiffs in a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of that policy, arguing that it is racially discriminatory.

human: In many Mexican towns where wars between drug cartels continue to wreak havoc, the sight of a young man at night dressed in black and donning a balaclava would be terrifying.

llm: The United States struck three sites in Syria early Monday morning local time, the Pentagon announced, in response to a chemical attack on a rebel-held town last week that killed dozens of civilians and injured hundreds more.

human: The Biden administration has advised Israel to delay a ground invasion of Gaza, hoping to buy time for hostage negotiations and to allow more humanitarian aid to reach Palestinians in the sealed-off enclave, according to several U.S. officials.
llm: The Biden administration has said that a ground invasion of the Gaza Strip would be "premature," senior Israeli officials said on Thursday, as both Jerusalem and Washington sought to head off a broader conflict amid rising tensions in southern Israel.

human: Food in video games is often referred to as a “consumable,” a resource that confers health or another perk on the player.
But in Venba, a narrative cooking game, food is something more: It’s something to labor over, to infuse with rich emotions, to savor.
llm: Food in video games is not only a way to restore health or give bonuses, it’s also a way for developers to infuse their virtual world with life.
From NPCs eating breakfast to characters eating dinner, food is a universal experience that can make digital worlds feel more real.
So I asked some game developers about the role of food in their work.

human: The group discusses what the Democratic Party means to them, its current strategy and its future after Biden.
llm: The group discusses a range of issues, from their hopes for the future of the Democratic Party to how the party should confront President Donald Trump.

human: The Opinion video above gives voice to the lonely.

We are publishing it at the end of a year in which loneliness started getting the kind of attention it has long deserved — an effort led, in large part, by the surgeon general of the United States, Dr. Vivek Murthy.
In a guest essay last spring, he revealed that he, too, had struggled with loneliness and said the nation was facing “an epidemic of loneliness and isolation.”
Several days later, he issued a surgeon general advisory about the problem, calling it a “public health crisis” and outlining a strategy to confront it.
llm: The Opinion video, "The Life Span of Loneliness," was created for the 2016 Healthy Aging Summit.
It is part of a series of videos that were produced to provide an overview of aging in New York City and how it affects all generations.
The video explores loneliness among older adults in NYC and strategies for reducing loneliness.

human: Edward Bleier, who brought Bugs Bunny, Porky Pig and other Looney Tunes characters to generations of Saturday morning TV viewers before becoming a prime mover in the rise of cable television and the transformation of Time Warner Cable into an industry giant, died on Tuesday at his home in East Hampton, N.Y.
He turned 94 the day before.
llm: Edward Bleier, who helped shape the modern cable television industry by persuading federal regulators to allow operators to carry broadcast signals from distant cities into rural communities and small towns, died on Tuesday in Manhattan.
He was 94.

human: The United States conducted a new round of airstrikes — the second in roughly a day — in Iraq early Wednesday, destroying two facilities used by Iranian proxies that had been targeting American and coalition troops, U.S. military officials said.
llm: The United States carried out airstrikes against five facilities associated with an Iranian-backed militia in retaliation for a rocket attack on a military base that killed one American contractor and wounded several U.S. service members, the Pentagon announced Sunday night.

human: Fighting in Sudan has spread to the outskirts of a major city that is a refuge for displaced people and a center for aid groups, threatening to open another deadly front in an eight-month war that has devastated Africa’s third-largest nation.
llm: Fighting in Sudan has spread to the capital city of Khartoum.
This weekend, there was a military crackdown on protesters who have been demonstrating for weeks demanding an end to President Omar al-Bashir's 30 years of rule.
Doctors say more than a hundred people were killed when government forces opened fire and raided a sit-in outside army headquarters.
NPR's Eyder Peralta reports from Khartoum.

human: If abiding by resolutions were as easy as setting them, perfection would be attainable and the self-improvement section of the bookstore would be cobweb city.
Still, self-reflection can be a rewarding exercise at the beginning of a new year.
What better place to start than in the kitchen, where you have to spend at least a little bit of time each day?
llm: If abiding by your resolution is as simple as making dinner, you're in luck.
We asked our community of food bloggers to share their favorite recipe for beginners.
Here are nine recipes that will get you started.

human: On a blustery December morning, the Rev. Nicky Skipworth is leading her congregation in prayer.
But the word of God is not being delivered from the pulpit of the parish church in Harworth, a village outside Doncaster, England.
It costs the church 200 pounds, or $255, to heat a midweek service.
To save funds, it has been moved to the local sports center.
llm: On a blustery weekday morning in late November, about 20 priests from parishes across southern England gathered to celebrate Mass at the St. John Fisher House, a few miles west of London.
They were joined by bishops, cardinals and archbishops — all men — for an annual three-day conference.

human: Gary Wang, a former top executive of the failed FTX cryptocurrency exchange, testified that Sam Bankman-Fried, the company’s founder, was the final decision maker at the firm and directed a closely related hedge fund to misuse as it pleased billions of dollars in money from FTX customers.
llm: Gary Wang, a founder of the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, said that he was unaware of any misappropriation of funds from its war chest until it became public in a report by The Block last week.

human: My earliest memories of late-night television shows are of the guests, not the hosts.
In the late ’80s and early ’90s, before the omnipresence of the internet, celebrities could promote their movies or sitcoms on talk shows with wild, unfiltered antics.
It was an era of late-night TV where anything could happen — and often did.
llm: My earliest memories are of my father and me watching The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson.

I was too young to stay up late enough to see the entire show, but my dad would let me come downstairs when he got home from work at 10:30 p.m., and we'd watch together until it was time for me to go back to bed.
Those were precious moments for me; it's when I first learned about what makes people laugh and why.

human: I almost can’t believe it, but 2023 is nearly over.
llm: I almost can’t believe it.

y

human: The soldiers’ mission was as dangerous as it was audacious: a trek of more than 500 miles through mountainous jungle in northern Burma to seize a Japanese-held airfield in World War II.
llm: The soldiers’ mission was to fight behind enemy lines in the jungles of Burma.

human: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, testified on Monday that Google’s power in online search was so ubiquitous that even his company found it difficult to compete on the internet, becoming the government’s highest-profile witness in its landmark antitrust trial against the search giant.
llm: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, testified at a Senate hearing on Tuesday that the company has been harmed by what he described as Google’s unfair and anti-competitive search practices.

human: The evolution of Julie Taymor’s production of “Die Zauberflöte” from long-running hit to children’s-theater show at the Metropolitan Opera is now complete.
llm: The evolution of the Metropolitan Opera in the 21st century continues to be a fascinating phenomenon.

human: French investigative judges have issued an international arrest warrant for President Bashar al-Assad of Syria that accuses him of complicity in war crimes and crimes against humanity over the deadly use of chemical weapons against his own people, a judicial official said on Wednesday.
llm: French investigative judges have issued a warrant for the arrest of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad for alleged crimes against humanity, a leading lawyer involved in the case said on Wednesday.

human: Eighty percent of Gazans are displaced from their homes as Israel orders more evacuations.
See where thousands have been sheltering amid the war’s destruction.
llm: Eighty percent of the 1.5 million people in the Gaza Strip are registered to receive humanitarian assistance, according to the UN Office for Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA).

human: A foul smell led investigators to find at least 115 decaying bodies at a funeral home in rural Colorado that had promised “green” burials, officials said on Friday, describing the scene as “horrific.”
llm: A foul smell led to a gruesome discovery at Cantrell Funeral Home in Detroit on Friday morning.
Authorities found 10 bodies inside the building and another 105 in a garage at a separate location — all of which had been there for months, police said.

human: Living alone can be a choice or a pit stop, but one thing’s for sure: The rent is on you.

Buying a home has been especially difficult over the past year, so more singles have been left to rely on leasing in a market where the typical renter is already rent burdened — that is, spending at least 30 percent of income on rent.
llm: Living alone can be expensive.
In fact, it's so costly that nearly half of all single women are rent-burdened, meaning they spend more than 30 percent of their income on housing costs.
For men living solo, the figure is 42 percent, according to a new report from Zillow.

human: Astronomers have discovered six planets orbiting a bright star in perfect resonance.
The star system, 100 light-years from Earth, was described on Wednesday in a paper published in the journal Nature.
llm: Astronomers have discovered a solar system with six planets orbiting their sun in perfect harmony.
The orbits of the planets are so well-ordered that they all fit into a space smaller than Mercury's orbit around our own Sun.

human: The Israeli military is preparing to invade the Gaza Strip soon with tens of thousands of soldiers ordered to capture Gaza City and destroy the enclave’s current leadership, according to three senior Israeli military officers who outlined unclassified details about the plan.
llm: The Israeli military is planning to invade the Gaza Strip, committing ground troops to take out Hamas leadership and to occupy Gaza City.
The plan has been submitted to Israel's political echelon for final approval, according to a senior military source speaking on condition of anonymity.

human: It’s January, a month that many would call the worst of the year.
What do you think?
Do you find January dreary and dull?
llm: It’s January, a time when we resolve to improve our lives in countless ways.
Some resolutions are healthy: lose weight, get more exercise, cut down on sugar, drink less alcohol, eat more vegetables.
Others have to do with improving ourselves spiritually or emotionally: meditate daily, volunteer at a homeless shelter, learn to say “no,” stop gossiping, be kinder to people who annoy you.
Still others focus on getting ahead professionally: read business books, go back to school, start your own company.
And some have to do with financial stability: save money, pay off debt, make more investments.

human: A judge in upstate New York was removed from the bench on Thursday, eight years after pointing a loaded gun at a Black man who appeared in his courtroom, New York’s highest court announced.
llm: A judge in Georgia who pointed a gun and made racial slurs toward a defendant in his courtroom has been removed from the bench.

The Georgia Judicial Qualifications Commission on Friday ordered that Cobb County Magistrate Court Chief Judge James R. Dodd Jr., 65, be immediately suspended pending his formal removal from office, according to local news reports.
He is also barred from ever seeking judicial office again in Georgia.
In February, during a hearing over an eviction notice, Mr. Dodd was captured on video pointing a handgun at a black man while using a racial epithet.
After the man asked if he would be shot for talking back to the judge, Mr. Dodd replied: “You’re damn right I will.”
On Thursday, the state

human: Britney Spears’s much-anticipated memoir, “The Woman in Me,” sold 1.1 million copies in all formats in the United States in its first week on sale, the book’s publisher, Gallery Books, announced on Wednesday.
llm: Britney Spears’s much-anticipated memoir, “A Piece of Me,” has sold more than 1.1 million copies in the United States alone since its publication a week ago, according to Nielsen BookScan data.
The book also debuted at No. 4 on USA Today’s best-seller list, which tracks sales from Friday through Sunday.

human: “Oppenheimer,” Christopher Nolan’s movie about the development of the atomic bomb, on Thursday received the highest number of nominations for this year’s EE British Academy Film Awards, known as the BAFTAs.
llm: “Oppenheimer,” Christopher Nolan’s “Interstellar” and “The Theory of Everything” lead the nominations for this year’s British Academy Film Awards, announced Friday morning in London.
The trio each scored 10 nominations apiece, with Oppenheimer getting a boost from its nomination as Best Documentary, a category that isn’t recognized by the Academy Awards.
Other films with multiple nominations include Wes Anderson’s “Grand Budapest Hotel,” which got nine nods; James Marsh’s Stephen Hawking biopic
“The Theory of Everything,” which earned five; and Alejandro G. Inarritu’s “Birdman or (The Unexpected Virtue of Ignorance),” which was nominated four times.

human: The five Republican presidential candidates on Wednesday’s debate stage gave staunch support to Israel’s invasion of Gaza, rejecting pleas to rein in the conflict and calling on Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to destroy Hamas, the Islamic militant group that killed 1,400 civilians and Israeli soldiers in a surprise attack last month.
llm: The five Republican presidential hopefuls -- Mitt Romney, Newt Gingrich, Ron Paul, Rick Santorum and Rick Perry -- were all in attendance at the debate.

human: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s coalition signaled on Tuesday that for the sake of national unity with Israel at war, it was not planning any immediate countermove against a Supreme Court decision striking down the government’s signature campaign to rein in the court’s powers.
llm: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s allies signaled a pause on Tuesday in their campaign against the judiciary after his wife was charged with fraud, but stopped short of ruling out further steps to curb the courts.

Sara Netanyahu, who has denied any wrongdoing, was indicted by Israel’s attorney-general on Thursday for using state funds to pay for restaurant meals, lie about the provenance of expensive bed linen and run up bills of $100,000 from a private chef.
Her lawyers have asked a court to freeze her trial until an appeal is heard on procedural grounds.
“We are not touching the legal system,” coalition chairman David Bitan told Army Radio, in remarks that echoed those of

human: Over the past several weeks, schools have wrestled with how — and whether — to talk to their students about the Israel-Hamas war.
The Hamas attack on Israel and the subsequent Israeli bombardment of Gaza have killed thousands of civilians.
llm: Over the past few weeks, I've been asked by colleagues and friends if my 6th grade social studies class was talking about what is going on in Gaza.

My response has been a resounding no for three reasons: 1) We don't have time to go into depth about every current event; 2) It's too complicated of an issue to teach well without being offensive or misleading; and 3) What would I gain from doing so?

human: President Biden headed home on Wednesday after a wartime trip to Israel, where he forcefully vowed that the United States would stand fast with Israel in its war against Hamas and unveiled a newly brokered deal to allow humanitarian aid into Gaza from Egypt.
llm: President Biden headed to a local military base, where he was briefed by the general in charge.
"At 0800 hours, we launched an attack on the enemy’s airbase," said the general.
"One hour later, the enemy deployed its first wave of fighter planes.
I gave the order for our planes --"

human: Standing before a gray backdrop decorated with Hamas logos and emblems of a gunman that commemorate the bloody Oct. 7 attack on Israel, Osama Hamdan, the organization’s representative in Lebanon, professed no concern about his Palestinian faction being dislodged from Gaza.
llm: Standing before a group of Israeli generals last week, the former head of Mossad, Meir Dagan, declared that the Israeli government was making a mistake by putting so much emphasis on its military campaign against the militants in Gaza.

human: Warner Bros. Discovery has joined the ranks of companies expressing interest in a possible merger with Paramount, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions.
llm: Warner Bros. Discovery Inc., the second-largest U.S. cable operator, is in talks with Viacom Inc.'s Paramount Communications Inc. about a merger that would create a $20 billion entertainment giant, according to sources familiar with the situation.

human: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Michael Podhorzer.
Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
llm: Every Tuesday and Thursday, I’m going to be posting transcripts of my interviews with policy experts.
Today, it’s the first part of an interview with Michael Podhorzer, who directs the AFL-CIO’s Department for Economic and Social Policy.

He is one of the country’s leading experts on labor economics and unionization, and has written extensively about the role unions play in the economy and their impact on wages and economic inequality.

human: When Ana Kirova first heard the idea that she should become chief executive of Feeld, the dating app, she was “terrified.”
llm: When Ana Kirova and her husband, Ravi, went to a polyamory conference in 2014, they didn't think they were poly.
But after meeting other poly people and learning more about it, they realized that the open relationship they had been practicing was actually polyamorous.

human: Let’s consider a counterfactual.
In the autumn of 2016, with American liberalism reeling from the election of Donald Trump, a shattered Hillary Clinton embraces the effort to pin all the blame on Vladimir Putin.
llm: Let’s consider a hypothetical situation: Imagine that Donald Trump was not president, but instead was the leader of an extremist right-wing political movement that had a realistic shot at winning national elections.
How would Democrats respond?
Would they try to win over some of his supporters by offering more conservative policies?
Or would they double down on progressive ideas like Medicare for All and a Green New Deal?

human: It is early April, in the evening.
I’m walking through Times Square on my way to a birthday dinner at a restaurant I’ve never been to.
As I weave through the souvenir stands, I’m trying to concentrate on the instructions on my phone screen.
llm: It is early September, and a man's mind turns to football.
I am not talking about the NFL or college ball.
I mean high school football.
This is the time of year when the weather begins to cool down and there is a crispness in the air on Friday nights.
It means that the local stadium will be packed with fans dressed in red and white (or blue and gold) cheering for their team.
I can smell the hot dogs and hamburgers cooking, and hear the marching band practicing.
Yes, it is football season again.
The first game of the season is tomorrow night.

human: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Sharon Brous.
Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
llm: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein brings you far-ranging conversations with the smartest people in politics.
Subscribe to The Ezra Klein Show on Apple Podcasts, Stitcher or wherever you get your podcasts.

human: UP A BUCKLING flight of stairs on Murray Street in Lower Manhattan, the dusty workshop of CTL Electronics is crammed with once-novel relics: cathode-ray tube (CRT) televisions, three-beam projectors and laserdisc players from the previous century.

Hundreds of outdated monitors are arranged beside money trees and waving maneki neko cats, an installation in a kind of mini-museum run by CTL’s proprietor, Chi-Tien Lui, who has worked as a TV and radio repairman since immigrating from Taiwan in 1961.

At CTL, which he opened in 1968, Lui initially sold closed-circuit TV systems and video equipment, but for the past couple of decades, his business has had a unique focus: repairing video artworks that, since the onset of the digital age, are increasingly likely to malfunction and decay.
llm: UP A BUCKLING, FLAMING BRIDGE OF LIGHT: NICK REYNOLDS
AT THE CENTER FOR CONTEMPORARY ART AND CULTURAL COMMUNICATIONS

human: A Florida venue canceled an event on Saturday featuring Marjorie Taylor Greene, the far-right Georgia congresswoman and acolyte of Donald J. Trump, after materials promoting the event advertised it, in part, as an occasion marking the third anniversary of the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol.
llm: A Florida venue that is hosting an event for Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-Fla.) has faced backlash over the congresswoman's past remarks about gun control and her support of President Donald Trump, The Tampa Bay Times reports.

human: Mati, the employee at the center of the hushed and absorbing documentary “A Still Small Voice,” reports for duty at an ordinary-looking office.
There are cubicles, roller chairs, a water cooler and flat lighting that the director, Luke Lorentzen, would never dishonor by gussying up with a lamp.

These are the chaplains’ quarters at The Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan, and Mati and her colleagues are here to comfort the dying and the families of the dead — to transform this 1,134-bed institution into a sacred space.
They are Olympian empaths and they are exhausted.
llm: Mati, the employee of a Jerusalem coffee shop who spends her free time volunteering at a crisis hotline for women, is the main character in a new Israeli film that had its world premiere last month at the Toronto International Film Festival.

human: John F. Kelly, the onetime chief of staff to former President Donald J. Trump, confirmed on Monday some of Mr. Trump’s most startling comments about service members and veterans, reeling them off in a statement in which he said his onetime boss had “contempt for our democratic institutions, our Constitution and the rule of law.”
llm: John F. Kelly, President Donald J. Trump's former chief of staff, confirmed that the president once described U.S. veterans as "drug dealers and thieves," The Washington Examiner reported on Thursday.
Kelly had previously denied making these remarks to The Los Angeles Times.

human: Through the long, busy months of autumn, the calls kept coming in: Mothers losing grip of their children while trying to cross the treacherous waters of the Rio Grande.
Pregnant women getting caught in barbed wire.
Bodies washing up on shore.
llm: Through the long, hot summer of 2014, McAllen and surrounding communities have been flooded with unaccompanied minors from Central America.
The influx has strained resources at every turn, but perhaps nowhere more than for EMS workers who are responding to calls for service at an alarming rate.

human: On a recent afternoon, in a ground-floor retail unit in one of London’s many vacant office buildings, a pair of flame-red platform heel boots with what looked like tentacles growing out of them and a multimedia sculpture of a coffin-like object circled by plastic shark fins were on show.
llm: On a recent afternoon, the artist Jonas Lund stood in front of an empty storefront on Canal Street and stared at his reflection in its grimy glass windows.
He was looking for inspiration.

human: Tom Hanks and Gayle King, a co-host of “CBS Mornings,” have separately warned their followers on social media that videos using artificial intelligence likenesses of them were being used for fraudulent advertisements.
llm: Tom Hanks and Hollywood have a message for you: Steer clear of any dental clinics that claim to use an artificial intelligence version of the actor in their advertising campaigns.

The warning comes after a Chinese company used an image of Hanks in one of its ads without his permission, with the actor’s name printed alongside a lineup of famous people who it says have visited its dental clinic over the years.

“Mr. Hanks is obviously very disturbed by this situation, as well as the potential ramifications of this technology being used and seen by other notable celebrities,” said Matthew Grossman, chief operating officer at Buzz, Mr. Hanks’s Los Angeles-based agency.
“We are exploring legal action against the company.”

human: A Nevada grand jury indicted top leaders of the state’s Republican Party on charges of forging and submitting fraudulent documents in the fake elector scheme to overturn Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in the 2020 presidential election, the state’s attorney general announced on Wednesday.
llm: A Nevada grand jury has indicted four Republican Party leaders on charges that they conspired to break the law by trying to get a slate of fake presidential electors on the ballot in the state.

human: At an emotional evening news conference immediately after he was removed as speaker of the House, Representative Kevin McCarthy gave an inconclusive answer about whether he would remain in Congress.
llm: At an emotional press conference in the Capitol on Thursday afternoon, Kevin McCarthy announced he was dropping out of the race for speaker of the House.
He was set to replace John Boehner when Boehner resigned at the end of October, but said that he didn't feel he could get the 218 votes needed from his colleagues to win the election.
“I think I shocked some of you, huh?”
McCarthy joked as he took questions from reporters.
It wasn’t a joke.
The move is a stunning political development, one that leaves Republicans without a clear path forward and Democrats giddy with schadenfreude.

human: There were times, a year ago, in Iceland, on a glacier, in the dark, in temperatures well below freezing, when Issa López thought to herself: “Who wrote this?
What is wrong with this person?”
López, the showrunner and director of Season 4 of the HBO anthology series “True Detective,” had only herself to blame.
llm: There were times, watching the first two episodes of Season 3 of “True Detective,” that I thought I was watching a new film by Michael Mann.

This is not to say that the show is as good as Mr. Mann’s best work (though it comes close), but rather that there are certain visual and dramatic strategies — especially in the use of digital photography for interior scenes and the way the story is structured around three main characters — that have been lifted from his playbook.

human: In 1996, in a phrase that’s stuck with me, Richard John Neuhaus described the Holocaust as “our only culturally available icon of absolute evil.”
The line appeared in a critical review of Daniel Jonah Goldhagen’s best-selling and furor-starting book, “Hitler’s Willing Executioners,” which was itself an example of Neuhaus’s point in action.

In the post-Cold War landscape, with American power seemingly occupying the stage of history by itself, the memory of Nazi Germany’s genocide came to play a special cultural role in the self-understanding of the liberal West: We might not agree on the highest good, but we knew the highest evil, and arguments about its memory and meaning and implications were absolutely central to politics and culture.
llm: In 1996, in an interview with the New York Times, Hamas's spiritual leader Sheikh Ahmed Yassin was asked about his views on the Holocaust.
He replied that it had never occurred.
When pressed for clarification he said: "I am familiar with Jewish history over the last 20 years, but not with the earlier period."

human: Days of intense negotiations enabled the Biden administration to avoid casting a veto at the United Nations Security Council in defense of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza.
llm: Days of intense shuttle diplomacy by Secretary of State John Kerry yielded a brief seven-hour cease-fire between Israel and Hamas in Gaza last weekend that was supposed to be extended by an additional 24 hours but wasn’t.
After that, with the conflict now nearly a month old, Mr. Kerry flew back to Washington with no progress toward ending it.

human: The Washington Ballet announced on Tuesday that Edwaard Liang would be its next artistic director, starting immediately.

human: The Los Angeles Times said on Tuesday that it would lay off about 115 journalists, slashing its newsroom by more than 20 percent after a tumultuous few weeks that saw top editors depart and workers walk off the job.
llm: The Los Angeles Times is planning to cut the number of newsroom staffers by more than a fifth.

human: Golf is a sport where certain years stand out above others, and 2023 may prove to be one of those years.
It’s a heady list.
llm: Golf is a game of inches.
So, too, it seems are golf mergers and acquisitions.
A little more than six years ago, in the early days of this blog, I wrote about the trend towards consolidation in the industry (see "M&A Activity Picks Up Among Golf Courses").
Now, here we are at the end of another year -- and another decade -- with a big merger deal once again leading the way in terms of M&A activity among golf course operators.

human: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has accused Russia of wanting to precipitate conflict in the Middle East to undermine international support for Ukraine, in comments that reflect concern that the war between Israel and the militant group Hamas could distract attention from Kyiv’s fight.
llm: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine says that the current war in Gaza has served to distract attention from Russia's actions against Ukraine.

human: Tasneem Ismael Ahel’s audio messages typically arrive all at once.
llm: Tasneem Ismael Ahel’s “My Life as a Refugee” is an audio diary that records the daily life of a refugee.

human: The next United Nations climate change summit appears set to take place in Azerbaijan, a spokesman for the country said Saturday, resolving a bitter, monthslong political standoff over which nation should host the talks in 2024.
llm: The next United Nations Climate Change Conference (COP-18) will be held in Doha, Qatar from November 26 through December 7, 2012.
This year’s conference is being referred to as the “CMP8” because it is the eighth meeting of the parties to the Kyoto Protocol.
The 1997 Kyoto Protocol is an international treaty that requires industrialized nations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and help developing countries adapt to the impacts of climate change.
The first commitment period of this protocol expires at the end of 2012.
At COP-18, countries are expected to negotiate a new agreement on emissions reductions after 2012, with particular attention being paid

human: Play a simplified version of the bonus round, then read on for strategy advice, whether you’re a future contestant or just watching at home.

human: Few challenges are as complex in Madrid as finding a cat.
Not the animal, but a gato — someone who was born in Madrid, whose parents and grandparents were born in Madrid.

Nobody in Madrid was born here: You’ll seldom be asked where you are from, because the assumption is that you’re from somewhere else, although suspicion — and prejudice — can come up when you have a certain accent or skin color.
llm: Few challenges are as daunting to a newcomer as figuring out how to get around in an unfamiliar city.
The Metro system is the most efficient way of getting from one place to another, but sometimes it's not that easy to figure out which line to take and where you need to get off.
There are several apps for smartphones that can help with this, but my preferred method is much more old-fashioned: I use the street map in the back of the Madrid section of Lonely Planet guidebooks.

human: Shortly after Donald Trump was elected in 2016, I spoke to a friend in Istanbul about my boundless horror, and while I can’t remember the exact words she said in response, they amounted to “Welcome to my world.”
I told her about all the protests breaking out, and she gently warned me not to get my hopes up.
She’d also demonstrated against Turkey’s authoritarian president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, she said, but eventually those protests had died out, and ours would too.
llm: Shortly after Donald Trump was elected president, the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU) received so many donations—more than $24 million online—that it had to delay processing them.
The reason?
The ACLU promised to be a thorn in the side of President-elect Trump if he tried to carry out some of his more controversial campaign promises once he took office.

human: More than 100,000 demonstrators in Paris and cities across France took to the streets on Sunday to show their solidarity with the country’s Jews and to deplore antisemitic acts that have multiplied across the nation since Hamas’s attack on Israel on Oct. 7.
llm: More than 100,000 people have marched in cities across France to condemn a recent spate of antisemitic attacks that culminated on Tuesday with vandals daubing swastikas and anti-Jewish slogans on around 90 graves in a Jewish cemetery.
The demonstrations come after a week of shock and soul searching in France over the plight of its Jewish community following a series of racist acts.
President Emmanuel Macron attended a rally against antisemitism organised by prominent members of the Jewish community including the chief rabbi Haim Korsia in Paris on Wednesday evening.
“What happened in Quatzenheim is intolerable,” Mr Macron said at the event, referring to an attack on a Jewish cemetery in eastern France where Naz

human: Lake City Army Ammunition Plant has made nearly all the rifle cartridges used by the U.S. military since it pulled out of Vietnam.
In recent years, it has also pumped billions of rounds of military-grade ammunition into the commercial market.
llm: Lake City Army Ammunition Plant is a government-owned, contractor-operated (GOCO) facility in Independence, Missouri, which was established by Remington Arms in 1941 to manufacture and test small caliber ammunition for the U.S. Army.
The plant has remained in continuous operation except for one 5-year period ending in 1985.
During this time of nonproduction for the Army, the plant supported Remington's commercial ammunition business.
Today the plant represents a $1 billion investment and can produce up to 1.4 billion rounds of ammunition annually.

human: When Mary Lou Retton, the decorated Olympic gymnast, accrued medical debt from a lengthy hospital stay, her family did what countless Americans have done before them: turned to crowdfunding to cover the bills.
llm: When Mary Lou Retton needed surgery on her knees, she turned to a crowdfunding website to pay for it.
The Olympic gold medalist was one of more than 416,000 Americans who used GoFundMe to pay medical bills in 2015.

human: An article on Friday about Iran’s links to regional conflicts referred incorrectly to Iran’s nuclear program.
Iran has raised the prospect that it could develop nuclear weapons, maintaining that its nuclear program has only peaceful purposes, but it has not developed them.
llm: An article on Monday about the possibility of a Hillary Rodham Clinton candidacy for president in 2016 misstated her age at that time.
She would be 69 — not “approaching 73.”
(The error was repeated in an editorial on Tuesday.)

human: Joseph J. Esposito, who served longer than anyone else as the highest-ranking uniformed officer of the New York Police Department, and who oversaw the city’s response to emergencies, including the 2001 terrorist attack on the World Trade Center and the devastation of Hurricane Sandy, died on Jan. 8 in Mineola, N.Y., on Long Island.
He was 73.
llm: Joseph J. Esposito, the longest-serving New York City police commissioner in history, whose tenure was marked by a precipitous decline in crime and who oversaw the Police Department's response to the terrorist attack on Sept. 11, died on Sunday night in Manhattan.
He was 78. ...
Mr. Esposito, a son of Italian immigrants from Calabria, was born in Brooklyn on May 25, 1940.
He attended St. Francis College in Brooklyn, where he played basketball; graduated with a degree in sociology; and met his future wife, the former Carmela Puleo.
After graduation, Mr. Esposito began working for the Police Department as an auxiliary officer while studying criminal justice at John

human: The key to cutting emissions from cars and light trucks that are heating the planet could lie with the nation’s super drivers, the small percentage of American motorists who drive, on average, about 110 miles per day.
llm: The key to the rebate program is that it's an incentive for people who are already driving electric vehicles.

human: Thousands of faculty members at the nation’s largest four-year public university system are canceling classes and mounting rolling strikes this week as they demand higher pay and better benefits.
llm: Thousands of faculty members at California State University (CSU) campuses are on strike this week, after months of negotiations with CSU administrators over salaries and working conditions.

The California Faculty Association, which represents 25,000 professors, lecturers, librarians, counselors and coaches in the CSU system, has been unable to reach a deal with the university’s management since contract negotiations began more than a year ago.

human: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of violence.
llm: Warning: this episode is not for the faint of heart.
In 1982, a war broke out between Israel and Lebanon.
But this war was unlike any other before it.

This week on the podcast, we explore the secret history of Israel's illegal arms deals in the 1980s, and how this led to the first ever suicide bomb attacks against the United States that killed hundreds of US Marines in Beirut.

human: A Virginia fisherman who died in 2017 was responsible for the killings of three people in two separate cases in the southeastern part of the state that sat unsolved for more than 30 years, the police announced this week.
llm: A Virginia fisherman has been charged in the killing of a couple found buried on his property after a third set of human remains was discovered there last month and identified as one of two women who disappeared more than 30 years ago, police said Monday.

human: The British Library on Monday began restoring its online catalog, which holds details of books, journals and music scores, the first step in its recovery from a brazen cyberattack in October, the library said.
llm: The British Library is still recovering from a cyberattack that took down the library’s website and internal computer systems.
The attack occurred in late May but wasn’t publicly disclosed until early June, when the library reported it had been hit by ransomware.
The library was closed for three days as staff worked to restore services.

human: The mechanics of how chess players might cheat increasingly occupies the minds of professional chess players, academics who build models to catch cheating and top chess platforms.
llm: The mechanics of cheating have become so sophisticated that a new industry has sprung up around catching it.

The World Chess Federation, which oversees the game and holds international tournaments, hired security experts to root out players who may be getting help from computers or other people during games.

human: In Seattle, the debate consumed much of two City Council meetings.
In San Francisco, the line to speak stretched long all night under the City Hall dome.
The Oakland City Council spent four hours just on public comment.
llm: In Seattle, the city council voted unanimously last month to divest from Wells Fargo over its financing of private prison companies.

In Davis, California, the student senate at the University of California campus passed a resolution calling on the university system to withdraw investments in “corporations that profit off the occupation” — and is pushing for the full board of regents to vote on it.
And in Portland, Oregon, activists are pressuring the city council to pass a resolution to end investment in Caterpillar, Hewlett Packard, G4S and Motorola Solutions.

human: Less than a week after presenting his third collection as Ferragamo’s creative director in Milan this past September, Maximilian Davis was at ease.
The clothes — a luxurious combination of asymmetrical dresses and Italian tailoring — had been well received.
As he spoke, quietly but with confidence, he gestured gently with his hands, like a conductor keeping an unhurried tempo.
Born in Manchester, England, to Trinidadian and Jamaican parents, Davis, 28, the youngest of three children, spent his summers in Trinidad until the age of 13.
A passion for clothing ran in the family: His maternal grandmother taught him to sew when he was 6, his mother was a working model and his father studied fashion design.
llm: Less than a year ago, designer Kerby Jean-Raymond was working on Wall Street.
Now he's showing his line at New York Fashion Week.

human: Al-Shifa Hospital, the Gaza Strip’s largest medical complex, has been overwhelmed with wounded patients since Israel launched airstrikes in Gaza in retaliation to Hamas’s attack.
llm: Al-Shifa Hospital, the largest medical facility in Gaza, has been overwhelmed with patients wounded by Israeli attacks.
The hospital is short on supplies and staff, and is struggling to keep up with the increasing number of casualties.

human: As 2023 comes to an end, there is a growing sense of panic in Europe.

Since the Russian invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the European Union has been preoccupied with integrating the country — widely seen as a geopolitical necessity — and with the internal reform required to make that possible.
But over the course of this year, as the much-hyped Ukrainian counteroffensive stalled, tensions among member states have increased.
llm: As 2023 comes to a close, we see that the United States has become an even more divided country.
The middle class is almost gone, and the gap between rich and poor continues to grow wider and wider.
There are more people in prison than ever before, and more Americans on government assistance programs than ever before.
While a few wealthy enclaves flourish, most of the rest of the country is deeply suffering.
The divide between Republicans and Democrats grows deeper every single year, and it has gotten to the point where many Republicans and many Democrats absolutely hate one another.
Mexico has fallen apart economically and socially, and millions upon millions of illegal aliens continue to pour across the border with no end in sight.
Meanwhile, other nations such as China have risen to take America

human: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain rejected claims on Friday that he had lowered his country’s net-zero ambitions and pledged to meet targets in a more pragmatic way.
llm: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and his wife Akshata Murty.

human: Colorado’s top court ruled on Tuesday that former President Donald J. Trump is disqualified from holding office again because he engaged in insurrection with his actions leading up to the Jan. 6 storming of the Capitol, an explosive ruling that is likely to put the basic contours of the 2024 election in the hands of the U.S. Supreme Court.
llm: Colorado’s top court has ruled that President Trump is disqualified from appearing on the state’s ballot in 2020 because he failed to disclose his tax returns.

The unanimous ruling by the Colorado Supreme Court overturned a previous decision by a lower court that had blocked a proposed ballot measure requiring presidential and vice-presidential candidates to release five years of tax returns in order to appear on the state’s ballot.
If the initiative is approved by voters next year, it would be added to the state constitution.

human: On a recent afternoon in SoHo, Seth Weisser and Gerard Maione were checking in on their shop, What Goes Around Comes Around, a luxury vintage boutique on West Broadway that has long been a downtown destination for stylists and celebrities.
llm: On a recent Wednesday afternoon, Katy Perry and her entourage — stylist, makeup artist, two assistants, a bodyguard and a friend who appeared to be a personal trainer — arrived at Shareen.
They were looking for an outfit for an appearance on “Saturday Night Live.”
A red sequined number was suggested.
Ms. Perry tried it on in the store’s dressing room.
She looked in the mirror, twirled around and declared that she loved it.

human: The International Court of Justice, the United Nations’ highest judicial body, held two days of hearings this week in a case brought by South Africa accusing Israel of committing genocide against Palestinians in Gaza.
llm: The International Court of Justice, also known as the World Court, is located in The Hague, Netherlands.
It was established by the United Nations Charter in 1945 and began work in April 1946.
Its main functions are to settle legal disputes submitted to it by states and to provide advisory opinions on legal questions referred to it by authorized U.N. organs and specialized agencies.

human: These days, real estate imagery is often defined by staged hotel-lobby-style furniture and generic artwork, dramatic drone shots on unsettlingly perfect sunny days and a lack of human presence — almost never do you see any people or evidence that these homes have been lived in.
llm: These days, real estate is a matter of buying and selling.
But for 40 years it was also a matter of living for Lee Friedlander, who has photographed buildings, rooms and people in their environments all over America.
A new book, "Lee Friedlander: The Little Screens," with an introduction by Walker Evans (Fraenkel Gallery, $65), reproduces 173 of these images.

human: Accusations of plagiarism appear to be the newest weapon in the raging battle over the leadership and direction of elite universities.
llm: Accusations of plagiarism are a recurring theme in the life and work of Feng Shilan, a Chinese businesswoman who has emerged as a central figure in an effort to oust the president of Harvard University.

Ms. Feng is married to Zhang Honggang, a wealthy investor in China who last week publicly called on Harvard’s president, Lawrence Bacow, to resign after Mr. Zhang was banned from campus following accusations that he had sexually harassed a female student at a Harvard conference last year.

human: A law making it illegal to discredit Russia’s army has ensnared thousands of Russians for even mild acts or statements against the war.
llm: A law making it illegal to criticize Russia's military actions went into effect in May.
Since then, the Kremlin has been cracking down on its critics with renewed vigor and efficiency.

human: Outrage over a blast that killed hundreds of people at a Gaza City hospital set off protests across the Middle East and elsewhere.
President Biden backed Israel’s assertion that it had nothing to do with the explosion.
llm: Outrage over a U.S.-made bomb that hit the al-Shifa hospital in Gaza sparks protests across the world.

human: As Holly, the protagonist of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” approaches an imposing, deserted mansion tucked off a remote country road, she drives past a tree stump that’s “choked with poison ivy, a riot of scarlet leaves and white berries.”

Though she doesn’t know it yet, the tree that once stood there claimed the life of Eleanor Vance, the tragic lead from the novel’s antecedent text, Shirley Jackson’s wildly influential “The Haunting of Hill House.”
And so, a couple dozen pages into the book, Hand makes her first decisive mark on Jackson’s landscape, acknowledging her predecessor while making the house her own.
When Jackson left Hill House, the tree was still standing.
Hand is here to chop it down.
llm: As Holly, the youngest Crain child in Netflix’s The Haunting of Hill House (now streaming), Paxton Singleton has a pivotal role: He not only plays a key part in the series’ present-day storyline but also serves as one of its many flashback narrators.

In EW’s exclusive first look at his audition tape for the series, above, Singleton’s take on Holly is chilling, capturing both the boy’s sweetness and his connection with the house that haunts his family.

human: Playing Prince Harry in the final season of Netflix’s “The Crown,” Luther Ford said he felt like royalty.
llm: Playing Prince Harry, the Royal Black Sheep https://t.co/qJg409lwZr pic.twitter.com/WaQdM7PcYD

human: American and Israeli officials said their intelligence showed that the deadly blast at a Gaza hospital on Tuesday was caused by an armed Palestinian group, rebutting Palestinian claims that an Israeli strike caused the explosion.
llm: American and Israeli intelligence officials say that evidence gathered after the deadly bombing of an American-Palestinian medical center in Gaza City this week indicates that a small radical group, with possible ties to Al Qaeda, was responsible for the blast.

human: “2024 is the final battle,” Donald Trump has said.
llm: “2024 is the next shot”: GOP Establishment Prepares for War with Trump

human: For years, a Native American tribe from the picturesque East End of Long Island has fought bitterly for formal state recognition, a designation that was stripped away more than a century ago by court decisions that are now widely considered racist.
llm: For years, a group of about 1,200 people who claim to be descendants of the Montaukett Indians have been trying to get New York State recognition as an Indian tribe.
On Thursday, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vetoed a bill that would have granted them that status — the fifth time in recent years that their quest has been denied by a governor.

human: The U.S. military program that provides leadership and civic values training for students in thousands of high schools across the country will have more oversight thanks to new legislation approved by Congress this week.
The changes came after complaints of sexual abuse by instructors and instances of schools requiring students to enroll in the Junior Reserve Officers’ Training Corps, also known as J.R.O.T.C.
llm: The U.S. military's Junior Reserve Officers Training Corps (J.R.O.T.C.) program is the nation's largest and most popular high school elective, with more than 314,000 students enrolled in 2006-7.
According to the American Civil Liberties Union, that number could soon increase exponentially as a result of a little known provision buried deep within the No Child Left Behind Act (NCLB).

The ACLU alleges that Section 9528, which was added to the law during House-Senate conference negotiations in late 2001, requires all public schools receiving federal funding to provide equal access to J.R.O.T.C. cadets.

human: In the ancient city of Exeter, three women were hanged for practicing witchcraft in the late 17th century, the last of such executions in England.

Now, merely a short walk from where the hangings occurred, the University of Exeter will offer a postgraduate degree in magic and occult science, which the school says is the first of its kind at a British university.
llm: In the ancient world, the occult was often seen as a science.
Some of the greatest minds in human history were drawn to its study and practice.

In 1904, the Hermetic Order of the Golden Dawn (a society that claimed several prominent figures as members, including William Butler Yeats and Winston Churchill) created the Horos mysticorum, an educational program that included classes in astrology, alchemy, tarot reading, geomancy, clairvoyance, divination and other esoteric disciplines.
The program culminated with a master’s degree in the occult arts.

human: Ever since Israel withdrew its soldiers and settlers from Gaza in 2005, critics have accused it of blockading and immiserating the territory — turning it, as they say, into an open-air prison.
llm: Ever since Israel withdrew from the Gaza Strip in 2005, Hamas has been preparing for a war with Israel.
It has smuggled into the strip more than 13,000 rockets and missiles, some of which can reach Tel Aviv, Jerusalem, Haifa, Beersheba and Ashkelon.
It has also built dozens of attack tunnels along the border between the Gaza Strip and Israel.

human: Michael Cunningham’s new novel, “Day,” visits a family on April 5 in 2019, 2020 and 2021 — before, during and after the onset of the Covid-19 pandemic, which shadows the book although the words “Covid” and “pandemic” never appear.
llm: Michael Cunningham’s new novel “The Snow Queen” is about a pandemic.
It takes place in New York City and begins with two brothers, Barrett and Tyler Meeks, at their mother’s deathbed.
Barrett, the older brother, is gay; Tyler is straight but he has an addiction to methamphetamines.
The brothers are as different from one another as two siblings can be, but they share a love for Beth, who is married to Barrett.
Soon after the novel opens, a mysterious virus appears that will cause everyone in the world to question his or her own mortality.

human: The guys in Bad Dog, a folkie duo from Washington, D.C., weren’t hoping to get rich off the album they recorded this summer.
David Post and Craig Blackwell have been devoted amateurs for decades, and they’re long past dreams of tours and limos.
Mostly they wanted a CD to give away at a house party in December.
llm: The guys in the band are now suing Spotify for $200 million, saying that they never gave permission to the company to stream their songs.
“Spotify brazenly disregards United States Copyright law and has committed willful, ongoing copyright infringement,” the complaint reads.

human: The United States-led airstrikes on Thursday and Friday against sites in Yemen controlled by the Houthi militia damaged or destroyed about 90 percent of the targets struck, but the group retained about three-quarters of its ability to fire missiles and drones at ships transiting the Red Sea, two U.S. officials said on Saturday.
llm: The United States-led military campaign in Yemen has not blunted the offensive capabilities of Houthi rebels, according to a new report by an American think tank.

human: David Ferry, a poet and translator whose direct, emotionally resonant work plumbing the chasms between the knowable and the unknowable won him broad praise and honors late in his career, including the National Book Award when he was 86, died on Sunday in Lexington, Mass.
He was 99.
llm: David Ferry, a poet and translator who was acclaimed for his elegant renderings of Horace, Virgil, the Roman lyric poet Catullus and other classical authors, died on Sept. 18 in Brookline, Mass.
He was 99.

human: Yes, we know, you get to Carnegie Hall with “practice, practice.”
And once you get there, starting Saturday for dinner and Monday for breakfast, lunch and coffee, you can have something to eat.

On Monday, the new Weill Café, occupying the stately, cream-colored room, recently renovated with gold and burgundy accents, that has long been serving snacks and drinks during intermissions, will be open to the public from 10 a.m. to 3 p.m., Mondays through Fridays.
Breakfast items, coffee and tea, soups, salads, quiches, sandwiches and pastries will be available, and there is a bar.
It will have a street entrance, so a concert ticket is not required.
That’s not the case when it comes to preconcert dining however.
Those with tickets to select performances in the Stern Auditorium can book tables starting at 6 p.m. for a three-course dinner, $139 including unlimited beverages, tax and service.

An initial menu by the executive chef, Derek Prough, working for Constellation Culinary Group, which is running the cafe, includes burrata with vegetables, citrus and beet carpaccio with shrimp, seared branzino, glazed short rib, roasted acorn squash tower, and dessert bites like chocolate lava cakes and apple-spice Bundt cakes.
The cafe area will be open to concertgoers during intermissions.
(Opens Jan. 20, 22)
llm: Yes, we know, the tickets are expensive.
But here is an insider secret: You can get into Weill Recital Hall without buying a ticket.
The downstairs café (the Café) is open to the public during concerts and intermissions, and you can come in just to listen to the music.
Of course, it’s much better if you do buy a ticket—you get a seat on the main floor of the hall, or you can sit up in the balcony where there’s more space and a better view.

human: As Democrats amplify their concerns about President Biden’s status with Black voters, South Carolina has emerged as a proving ground for his campaign: one where he can test his message to a predominantly Black electorate and use it as a largely ceremonial launchpad for his re-election.
llm: As Democrats amplify their focus on the black voters who are critical to their success in 2020, two presidential candidates will be in South Carolina this weekend to test messages focused squarely on African Americans.

human: The Russian ruble briefly weakened to a symbolically important exchange rate of 100 to the dollar on Tuesday for the first time since mid-August, when worries about wartime shocks to the economy led the central bank to call an emergency meeting at which it sharply raised interest rates to 12 percent.
llm: The Russian ruble briefly weakened to 100 against the U.S. dollar on the Moscow Exchange on Monday, before recovering to 98.27 against the greenback at 3:46 p.m., according to the exchange's data.

human: Democrats won decisive victories in major races across the country on Tuesday evening, overcoming the downward pull of an unpopular president, lingering inflation and growing global unrest by relying on abortion, the issue that has emerged as their fail-safe since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade last year.
llm: Democrats won decisive victories in Tuesday's election by campaigning on a boldly pro-choice platform.
In Virginia, Democrat Ralph Northam defeated Republican Ed Gillespie to become the state’s next governor.
The contest was widely seen as an early referendum on Donald Trump’s presidency ahead of the 2018 midterm elections.
We speak with Jessica Mason Pieklo, senior legal analyst at Rewire, about how the race shows that Democrats can win big when they embrace abortion rights.

human: Voters in New Hampshire received robocall messages over the weekend in a voice that was most likely artificially generated to impersonate President Biden’s, urging them not to vote in Tuesday’s primary election, according to the state attorney general’s office.
llm: Voters in New Hampshire, a state that holds an early primary election every four years, are being harassed by robocallers who impersonate Joe Biden, the former vice president and current Democratic presidential candidate.
On Saturday, Biden called for the Federal Communications Commission (FCC) to investigate these calls.

human: Polls in states with major elections will close on Tuesday across a three-hour period nationwide, beginning at 6 p.m. Eastern time in Kentucky and ending at 9 p.m. Eastern time in Colorado, New York and parts of Texas.
llm: Polls in states that are still on standard time will close an hour earlier than polls in states that have already switched to daylight saving time.
The latter group includes Arizona, Hawaii and American Samoa (the only U.S. territory that does not observe DST).

human: Visits to the International Space Station are valuable, and would-be astronauts and their countries can wait a long time for the opportunity.
In addition to wealthy adventurers, Axiom Space is making it possible for people to make the trip from countries that have seldom or never had astronauts aboard the orbital outpost.

The three on the Ax-3 flight are: Alper Gezeravcı, who will be the first Turkish astronaut; Marcus Wandt, a European Space Agency astronaut from Sweden; and Walter Villadei, an Italian Air Force pilot who previously flew to the edge of space on a Virgin Galactic rocket plane.
A launch on Wednesday was postponed to Thursday.
llm: Visits to the ISS by private individuals have been increasing in recent years.
Dennis Tito was the first space tourist back in 2001.
In 2009, Cirque du Soleil founder Guy Laliberte spent nine days at the station as part of his 'Poetic Social Mission'.
He became the seventh space tourist.
In November 2009 Richard Garriott de Cayeux, the son of NASA astronaut Owen K. Garriott, followed him, becoming the eighth person to visit the ISS.
The ninth space tourist is Charles Simonyi, who visited the ISS twice.
He first flew there aboard Soyuz TMA-10 on April 7, 2007 and returned

human: You don’t need Halloween to justify reading scary books, any more than you need sand to justify reading a beach novel.
But the holiday does give editors here a handy excuse to talk about some of their favorite spooky reads.
On this week’s episode, the host Gilbert Cruz talks with his colleagues Tina Jordan and Sadie Stein about the enduring appeal of ghost stories, Gothic novels and the horror genre as a whole.
llm: You don’t need to be afraid of the dark, but you do have to watch out for ghosts.
In this spooky collection of stories, you'll meet a ghost who can't stop talking and a girl whose dreams come true in unexpected ways.
You'll also read about an invisible friend who plays tricks on his family, a boy who can't wait to grow up, and a group of teenagers who encounter supernatural creatures.
So turn off the lights, pull up the covers, and get ready to read!

human: Do you have pets, or have you ever had one?
Would you like to have one?
llm: Do you have a dog?
Have you ever thought that your dog would live longer, but it is dying of old age?
If you had the chance to make your pet live longer than its natural lifespan, would you take it?
The answer for me is no.
I think this could be one of the worst things you can do to a dog.
Dogs are not like humans in many ways, and they don’t get sick as easily or as often.
They also die of old age very often.
But sometimes they do get cancer and other life-threatening diseases.
That is when it is time for the owner to decide what to do with their dog.
In my opinion, there are several reasons why dogs shouldn’t live any longer than their natural lifespans.
Firstly, dogs might suffer from

human: Butter, chocolate, sugar, eggs, vanilla, cocoa, salt.
Those ingredients make up Vaughn Vreeland’s new chocolate chess pie (above), a veritable litany of all the baking stuffs we want when the weather turns cold and the yule log turns warm.

Made with a store-bought pie crust (or a half-recipe of this foolproof pie dough), it’s the perfect move for a gathering where some people want pie, some want chocolate and everyone wants something sweet.
llm: Butter, chocolate, sugar, eggs: There’s no way to go wrong with this Southern classic.

human: Leesburg Animal Park in Northern Virginia has seen strong business at its Pumpkin Village festival this autumn.
Even with rainy weekends and a jump in admission prices, families have been coming out to visit the petting zoo, ride on giant slides and zigzag through a hay-bale maze.
llm: Leesburg Animal Park in Virginia is a family-run business.
It has two full-time employees and eight seasonal ones, according to its website.
But that's not enough staff for the zoo to operate every day.
So it opened only on weekends last year, instead of daily from March through October as in previous years.

human: As Israel called for Gazans to leave the north of the besieged enclave, hospitals in Gaza City said they had no way to evacuate thousands of sick and injured patients and that there were not enough hospitals to treat them in the south.
llm: As Israel called on Gazans to evacuate their homes, a Palestinian man stands on the rubble of his house after it was destroyed in an Israeli strike on Rafah.

human: The president paid tribute to the 18 people killed in shootings at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine.
llm: The president paid tribute to the victims of the mass shooting in Orlando.

human: In Cairo and at the U.N., talks about a possible truce between Israel and Hamas over the war in the Gaza Strip are making slow progress, as negotiators struggled to come up with plans for pausing the fighting, freeing hostages and speeding up help for Gazans.
llm: In Cairo and elsewhere in Egypt, the streets were filled with protesters.
In Alexandria, an angry crowd stormed a police station, forcing several officers to flee by climbing over a back wall.
In Suez, east of Cairo on the Red Sea coast, protesters set fire to a government building.

human: After drifting steadily away from its source of inspiration — Joel and Ethan Coen’s 1996 neo-noir thriller about the bloody unraveling of a criminal scheme in Minnesota and North Dakota — “Fargo” appears to be creeping back.
llm: After drifting steadily further away from its source material over the past four seasons, “Fargo” has finally returned to where it began.
The new season opens in March of 2006, on a snowy night in East Berlin, North Dakota, with the same kind of murder that kicked off the show’s pilot back in 2014:
A man named Rye Gerhardt (Kellan Lutz) is driving home after getting into a bar fight, when he’s stopped by an officer who doesn’t like his attitude and shoots him dead for no apparent reason.

human: Inflation in the eurozone fell to a new two-year low in November, dropping much faster than expected as a result of high interest rates and efforts by European countries to ease prices for energy and food, setting the stage for the European Central Bank to hold interest rates steady at its next meeting.
llm: Inflation in the euro area fell faster than expected to a three-year low of 0.3% in September, as energy prices plunged and economic weakness kept a lid on consumer demand.
The decline will likely increase pressure on the European Central Bank to expand its stimulus efforts to prevent inflation from falling further below the ECB’s target rate of just under 2%.
Eurostat said Friday that the annual rate of inflation across the currency bloc dropped from 0.4% in August.
That is the lowest level since October 2009 when it was also 0.3%.
Consumer prices rose 0.7% on month in September after increasing by the same amount in August.
Analysts had forecast an annual inflation rate of 0.5% in September and

human: “If my regiment could see five minutes of what I saw today, there would be a revolution.”
llm: “If my regiment had known I was planning to defect with that plane, they would have torn me apart,” said Victor Belenko.
