human: A young Palestinian man from East Jerusalem, Soheib Muhammad Abu Amar, is missing and believed to have been taken hostage by Hamas and ferried into Gaza, his family said.
llm: A young Palestinian woman, 20-year-old Aya Khatib from Jenin, told Ynet that she and her friends had tried to go to the event.
She said they were stopped by Hamas police forces at a checkpoint on the way.

human: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including a review of the Showtime series "The Curse."
llm: A selection of things to do this weekend in Chicago, including the start of Lollapalooza and a beer-centric festival.

human: The year-end holiday travel season is here, and if you’re skipping the airport and hitting the highway for your family gatherings, both Google Maps and Apple’s Maps have apps that can help save you time and money.

Sure, online map navigation has been around for years, but if you haven’t used the apps for the long haul lately, both companies have recently improved their tools for modern road-trip concerns — like finding electric-vehicle charging stations or not getting lost in low-signal country.
Here’s an overview.
llm: The year-end holiday season is a time of reflection, gratitude and hope.
It’s also one of the busiest travel seasons of the year.
According to AAA, more than 103 million Americans are expected to travel during this year’s holiday season – the most since 2005.

In fact, the National Safety Council estimates that over 430 people could be killed on our roads in December alone as a result of car crashes caused by drunk driving, speeding, texting or other dangerous behaviors.

That’s why we’re working hard to help make it easier for you to get around town with Google Maps, whether you’re visiting family and friends across the country, or just heading out for last minute shopping closer to home.

human: After Russia invaded Ukraine in 2022, Germany went through a period of uncomfortable soul-searching about the close ties that some of its political and business leaders had to Moscow.
llm: After Russia invaded Crimea in 2014, the German journalist and commentator Jürgen Elsässer took a strong line against Western governments’ efforts to isolate Moscow.
“The West is guilty,” he wrote in the right-wing Swiss magazine Compact.
“Putin did not start this war.”

human: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced on Sunday night that he has chosen Laphonza Butler, the president of Emily’s List and a former labor leader, to fill the vacancy left in the Senate by the death of Dianne Feinstein.

This paper examines the performance of catechisms in a Goan community in Nairobi as a way of understanding how migrants negotiate their belonging within and outside of Kenya through religious practices.
Through an ethnographic study of the catechism, I will explore how Goans make sense of their place in Kenyan society through a complex negotiation of religion, ethnicity and nationality.
In particular, I will show how the catechism enables Goans to re-imagine themselves as a religiously unified group with deep roots in

human: For six months, the disappearance of $17.2 million in gold bars and cash from a warehouse at Toronto Pearson International Airport has remained a mystery.

human: If Donald Trump is the Republican nominee for president in 2024, it’s now clear he will likely still have criminal indictments hanging over his head on Election Day.

human: Dorothy Hoffner, born in 1918, had survived both the Spanish flu and Covid pandemics, as well as her first skydiving attempt at age 100.

human: For over a year, we’ve been rooting through jazz history five minutes at a time.

Now let’s turn our attention to a vocalist who epitomized — but couldn’t be contained by — jazz: Sarah Vaughan, “The Divine One,” owner of perhaps the most impressive vocal instrument in recorded history.
llm: For over a year I’ve been writing about jazz musicians, and for the past few months, I’ve been especially focused on women.
This week marks the 26th anniversary of Ella Fitzgerald’s death, so to commemorate it, I wanted to talk about one of her contemporaries: Sarah Lois Vaughan, better known as Sassy or The Divine One.
Her life was almost as storied as her voice.

human: Certain kinds of surprises are de rigueur in television.

Television writers do it all the time.
llm: Certain kinds of people get caught up in the curse of the law.
It is a curse for those who seek to be justified by it.
It is a blessing for those who have fled to Christ and found refuge under his blood.
The law was given to lead us to Christ, not to make us righteous.
The law cannot justify because it only reveals sin but cannot remove it.
Only Christ can do that.
When you see your sin, run to Jesus.
He is the one who takes away the sins of the world.

human: How do you sift through Mexico City’s roughly 57,000 places to eat — more than twice as many as there are in New York City — and choose the most essential dishes?
“In a city like Mexico City, how do you narrow it down?
It’s insane.

The exercise is absurd to begin with,” says Gabriela Cámara, the chef and owner of Contramar and three other restaurants in the Mexican capital, at the outset of the video conversation I’d arranged to do just that: identify the specific meals or bites (or drinks) that best represent the metropolis’s formidable food scene right now.

Nonetheless, Cámara was up for the challenge, as were the four other panelists I’d convened, all of whom live in Mexico City either year-round or part time: Ana Dolores, the chef and owner of Esquina Común restaurant in the Condesa neighborhood; Anais Martinez, who founded the Curious Mexican, a street-food tour company, and recently opened Manada, an all-Mexican cocktail and natural wine bar in Narvarte; the food writer Alonso Ruvalcaba, the author of the guide “24 Horas de Comida en la Ciudad de México” (2018); and Carla Valdivia Nakatani, T Magazine’s art director, who splits her time between Manhattan and Mexico City, where she co-owns a boutique in Roma.

Before we met as a group, I’d asked each participant to nominate around 10 dishes, including a sweet and a drink, from 10 different spots, ranging from fine-dining restaurants to street carts and market stalls.

Then we spent two hours and several subsequent emails and phone calls debating our choices, trying to whittle down the 50-plus nominations to 25 in order to produce a list like those in the ongoing T 25 series devoted to food in Paris and in New York.
llm: How do you get from one place to another?
How did I get around Mexico City without knowing any Spanish, and without the help of Uber or Lyft?
In this video I go over how to use the public transportation system.
It's really easy!
The Metro is super cheap, safey, clean, and efficient.
It's also a great way to see how locals live as you travel between stops on the Metro.
You can find me on...

human: At least 40 percent of crop workers in the United States do not have legal immigration status.
Americans typically aren’t willing to do backbreaking work in the fields, farmers say.
llm: At least 40 percent of farm workers are over the age of 35.
That’s about double what it was in 2000, according to the latest U.S. Department of Labor statistics.
And the number of workers older than 65 has tripled since then.
These numbers reflect both the aging baby boomer population and increased immigration restrictions that have slowed the flow of young people from Mexico into the United States.
As a result, there is a growing demand for experienced workers, even as fewer Americans want to do this type of work.
This combination is keeping many older farm workers employed.

human: In the 1970s, soft-shell clams started mysteriously dying off in Maine and the Chesapeake Bay.

llm: In the 1970s, researchers in New Zealand were studying a bizarre cancer that was killing off abalone.
They discovered that the cancer had spread through seawater and had killed large numbers of other shellfish in the region as well.
The cancer has since been found to have infected many types of marine life worldwide, including sea urchins, mussels and lobsters.
A new study suggests it's been around for at least a century or two. ...

human: A few years after the Society for the Protection of New Hampshire Forests started a Christmas tree farm, Nigel Manley, who oversaw the operations, began noticing some interesting developments among the rows of fragrant balsam and Fraser firs lining the land.

human: The terms of the private loan were as generous as they were clear: With no money down, Justice Clarence Thomas could borrow more than a quarter of a million dollars from a wealthy friend to buy a 40-foot luxury motor coach, making annual interest-only payments for five years.

human: “The Sweet East,” a shape-shifting satire about modern American subcultures, is a curious — occasionally delightful — object.

Both are blank canvasses filled out by different kinds of American dreams.
Not the gooey, aspirational sort, but the delusional kind that makes you question humanity’s worth even though you can’t look away.
llm: “The Sweet East,” a new play by Stephen Metcalfe, is set in a time and place that are no longer with us.
It was the late 1960s, when the world was still ruled by men who wore suits to work and didn’t leave their wives for younger women.
It was also a time of relative innocence; one character describes it as “a sweet east wind that blew across America.”
That wind has now changed into something darker and more destructive — an ill wind that blows nobody any good.

human: A lot happened in the early 1990s:

llm: A lot happened in 1993.

The World Trade Center was bombed, Bill Clinton was inaugurated, the first World Trade Organization ministerial conference took place in Singapore, and the Maastricht Treaty established the European Union.
That year also saw the release of a few movies that would go on to become classics: Jurassic Park, Groundhog Day, The Fugitive, Mrs. Doubtfire, In the Line of Fire, and Schindler’s List.

llm: A leading presidential candidate’s campaign manager.
A billionaire tycoon with a gambling empire.
The former head of the country’s internal revenue service.
And a former spymaster.

human: When was the last time you listened to Donald Trump for longer than 30 seconds?
Longer than a clip sailing by in a tweet or a TikTok or packaged on the evening news?
Lovers and haters alike seem filled to the brim with information about this man, unable to take in any more or alter their view of him.
llm: When was the last time you read a book by someone who is a professional writer?
That’s not an easy question to answer.
For me, it was probably the summer of 2016 when I read The Secret History, by Donna Tartt.
That was the last time I remember being truly captivated and enthralled by a novel.
Since then, I have mostly been reading non-fiction books that are either about politics or economics.

human: The Israeli military warned on Friday that it was stepping up operations in the southern Gaza Strip, where hundreds of thousands of people had fled to safety, while hospital officials said Israel bombed an area in the south where it had ordered civilians to seek shelter.
llm: The Israeli military operation in Lebanon is being conducted, as we all know, with a great deal of force.
The civilian population is paying a very heavy price.
We hear reports that up to 40 percent of those killed are children under the age of 13.
That figure may or may not be accurate but it seems plausible given what we have seen on television and what we read in the newspapers.
And there is no doubt that this is a terrible tragedy for the people of Lebanon.

human: You need to put politics aside to shrink government budget deficits — or that’s the conventional wisdom, anyway.
Heidi Heitkamp disagrees.

Heitkamp, who served one term in the U.S. Senate as a Democrat from the red state North Dakota, argues that it’s impossible to cut deficits and restrain the growth of the national debt without politics.
llm: You need to ask why the U.S. budget deficit is so big?
And the answer is that it’s not because we are spending too much on public services.
The reason the U.S. has such a huge budget deficit is because the richest people in the country have been paying less taxes every year for decades, while they get more and more of the wealth.

human: When Indiana officials created a new industrial park to lure huge microchip firms to the state, they picked a nearly 10,000-acre site close to a booming metropolis, a major airport and a university research center.
llm: When Indiana officials announced a plan last fall to pipe millions of gallons of water from Lake Michigan to help cool the microchips that fuel the digital world, they were hoping to create jobs in the state.

human: Margaret Newcomb, 69, a retired French teacher, is desperately trying to protect her retirement savings by caring for her 82-year-old husband, who has severe dementia, at home in Seattle.
She used to fear his disease-induced paranoia, but now he’s so frail and confused that he wanders away with no idea of how to find his way home.
He gets lost so often that she attaches a tag to his shoelace with her phone number.
llm: Margaret Newcomb, 69, who has dementia and lives in an assisted-living facility, was one of the oldest residents at a group home in Fitchburg, Mass., where she received round-the-clock care.
But the costs were so high that her money ran out after three years, and she had to move this year into a nursing home paid for by Medicaid.

human: A volcano in southwestern Iceland, the country’s most populated region, began erupting Monday with lava fountains reaching high in the air and the glow lighting up the sky miles away in the center of the capital, Reykjavik.
llm: A volcano in southern Iceland erupted on Wednesday for the first time since 1823, forcing hundreds to evacuate and sending huge plumes of smoke and ash into the air.
The cloud of ash was heading toward Scotland, forecasters said, raising concerns about possible disruptions to aviation there.
In a statement, Iceland's Meteorological Office said it had raised its aviation warning level to red, meaning that an eruption is imminent or under way, with a risk of spewing ash.
It said the eruption was believed to have started around 9:30 p.m. local time at the Eyjafjallajokull glacier, which covers the caldera of a volcano that last erupted

human: The original 2004 movie “Mean Girls” contained something unusual, both then and now: a main character who was home-schooled.
But not that kind of home-schooled.
llm: The original 2004 film was a surprise hit, grossing more than $129 million worldwide.
It featured Lohan as Cady Heron, a home-schooled teenager who moves to suburban Illinois from Africa with her family.
She falls in with a group of cool girls known as The Plastics — played by Rachel McAdams, Amanda Seyfried and Lacey Chabert — only to find that they are secretly vicious bullies.

human: On Dec. 11, NASA engineers anxiously gathered at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory in Pasadena, Calif., to view a cat video, wondering if it would be in the pristine high definition for which they had hoped.
llm: On Dec. 11, the Internet was abuzz with talk of a NASA-produced video depicting two cats playing in space.
Well, the feline stars are back with a sequel to their original hit.

The new video is called “Cat in Zero G” and shows two felines named Félicette and Mr. Mach doing what they do best: chasing lasers, exploring boxes, and just generally having fun while floating around.

human: And just like that, Ron DeSantis’s quest for the presidency is kaput.
In a short video on Sunday, the Florida governor looked natty in a blue suit and red tie, every hair perfectly in place as he papered over his deeply imperfect campaign.
He touted his leadership and, perhaps with an eye toward running again in 2028, endorsed the Republican kingmaker, Donald Trump.
It wasn’t a terrible performance, especially under the circumstances.
But watching Mr. DeSantis’s now-famous awkward smile and listening to his unnatural cadence, it was hard not to think:
Yeah.
I can see why this guy’s candidacy is deader than disco.
llm: And just like that, we've got ourselves a race.

human: “So, well, there’s that.”
You said it, Axe.

The penultimate episode of “Billions” has now come and gone, and with it one of the show’s final opportunities to really blow us away with a patented five-steps-ahead scheme that ends in a sudden twist turning everything on its ear.
That is … not what we got.
llm: “So, well, there’s not much to say.
She won.”

human: Former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday defended six Nevada Republicans who were recently indicted in connection with a scheme to overturn his 2020 election loss, claiming without evidence that they were victims of political persecution by the Biden administration.
llm: Former President Donald Trump on Thursday defended the six Republican lawmakers charged with conspiracy to commit voter fraud and election rigging, saying that they are “good people” who had only been trying to protect him from losing the 2020 presidential election.
“They’re good people,” Mr. Trump said of the defendants, who include Representatives Devin Nunes of California and Matt Gaetz of Florida.
“I don’t know if it was a conspiracy or not.
They were just doing what I told them to do.”

human: Ask Minnesotans about the state’s official flag, and prepare for a crush of critiques.
llm: Ask Minnesotans about their state flag, and you'll likely get a blank stare in return.
The design is little-known even to most locals, but that may change soon: A new flag could be on the horizon.

human: Could President Biden and Donald J. Trump really be locked in a close race among young voters — a group Democrats typically carry by double digits — as the recent Times/Siena polls suggest?
llm: Could President Biden be the best thing that could happen to the Republican party?

human: Clallam County in Washington State is far from Washington, D.C. — almost as far as you can go without leaving the continental United States.
llm: Clallam County in the state of Washington has been voting against same-sex marriage for a long time.

human: Brothers and Sisters for Israel formed initially to protest judiciary reform.

llm: Brothers and Sisters, I have been asked by the family of our Brother in Christ, John “Jack” E. Riley Sr., Retired FDNY Firefighter, L-17, to notify you of his passing.
Jack was a Vietnam Veteran who served with B Troop 2nd/10th Cavalry, 4th Infantry Division from March 68 until March 69 when he was wounded.
He received a Purple Heart, Combat Infantry Badge and Army Commendation Medal for Valor.
His last assignment was as a Firefighter assigned to Ladder 17 in Manhattan.
Our thoughts and prayers are with his family and friends at this difficult time.
For those wishing to pay their respects, viewing will be held at McLaughlin K

human: After weeks of anticipation, a volcanic eruption in Iceland’s most populated area sent lava spewing into the night sky late Monday and pushed the authorities into action mode Tuesday.
The eruption, which was larger than volcanologists had predicted, happened not far from an evacuated town and a power plant.
llm: After weeks of unprecedented flooding in the Midwest, the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers is poised to open up a spillway north of New Orleans for only the third time since 1935.
It would be the first time it has ever been opened twice in one year.

human: “When I was maybe 3 years old or so, I was given a gold bracelet with dragons on it from my grandmother,” Diane Neuville said on a video call from Versailles, France, where she lives and works.
“My mother is Vietnamese, and in Vietnam jewelry in gold with gemstones is given to children and handed down from mother to daughter.
It’s symbolic, like a message of love from the family.”
llm: “When I was a little girl, my father bought me a ring.
He told me that it would be my birthday present every year and one day it would be mine to keep.”
That’s how designer Lilly Fitzgerald describes her introduction to jewels as a child growing up in Ireland.

Today she is the founder of Lilly Fitzgerald Jewellery (lillyfitzgerald.com), an eponymous line that caters to children and tweens, with whimsical pieces like unicorn rings ($50) and mermaid earrings ($49).
“It all started when I saw a gap in the market,” says Fitzgerald.
“I wanted something more exciting for my own daughter.”
The company has grown since its 2016 launch,

human: At age 80, Byron Wien compiled “20 Life Lessons” from a long career as a Wall Street soothsayer.
“Never retire” was No. 20.
“If you work forever, you can live forever,’’ he explained.
“I know there is an abundance of biological evidence against this theory, but I’m going with it anyway.”
llm: At age 80, Byron Wien was forced to retire from Blackstone.
But he wasn't ready for that, so he started a new career in his eighties, becoming an investment advisor with the firm Blackstone Advisory Partners.
In this role, he issued a yearly list of "ten surprises," or predictions of ten unexpected events that could happen during the upcoming year.
He did this for seven years.

human: Even in the Golden Age of musical theater, shows so commonly died after intermission that critics came up with a name for the disease.
“Second act trouble” presented in many ways: unmoored songs, desperate cutting, illogical crises, hasty workarounds.
Yet all those second act symptoms arose from the same underlying condition: first act ambitions.
llm: Even in the age of autotune, a great voice is still what makes or breaks a pop star.
It was one of the first things we heard from Alicia Keys, whose 2001 debut album Songs In A Minor announced the arrival of a new soul singer with pipes to spare.
But after six albums, Keys has hit a rut.
“I don’t know if I can be myself anymore,” she sings on her latest, Here.
The statement doubles as a confession and a warning.

human: Inside the “blueberry muffin” conference room, the walls are, naturally, painted blue.
Not just any blue — it’s the calming color you might find a baby’s bedroom, what the paint can refers to as “sea to shining sea.”
Anchoring the room is a table, red and oblong, adorned with fake succulents in purple pots.
llm: Inside the “blueberry” building of LinkedIn’s Sunnyvale, California office.
Photo by Jasper Sanidad via LinkedIn.

human: Robert Card displayed a textbook set of warning signs: He was hearing voices.

And his behavior had markedly changed in the months leading up to the mass shooting he carried out last week.
llm: Robert Card displayed a "Jesus loves you" sign on his lawn after 10 people were shot and killed at the municipal building in Appalachian Trail, Pa., on Aug. 4.

human: America’s Democratic governors brag about booming local economies, preside over ribbon-cuttings of projects paid for with new federal legislation and have successfully framed themselves as defenders of abortion rights and democracy.
llm: America’s Democratic governors gathered in Philadelphia to talk about how to beat President Donald Trump — but the potential candidates were also given some advice on how not to lose.

human: In a perfect world, you’d always be able to serve your Thanksgiving turkey directly after its sojourn in the oven.
It’s the best way to take advantage of the bird’s crisp juiciness and meaty aroma — not to mention a chance to hide in the kitchen from football games.
llm: In a perfect world, you’d have the time to cook Thanksgiving dinner all in one day.
But if you’re like me, you probably have other commitments—work, school, or family—that take up your weekday hours and leave little time for cooking.
If this is the case, I recommend cooking your turkey ahead of time, and reheating it on Thursday.
It makes life much easier.
Here’s how to do it.

human: What you need to understand about a sniper mission is that from the minute it begins to the minute it ends, everything you do is in service of killing another human being.
llm: What you need to know about Russia's military

Israel just ordered a “complete siege” of Gaza, as rockets continue to land on both sides of the border and Israeli forces prepare for a potential ground invasion.

human: Mayor Eric Adams of New York on Thursday ratcheted up his feud with Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas, filing suit against 17 transportation companies that he said had carried out a plan by Mr. Abbott to send more than 30,000 migrants to New York City and make the city pay for their care.

human: The House voted on Tuesday to oust Kevin McCarthy, Republican of California, from the speakership, an unprecedented development that plunged the chamber into chaos.
llm: The House voted 240-186 to impeach President Donald Trump on Wednesday, with one independent and no Republicans joining Democrats in favor of the first article of impeachment, abuse of power.
Two Democrats joined all Republicans present in voting against it.

The vote was almost entirely along party lines: Rep. Justin Amash (I–Mich.) joined all Democrats present in supporting the measure; Reps. Jeff Van Drew (D–N.J.), Jared Golden (D–Maine), Collin Peterson (D–Minn.), and Tulsi Gabbard (D–Hawaii) joined all Republicans present in opposing it.

human: Ohio voters are deciding on a ballot measure that would amend the state’s Constitution to explicitly guarantee the right to abortion.
llm: Ohio voters are considering a proposed constitutional amendment that would establish the right to abortion in Ohio.
The measure, Issue 1, has received little attention and few resources from national groups but could have major implications for reproductive rights in the state.

human: When you’re choosing curtains for a room, there are so many things to consider.
Jake Arnold, an interior designer in Los Angeles, walks us through it.
llm: When you’re choosing the right curtains for your home, it’s important to consider a few things.
The first is whether or not they will fit with the existing decor of your room, and if they will match the color scheme.
You also need to think about how much sunlight they let in, as well as their energy efficiency.
It’s also important to consider what type of fabric you want them made out of, as this will determine the longevity of your curtains.
However, no matter which ones you choose, you can hang them yourself if you follow these simple instructions.

human: It started with a postcard-perfect snapshot.

An image of India’s prime minister, Narendra Modi, lounging in a chair on a secluded white-sand beach, provoked heated words from officials in the Maldives, a tiny archipelago nation in the Indian Ocean.
llm: It started with a beach.

human: Britain’s Supreme Court ruled on Wednesday that a policy to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda is unlawful, dealing a major blow to a Conservative government that has long described the plan as central to its pledge to stop the arrival of the small boats that cross the English Channel.
llm: Britain’s Supreme Court has ruled that the Home Office cannot deport asylum seekers to Rwanda if they face a real risk of persecution there because of their race or ethnic origin.

The court rejected an appeal by the British government against an earlier decision by the Court of Appeal that it was unlawful to remove individuals from Britain to Rwanda on the basis of assurances given by the Kigali regime.
The ruling will have implications for other countries to which the U.K. seeks to return refugees whose applications are rejected.

human: In the most recent Modern Love essay, “When Your Search History Says What You Can’t,” Kassia Oset shares a cautionary tale of the heart and the browser.
llm: In the most recent issue of Wired magazine (March 2015), there is an article by Mat Honan entitled, "Love Letter: When Google Search Reveals Too Much".
It's a great read about how our lives are revealed through search results.
I encourage you to check it out.
The article focuses on how a Google search for his name reveals a lot of personal information about him.
It's not necessarily bad stuff - just stuff that he would prefer be private and confidential.

human: The word ordeal has appeared in 291 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 31 in “I Was Trying to Build My Son’s Resilience, Not Scar Him for Life” by Erik Vance:
llm: The word ordeal is a noun meaning “a very difficult or unpleasant situation, experience, or period of time.”
It is most often used to describe a particularly bad situation that someone has to endure.

human: In “Oppenheimer,” the writer and director Christopher Nolan’s summer blockbuster biopic — three words that generally don’t go together — the character of Kitty Oppenheimer is effaced twice over.
llm: In “Oppenheimer,” the new film about J. Robert Oppenheimer, the father of the atomic bomb, Emily Blunt plays Kitty Oppenheimer, his wife.
As Blunt explains to WWD, she didn’t really care whether her character was likable or not.

human: In Weirton, W.Va., in the heart of coal country, a company started by MIT scientists plans to build a plant that will produce a metal and alloy critical for clean energy, fuel cells and cleaner steel.
llm: In Weirton, W.Va., the steel mill has been closed for years.
The city’s tax base is gone and its population has fallen by half since 1960.
The only growth industry in town is the local funeral home.
But now, the federal government has awarded $4 million to build a manufacturing plant that will make parts for wind turbines.

human: As a racketeering trial begins in Atlanta, much of the focus is on the high-profile defendant, the best-selling rapper Young Thug.
llm: As a racketeering trial involving Tekashi 6ix9ine nears its conclusion, the line between the gangster-rapper persona he crafted online and his actual criminal behavior has blurred.

human: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump on Tuesday made their final written request to a federal appeals court to grant Mr. Trump immunity to charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election, arguing the indictment should be tossed out because it arose from actions he took while in the White House.
llm: Lawyers for former Trump campaign manager Corey Lewandowski and White House deputy chief of staff Rick Dearborn have filed their own motion asking that the case be tossed out.

human: Astrid Delgado first wrote her college application essay about a death in her family.
Then she reshaped it around a Spanish book she read as a way to connect to her Dominican heritage.
llm: Astrid Delgado first learned that she might have to work harder than her white classmates when she was in middle school and took an exam for a private high school.
When the results came back, her father was upset to learn that his daughter had scored 90 percent or higher on all but one part of the test — where she got only 51 percent.
The section asked students to choose words from a list that best described themselves.
Ms. Delgado, who is now 23, said she chose “shy” because it seemed like the right answer.
But her father, who was born in Mexico, thought otherwise.
“My dad told me I should have put ‘Latina,’” she said.
“I didn’t think about my race.”

human: When is walking in circles a good thing?
When following a trail through villages, forests and fields using open-access paths that begin and end at the same train station.
llm: When is walking around in circles not a waste of time?
When it’s a labyrinth, apparently.
And you can find some great ones just outside the capital.
